Description: This file stores information about new-style cross-references defined on afile. Whereas traditional cross-references are stored under the 1 nodes ofthe this file and can consist of one field (simple cross-references), as wellas more than one field (compound cross-references).
This file stores destinations of data (e.g., a specific form orsystem).  A field can be associated with a destination of its data.

This file stores information about keys on a file or subfile. A key is aset of one or more fields that uniquely identifies a record in a file. Ifmore than one set of fields can uniquely identify a record, one of thosesets should be designated the primary key; all others should be designatedsecondary keys. The primary key is the principal means of identifyingrecords in the file. To allow FileMan to enforce key uniqueness, the database designer mustdefine a regular index that consists of all the fields that make up thekey. This index is called the uniqueness index. All key fields must have values. They cannot be null.
This file stores the PRINT FIELDS data and other information about printtemplates.  These templates are used in the Print, Filegram, Extract, andExport options.

This file stores either SORT or SEARCH criteria. For SORT criteria, theSORT DATA multiple contains the sort parameters. For SEARCH criteria, thetemplate also contains a list of record numbers selected as the result ofrunning the search.

This field contains the first subscript from the part of the DPP arraythat contains overflow code executed when sorting by a field that isgotten to relationally or a computed field.  Overflow code is generatedwhen needed by DICOMP.  This field will typically look something like"OVF0".
This file stores the EDIT FIELDS data from an input template.
This file stores ScreenMan forms, which are composed of blocks.  Theform's attributes that describe how information is presented on the screenare contained in this file.
This file stores ScreenMan blocks, which are used to build forms in theForm file.
This multiple holds information about each field being exported.
This file stores the characteristics of various file export formats,which are used by the Export tool in building Export Templates to senddata to non-M systems.
Description and information about the format's other name.
A description of the foreign format.
Information about the use of the format; for example, which commands onthe foreign system should be used to load the file.

This file stores information about FUNCTIONS used by FileMan.  The first100 records in this file are reserved for functions brought in during theFileMan INIT process.  The rest of the file is available for otherdevelopers to enter their own functions.
This file stores an audit trail of changes made to data dictionaries.

This file stores operating system-specific code.  Since the code to invokesome operating system utilities that FileMan uses varies among operatingsystems, code to perform these utilities is stored in and executed fromthis file.  During the FileMan INIT process an operating system isselected so that FileMan knows which entry to use from this file.
This file stores all of the data types that VA FileMan allows in theMODIFY FILE ATTRIBUTES option.
This multiple lists all the PROPERTIES that specify what this DATA TYPE does.
This multiple lists all the METHODS that specify what this DATA TYPE does.

This multiple field list all fields in this database that point to this DATA TYPE.  These are not editable here.The values are stuffed automatically when a field using this DATA TYPE is created under 'MODIFY FILE ATTRIBUTES'.

This file stores information used for creating compiled SORT routines.During the FileMan SORT/PRINT option, if the user has specified that asort template is compiled, a routine name is generated by concatenating"DIZS" with the next available number from this list.  A flag indicateswhether or not a number is currently in use.

This file stores the dialog used to 'talk' to a user (error messages,help text, and other prompts.) Entry points in the retrieve text from this file.  Variable parameters can be passed to thesecalls.  The parameters are inserted into windows within the text as it isbuilt.  The text is returned in an array.  This file and associated callscan be used by any package to pass information in arrays rather thanwriting to the current device.  Record numbers 1 through 10000 arereserved for VA FileMan.
Used for internal documentation purposes.

Actual text of the message.  If parameters (variable pieces of text) areto be inserted into the dialogue when the message is built, the parameterwill appear as a 'window' in this TEXT field, surrounded by vertical bars.The data within the 'window' will represent a subscript of the inputparameter list that is passed to BLDbuilding the message. This same subscript should be used as the .01 of thePARAMETER field in this file to document the parameter.
Insert here the non-English equivalent for this language to the text inthe TEXT field for this entry.  This field may contain windows forvariable parameters the same as the TEXT field.

The LANGUAGE file is used both to officially identify a language, and tostore MUMPS code needed to do language-specific conversions of data suchas dates and numbers. The KIDS build for FileMan 22.2 contains all languages in ISO 639-2:1998(as revised 11/21/2012).When installed without the KIDS build, FileMan 22.2 installs 11 languages. A pointer to this file from the TRANSLATION multiple on the DIALOG filealso allows non-English text to be returned via FileMan calls. A note to VISTA developers: Although users can select entries by name, software should use the official two or three letter codes to eliminate mistakes resulting from languages that have similar spelling.
This multiple contains other names by which the language in this entry is known.
This file stores the names of different kinds of STRINGS that describe data.
This file stores the names of different kinds of lines of MUMPS code that are used in the definitions of DATA TYPES

The Meta Data Dictionary file contains detailed information about the Fields in FileMan Files.  The information is retrieved from the installed data dictionaries by running the 'Update the META Data Dictionary'Option on the Data Dictionary Utilities menu.  That option runs the DDD routine.
Contains the text of the HELP-PROMPT and DESCRIPTION of the Field, if available.Built by the DDD routine.
This file stores the descriptive information for all files in the FileManmanaged database.
This multiple contains the renderings of the File's NAME in various languages.
This file stores an audit trail of changes made to data fields.
This file stores information and status of data archiving activities.
This file stores information and status of filegram activities.
This file stores information about Filegram errors and the textof the affected Filegrams.

This file stores information about the editors that can be used to edit VAFileMan WP fields. The LINE EDITOR and SCREEN EDITOR are exported with VAFileMan, but instructions are given to allow site managers to enter localeditors of their choice.  There is a pointer in the NEW PERSON File tothis file.  The pointed-to editor for that person is then used wheneverthe person edits a WP field.
This is a description of the editor that will be shown to the userif they enter ??? at the Select prompt.Not in use yet.
A set of tables and domains. A subset of catalog and environment
SQL identifiers that may not be used for column and table names. SQL, ODBC and vendors all have lists of restricted words, whichshould be put in this table before SQLI table generation.

A set of values from which all domains of that type may be drawn.PRIMARY_KEY - the set of all primary keys (in SQLI_TABLE_ELEMENT, type P)CHARACTER - the set of all character strings of length less than 256INTEGER - the set of all cardinal numbersNUMERIC - the set of all real numbersDATE - the set of all date valued tokensTIME - the set of all time valued tokensMOMENT - the set of all tokens which have both a date and a time valueBOOLEAN - the set of all tokens which evaluate to true or false onlyMEMO - the set of all character strings of length > 255

The set from which all objects of that domain must be drawn.In SQLI, all table elements (SQLI_TABLE_ELEMENT) have a domain whichrestricts them to their domain set. For each data type there is a domainof the same name, representing the same set. Other domains have differentset membership restrictions.  Each domain has a data type, which determines the rules for comparingvalues from different domains, and the operators which may be used on them. The PRIMARY_KEY data type and domain is unique to SQLI. It is used torelate primary keys to foreign keys unambiguously (see SQLI_TABLE_ELEMENT)

Strategies for converting base values into key values.Soundex and upper case conversion are common examples. This implies thatcomparisons of key values with base values must be preceded by conversionof the base value to key value. Key formats are frequently lossy; theycan't be converted uniquely back to base format.

Strategies for converting base values to external values.In FileMan they are used to convert references to pointers totheir text values. They are also used for the SET OF CODES type. SQLI projects pointer and set of codes as calls to $$GET1variable pointer into calls to $$EXTERNAL Vendors and other users of SQLI may choose to implement their own conversions to improve performance.

Descriptor of a set of table elements: Includes name and file no.(See SQLI_TABLE_ELEMENTS). Each model of FileMan. Further, each index represents a table.  Each schema contains multiple tables. Each table contains just one primarykey, but multiple columns, foreign keys and indicies.

Names and domains of primary keys, columns and foreign keys.Each represents the relational concept of an attribute, whose essentialcharactaristics are a name (unique by relation) and a domain. See SQLI_PRIMARY_KEY, SQLI_COLUMN and SQLI_FOREIGN key for more.

A set of formatting and physical structure specifications.Each column specification has a column type table element(SQLI_TABLE_ELEMENT) which contains the relational specifications, nameand domain. The column specification contains those attributes requiredto locate the value in the global structure, and to project the value tothe user.

A chosen set of columns which uniquely identify a table.In the relational model (as in set theory) the columns of a primary keyare not ordered. In SQLI they must be, in order to map to the quasi-hierarchical model of M globals. FileMan subfiles (multiples) have a primary key element for each parentplus one for the subfile. Each contains a pointer to its primary key tableelement (SQLI_TABLE-ELEMENT), a sequence and a column in the local base table (SQL_COLUMN).

A set of columns in a table that match the primary key of another table. They represent an explicit join of the two tables. Each foreign key element points to it's table element (SQLI_TABLE_ELEMENT),a column in the local table (SQLI_COLUMN) and a primary key element of a foreign table (SQLI_PRIMARY_KEY). The primary key table element of theforeign table has the domain of that table, which makes the connection.
A numbered list of error messages, auto-generated by ERR

Log of all errors encountered while compiling SQLI.It generates the error text table (SQLI_ERROR_TEXT) on a laygo basis;errors are added only when they occur. If DBS errors triggered theerror, the DIALOG file reference is also saved.
This file denotes time zone designations used throughout the world.
This multiple contains all the occurrences of timeframe that may existfor the given time zone.

Country is found under timeframe because while all countries follow STANDARD timeframe, not every country in the same timezone follows DAYLIGHT SAVINGS or SUMMER timeframe.A country should be listed under one or more timeframes that they follow.
This file is used to track which countries have periods during the yearin which they follow DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME, STANDARD TIME, or SUMMER TIME.

Some countries change their timeframe every year and sometimesthere are gaps or they stop altogether.  The year indicates whetherthis specific country changed their timeframe on the specific dateand time listed.
This file contains the list of valid races.  The allowable entries aremaintained by VA Central Office and, as such, alteration and/or additionof entries is not allowed.
This multiple contains all alternate names by which this race can be calledup by a user.
This file contains the list of valid ethnicities.  The allowable entriesare maintained by VA Central Office and, as such, alteration and/oraddition of entries is not allowed.

This file contains the list of valid collection methods for race and ethnicity.  The allowable entries are maintained by VA Central Office and,as such, alteration and/or addition of entries is not allowed.
This is the file of orders/requisitions made for any package through theOrder Entry Option (OR).
This multiple contains the items being ordered.
This field allows a single order or set of orders to be linked to a parent order.
These are the actions taken on this order, including the signature andverification required to release to the service.
This is the text of the order.

This is the text of the order stored in external format.DO NOT EDIT THIS FIELD!  This field is used to create a Digital Signature.Editing this field will render the Digital Signature invalid and preventthe order from being processed.
This is where ward or clinic comments on orders are stored.

This file contains the possible statuses that may be associated withan order in OE/RR. Per VHA Directive 2005-044, this file has been "locked down" by Data Standardization (DS).  The file definition (i.e. data dictionary) shall not be modified.  All additions, changes and deletions to entries in the file shall be done by Enterprise Reference Terminology (ERT) using the Master File Server (MFS), provided by Common Services (CS).   Creating and/or editing locally defined fields in the file are not permitted.  Use of locally defined fields that were created prior to VHA Directive 2005-044 shall not be supported.
Describes the pair Status and Effective Date/Time for each reference term.

This file should not be added to or deleted from.  It determines theactions that are to be taken based on the nature of an order or change toan order. Per VHA Directive 2005-044, this file has been "locked down" by Data Standardization (DS).  The file definition (i.e. data dictionary) shall not be modified.  All additions, changes and deletions to entries in the file shall be done by Enterprise Reference Terminology (ERT) using the Master File Server (MFS), provided by Common Services (CS).   Creating and/or editing locally defined fields in the file are not permitted.  Use of locally defined fields that were created prior to VHA Directive 2005-044 shall not be supported. The Orders Domain has approved editing of the following fields in thisfile: - PRINT CHART COPY (#.12) - PRINT DAILY SUMMARY (#.13) - PRINT WORK COPY (#.15) - INCLUDE IN ACTIVE ORDERS (#.16)This may be accomplished via the option "Print Parameters for Nature of Order" [ORCL NATURE], on the "Print/Report Parameters" [OR PARAM PRINTS] menu.
Describes the pair Status and Effective Date/Time for each reference term.

This file is used to define the possible reasons for DC'ing/cancellingan order.  The entries are identified by package so that each packagecan have their own set of reasons.  Sites may wish to modify theentries in this file to fit their needs.  It is important to maintainthe correct links to the Radiology Reason file if modifications aremade.  These links are maintained in the CODE field.  For Radiologyreasons, the code field is the internal # of the radiology reason filefollowed by the characters RA. This file points the the Nature of Order file.  This relationshipis what identifies the appropriate actions to take for any DC Reason.
This contains the responses to an order dialog.
This contains responses to items that are a word processing type.
The purpose of this file is to create a repository for instances of order checks that are presented to the users of VISTA across all applications.
These are the the diagnoses associated with this order.
The dispense drug(s) associated with the order check.

Contains the interacting pharmacy pending inpatient orders, pendingoutpatient orders and outpatient prescriptions for duplicate drugs, drug-drug interactions, Clozapine and duplicate therapy order checks.
Contains the lab result(s) for Clozapine order checks.
This is the list of order checks found for this order.

Contains the interacting pharmacy non-VA medication, unit dose, and IVorder numbers, as well as remote outpatient prescriptions, for theduplicate drugs, drug-drug interactions, Clozapine and duplicate therapyorder checks.
This field contains interacting IV Additive(s) for drug interactions andduplicate therapy order checks.
This field contains interacting IV Solution(s) for drug interactions andduplicate therapy order checks.
This is the description of the status.
Contains the clinical effects for drug-drug interaction order checks.
This field contains the interacting IV Additive(s) for drug interactions and duplicate therapy order checks.
This file is used by CPRS to track what happened to a patient's orders asa result of an event, such as an MAS movement or returning from the OR.
This file contains data related to lists.  Generally these lists take theform of provider(s)/patients.
The list member is an item on the list.  The member for personal and team patient lists is a patient (if list type is P or T, this field points tothe patient file.)
This field is unused and will be deleted post-CPRS 1.
These are the user(s) that belong to the list.  If the list is of typeTEAM PATIENT or PERSONAL PATIENT, users on the list may receive clinical notifications for patients also on the list.

This field is used to link the list with WARDs, ROOM-BEDs,PROVIDERs, TREATING SPECIALTYs, or CLINICs.  This field  points to the entry in the file where the link is to occur.  When ADT movement occur for patients, they areadded to the appropriate OE/RR lists as identified by theAUTOLINK field (via "AC" cross-ref).Lists with autolink providers are updated (patient added) when the PROVIDERlink matches the entry at the PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN or ATTENDINGPHYSICIAN prompts.

Entries in this file with an internal number >1000 have been exportedwith the OE/RR package.  Everytime a new version of OE/RR is installedthe entries above 1000 are removed and overwritten. If you want to use one of these exported entries, transfer the entryto a number less than 1000 and give it a new name so that it can bedifferentiated from exported entry.
If present, the word-processing type data in this field will be presentedin lieu of the EXAMPLE ENTRY data, when the FORMATTING FUNCTION is specifiedto be WORD (e.g., REASON FOR REQUEST).

Entries in this file with an internal number >1000 have been exportedwith the OE/RR package.  Everytime a new version of OE/RR is installedthe entries above 1000 are removed and overwritten. If you want to use one of these exported entries, transfer the entry toa number less than 1000 and give it a new name so that it can bedifferentiated from the exported entry.
Each format includes one or more fields that are compiled here.
This is the MUMPS code that is compiled when using the PRINT FORMATSutility in OE/RR to build print formats.  This field should not beedited.
This field contains M code that gets executed by 'Silent API's' toproduce formatted text arrays for use in GUI or other applications.

This file is used to store "Combination" pointers for Patient SelectionLists in OE/RR.  Users can select individual default settings for Wards,Providers, etc. - but the "Combination" option allows them to set amultiple, or combination, of such choices.  When the user enters CPRS, thedefault patient list will be built from the combined list of sources inthis file (as compared to a single source).
This is the sub-file multiple for the combination source entries.
This multiple contains a log of actions taken on this event that arerelevant to the release or discontinuance of orders.
This multiple field contains the delayed orders that were released basedon the release event defined in the OE/RR RELEASE EVENTS file #100.5 whenthis event occurred.
This multiple contains the orders that were automatically discontinuedbased on the rules defined in the OE/RR AUTO-DC RULES file #100.6 whenthis event occurred.

This file contains a record of events that failed or errored outduring the use of OE/RR.  This file is not to be edited. It isfor debugging purposes.Entries in this file are automatically purged.  The life of anentry depends on the parameter ERROR DAYS in the ORDER PARAMETERSfile (100.99).
This contains a description of the error; if the error occurred withinthe processing of HL7 messages, the message itself may be stored here.

This file contains the locally-defined events that can release delayedorders within each division. It is strongly recommended that this file not be edited withFile Manager.  Please use the edit options provided within CPRS.
These are treating specialties that can satisfy this event; if thepatient's new specialty matches one in this list then orders delayedfor this event may be released.
These are ward locations that can satisfy this event; if the patient's newlocation matches one in this list then orders delayed for this event maybe released.
This field stores the monograph for Drug-Drug Interactions.
This sub-file contains drug allergies that were displayed during pharmacy(OP & IP) order entry.
This sub-file stores the drug classes associated with the drug allergy.
This sub-file contains drug ingredients associated with the drug allergies.
Signs and symptoms of drug allergy.
This field represents the reason that the provider is overriding the order check and continuing with placing the order.
This field stores the text of the order check that was presented to the user.

This file contains the locally-defined rules that control if and whenactive orders are automatically discontinued within each division. It is strongly recommended that this file not be edited usingFile Manager.  Please use the edit options provided in CPRS.
These are the MAS Movement Types that define this event; when an MAS eventoccurs for one of these types, this rule will be processed if active.
These are treating specialties that will cause this rule to not beprocessed, if the EXCEPT FROM and TO specialties match the patient'stransfer.
These are treating specialties that will cause this rule to not beprocessed, if the EXCEPT FROM and TO specialties match the patient'stransfer.
These are the divisions that will cause this rule to be processed, if theFROM division matches the patient's transfer.
These are the packages whose orders are to be automatically discontinuedwhen this rule is processed.
These are the orderable items that are NOT to be automaticallydiscontinued when this rule is processed, even if an order for it belongsto a package in the INCLUDED PACKAGES multiple.
This file stores the electronic Prescribing of Controlled Substances (ePCS) parameters used by CPRS.
Users for which ePCS is enabled.
This field contains the interacting IV Solution(s) for drug interactions andduplicate therapy order checks.
This file contains the order checks which are used within OE/RR-CPRS toperform real-time order checking within the OE/RR-CPRS ordering dialogs.
This field describes the order check.

This file contains data used to generate notifications.  Packagesdetermine if a notification should be sent then send the patient ID andnotification ID (IEN in this file) to order entry routines.  Based on thenotification IEN, data from this file is used to generate the notificationand help determine its recipients.
This field tells the notification system any special instructions to follow when creating the notification.

This file allows orders to be clustered in groups other than by package.It is similar in structure to the OPTION File (19).  This allows displaygroups to be arranged in a hierarchy.  The main entry in this fileshould be 'ALL SERVICES'.  Other entries should be logically subordinateto the 'ALL SERVICES' entry.
This is a list of specific display groups that `belong' to the displaygroup listed in the NAME field.  (This is similar to menu items in theOPTION File.)
This file contains site specific parameters for OE/RR.  It has onlyone entry.
Here are the package specific parameters that can be modified bythe installation site.
This multiple allows each package to have multiple service copy printdevices.  Such a model is often necessary at multidivisional sites, orfor DHCP packages which serve multiple hospital services.
This multiple will store patients that have not yet been converted by theOE/RR version 3.0 (CPRS) orders conversion.  It is maintained by theconversion and should not be edited or updated.
This is a list of the protocols for which corresponding entries have beencreated in the Order Dialog file.
This is a list of the protocols for which corresponding entries were notsuccessfully created in the Order Dialog file.
This is the name of the system as found in the global nodesystem that generates orders.
This field allows parameters to be set up for each location in the hospital that uses OE/RR.

This field allows each package to define its own set of parameters.The entries in this multiple field are exported much the same asentries in the PACKAGE File are exported when a package is initialized.
Protocols entered in this multiple will be exported with this package.
This field allows a package to install its protocols on menus thatmay be in a different namespace.  The protocol is installed at theinstallation site if the menu exists on that system.
This set of fields is used by a clinical coordinator utility to defineprotocols in the PROTOCOL file for specific procedures that are orderablefor ancillary services.

This file points to file 405.2, MAS MOVEMENT FILE.  It identifies VistA movement types that require special handling for the R1FHVC ADT interface. For version 1.0 of the software, the movements and their classification are: R1FHVC MOVEMENT TYPES LIST                     DEC 10,2010  08:27  NUMBER  NAME                                 EXCEPTION-------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1       AUTH ABSENCE 96 HOURS OR LESS          TO LEAVE2       AUTHORIZED ABSENCE                     TO LEAVE3       UNAUTHORIZED ABSENCE                   TO LEAVE13      TO ASIH (VAH)                          TO ASIH14      FROM ASIH (VAH)                        FROM ASIH22      FROM UNAUTHORIZED ABSENCE              FROM LEAVE23      FROM AUTH. ABSENCE OF 96 HOURS OR L    FROM LEAVE24      FROM AUTHORIZED ABSENCE                FROM LEAVE25      FROM AUTHORIZED TO UNAUTHORIZED ABS    IGNORE26      FROM UNAUTHORIZED TO AUTHORIZED ABS    IGNORE40      TO ASIH                                TO ASIH41      FROM ASIH                              FROM ASIH45      CHANGE ASIH LOCATION (OTHER FACILITY)  IGNORE

This file holds pointers to future discharges that are created wheninpatients are transferred with movement type ASIH (OTHER FACILITY).The vendor system cannot accept movements with future dates, sothis file will be checked periodically for discharge movements thathave 'expired', and if the movement still exists with the originaldischarge date, an A03 message will be sent to the vendor system.

Contains site-specific and vendor implementation-specific itemsfor the VistA Nutrition &Food Service interface.There should only be ONE ENTRY in this file. The package was designed to send patient ADT and diet orders toa commercial system.
File to maintain link between package file 9.4 and VA's VDL URL specific to this package.
Translation file for CORI4 interface.  Allows lookup of a Cori Report Header to see which field in file 699 receives the data
Parameter file for the CORI/VISTA HL7 interface
A conversion template is used to convert or translate one HL7 message to another, or to build an HL7 message from scratch.

Contains various pieces of information for this device, such as:    1            IRM 2237 COMPLETE DATE   2            IRM 2237 COMPLETING PERSON   3            LOCATION LAST UPDATED DATE   4            LOCATION LAST UPDATED BY   5            PRINTER NAME   6            OLD LOCAL ID   7            SOFTWARE UPDATES DATE
Contains Loan Out information for a device.
Information on a "Short Term Loaner" fleet, if a site has one.  These are devices designed to be loaned out on a short term basis only.
Contains historical loan out info for a device.
This file contains the report definitions for the daily BCMA printouts.
The number of lines is limited to 4.
Region 1 phone directory for all sites.
This file is used by the Consult Closure Tool to associate consults,clinics, and note titles.
Select a consult service.
Select a consult procedure.
Select a consult order item.
Select a consult clinical procedure.
Select a clinic associated with the consult(s).
Select a note title associated with the consult(s) / clinic(s).
This stores the definition of the configuration when using the [S]FTP APImenu mode entry point.
This stores a transcription of the session log when using the menumode entry point of the [S]FTP API.
This file is used to public/private encryption key pairs used in sftp file transfers.
This field holds the text of the public encryption key.
This field holds the encrypted text of the private encryption key.

This field is used to hold the description of the encryption key.  The description might include such information as which VistA option uses the encryption key and which remote site the public encryption key was sent to.

This field is used to hold the reason the encryption key was inactivated.The inactivation reason might include such information as which VistAoption uses the encryption key, which remote site the public encryptionkey was sent to, and why the key was inactivated.
Additional information regarding Surgery cases.
Collective information regarding Surgery cases.
This is the CPT code corresponding to the principal operative procedure.
This file contains parameters to be used with the R2WL Welch Allyn Vitals application.
This file contains the orderables and methods for accomplishing orders(protocols) within OE/RR.
This is the item multiple for a protocol
This is another name for the protocol that may be used on lookup.

This lists the variables that must be defined for the proper execution ofthis protocol.  This aids in documenting the protocol.  Also, in the caseof ';' jumping, the variables defined as required may be newed beforejumping, thus preserving the context when returning from the jump.
This multiple contains the list of security keys which allow access tothe protocol.  If there are no keys, all users have access.
This is text used as a template for an item in a dialog that is a wordprocessing type.
This number identifies individual methods (actions) that may be invokedfor this protocol.
This field contains a brief explanation of the protocol.
This is a namespaced name of a set.  If this is entered, a cross referenceof the format "S.set membership" is created.  This allows rapid lookups onsubsets of the Protocol file.

This is a scratch file used for entering word processing fields usedduring dialogs.  It allows text to be captured and edited before it isactually passed to the database.  Entries in this file are very transient.They are created, accepted, transferred to a destination file, thendeleted.
This contains the actual text that has been entered.
This file stores CPRS GUI Cover Sheet tab acronyms.
Optional description of COM Object.  Should include any contactinformation for vendor or other provider of the COM Object.

This file contains definitions and parameters used in various reportswithin CPRS. Entry numbers >1000 are reserved for national use.  Any local entriesshould be added to a number <1000.  If this convention is not followed,you run the risk of having your local entries overwritten by a patchor future release of CPRS.
This field contains a description of what the execute code does.
This file contains the information needed to define how to prompt for eachorder, what values are acceptable, etc.
This is a description of the dialog and its uses.

This field contains the components for dialogs:     Dialogs      -> prompts     Quick orders -> prompts (completed)     Order sets   -> dialogs or quick orders     Menus        -> dialogs, quick orders, or order sets
This is default text to be stuffed into this word-processing prompt.
This multiple contains any responses to prompts that have been pre-answeredto create a quick order.
This contains the actual response, for word-processing type prompts.
This file contains the urgencies available to assign to an order.
This multiple contains all the possible ways to use this urgency.
This file contains the orderable items for use within OE/RR.
This multiple contains the components of this orderable item, i.e. drugingredients or tests in a lab panel.
This multiple contains synonyms for this orderable item, used whensearching the file.
This field contains text that is to be displayed to the user wheneverthis item is selected to be ordered.
This field contains the names of sets to which this orderable item belongs.When a set name is entered here, a cross-reference of the format "S.name"is created, allowing rapid lookups on this file.

The newer CPRS ordering dialogs use a Windows Listview control fordisplaying lists of orderable items and quick orders.  Using this controlwill help us rely less on custom built controls to handle long lists ofitems.  While the Listview control is able to operate on long lists ofitems, it must know at the outset how many items are potentially going todisplay and must be able to map from any sequence number produced by theListview control  to a specific item in the list.  The ORDER QUICK VIEWfile (101.44) provides this mapping.  It maps a subset of orderable itemsor quick orders in alphabetical order to specific sequence numbers.
This multiple contains the quick orders that belong to a given list.
This multiple contains the orderable items in a specific subset (lab,inpatient meds, diets, etc.).

The purpose of this file is to satisfy the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) requirementfor an electronic prescribing system to maintain an archive of all controlled substance prescriptions that were electronically entered. The file will store all the information that is considered a part of the prescription. The file should always be audited. In addition, the file should NEVER beedited using FileMan. These are both DEA requirements. In order to satisfy the requirement that both the prescribing (CPRS) and filling systems (Outpatient Pharmacy) create an archive, but to reduce the need for additional storage space, both CPRS and Pharmacy will use the same file. CPRS will create the entries when an order is signed or when a backdoor order message is received from Pharmacy. Once Pharmacy verifies the data in the Pharmacy system is an exact match for what CPRS stored, they will subscribe to the entry in the archive file and will update the PRESCRIPTION NUMBER (#1) field. The file was defined in a different global name in order to handle the volume set from the rest of the CPRS system (i.e., the ORDER file).It is important to note that to fully meet the DEA requirements, the fields required by the DEA cannot be pointers. We must store the data completely. The fields that are pointers are for our internal use, rather than for the DEA purposes.

This is a multiple field for storing the directions for use. In this particular storage location, directions are stored in the format that they are transmitted via the HL7 array and protocols to Pharmacy, rather than in human readable format.

The CPRS query tool provides a mechanism by which clinical users may search for items typically managed by CPRS.  These are very limited typesof queries.  A wizard helps the user construct the criteria used in thequery. This file contains definitions of queries used to build reports of CPRSitems (orders, consults, documents).  Each query definition contains alist of constraints.  These constraints are used by the query routines toreturn a subset of CPRS items. This file also contains definitions of report criteria.  These criteria are selected and modified by the user when building custom reports.  Areport criterion contains a list of constraints that apply to theparticular criterion. A critieron behaves much like a "mini-report". The other part of a query definition stored in this file is the list offields to be displayed after the query is run.  The query produces a columnar report with the selected display field in each column.
This multiple allows a sequence of captions to be defined that comprisethe default text of a query description.
This multiple contains formatting information for the columns of thereport.

This file contains the list of constraints that are available whendefining a query of CPRS items.  Each constraint is associated with a particular editor.  This is a graphical interface based editor.  The constraint name is also used to build the name=value pairs that make up the query.
This file contains a list of graphical editors that are available within the CPRS query tool for editing constraints.

This file contains display fields that may be selected.  Each display field may be a column in the results of a query.  For each display field, the file contains information about how the column should be sorted when clicked and some sample data to assist the user when setting up the columns.
This multiple contains sample data for this type of field that may bein a preview report.
This file contains patient tasks for the Care Management dashboards;all supporting attributes are stored here, as well as tracking of eachone's cancellation or fulfillment.
This multiple contains identifiers for items that have been linked tothis task.

This file contains all acknowledgments for order results captured viathe Care Management dashboards.  A stub is created here for the orderingprovider when new results become available for an order that s/he placed;the entry is then updated when the order is actually acknowledged viathe CM application.  An order's results may also be acknowledged byother users as well, such as the nursing staff caring for the patient.

This file captures flowsheet data in support of the the Anticoagulation Management Program (AMP), which is a Joint Commission National PatientSafety Goal initiative to use a standardized process for the management oftheir patients on extended anticoagulation therapy. AMP runs as a Windows Application from the CPRS Tools menu, and assists Clinicians with the expeditious documentation of visits to AnticoagulationClinics.
If patient allows leaving of anticoagulation messages with others at his/her phone number, this indicates WHO is allowed to receive the messages.
Word processing set of special instrections inputted into theAnticoagulator.Visible in the Anticoagulator and in the Header of the flow sheet on the REPORTS tab.
Word processing set of risk factors inputted into the Anticoagulator.  Visible in the Anticoagulator and in the Header of the flow sheet on the REPORTS tab.

Free text item to remind person who is accessing the Anticoagulator on a specific patient that something needs to be done.  Will only appear at or after the reminder date (field 80).example: "CBC due"
Free text or selected information on complication.
Free text information for this flow sheet entry.

This file holds the set of parameters which modify the operation of the MRSA Program Tools to suit the needs of your site. For multi-divisional facilities, each division should have a separate entry in this file.
This subfile contains specimen(s) for each division.
This file contains search criteria used by the MRSA Program Tools software. This file should only be edited using the MRSA Tools Lab Parameter Setup option provided with this software.

This file contains the different multi-drug resistant organisms (MDROs)that are needed for the MRSA Program Tools software. Entries in this fileshould not be edited. This file will be maintained by the support team.

This file contains the Ward Mappings for the MDRO Program Tools software. Here you will create 'Geographical Units' which consist of one or more Ward Locations (from file 42). For purposes of the MDRO Program Tools software all Ward Locations belonging to the same Geographical unit are one - and any interward transfers between wards belonging to the same geographical unit will be ignored.

This file contains Micom configurations to be automatically transferredto the Micom by the loader routine.  Each configuration has commands andmessages.  Commands are stored in the order they are to be transmittedto the Micom.  The system welcome message is a multi-line text.  Individualclass messages are 1 - 29 characters in length.  The configurationidentifier may be a number or name 1 - 8 characters.

This field stores the list of commands, in order, used to configurethe Micom. If using an Instanet 6600, you can run the routine automatically create the configuration by polling the administrationport.

The system welcome message will be automatically enabled for allselectable class terminals.  This message may be several lines longand up to 80 characters per line. This field should be left empty if using a Instanet 6600.  All messagesshould be entered in the 'Fixed class or Message number' field.
Class number and class message text for each class message to be entered.
Used to disconnect DZ devices from Micom ports when users log outthrough H Also used to map a printer to a Micom line number for use in printercontention.
This file is used to store the statistics logged from the MicomStatistics port.
This file is used to store the different action types of statisticssent from the Micom statistics port.  It is distributed with data.
This file allows the user to keep track of the locations that Micomlines go.  It also stores the cumulative statistics for each Micomline.
Stores daily statistics.

This file is used by printer contention to store an up to date mapof which Micom ports, connected to which device, on which system,is in use by printer contention.  This map is used to determine ifa printer (connected to a line) is being used by a Micom port/deviceconnected to another system.
This file stores the Micom site parameters.  There should be an entrymade into this file for each different cpu that is using the Micomsoftware.
Stores the configurations to be loaded when the system starts up.

The MARTIAL STATUS file currently consists of six entries whichare distributed by the MAS development team.  Alteration of any ofthe six entries or addition of entries to this file which are notdistributed by the MAS developers may have a negative impact onthe performance of the MAS module as well as other modules.

This file contains a list of all of the diet modifications allowedby the using facility. Associated with each diet are characteristicssuch as alternate names, an abbreviated name, whether a clinicianis to be bulletined when ordered, and a diet precedence whichis used to prevent diet conflicts and as a printing sequence order.
This field may be used for any number of alternate names forthe diet modification. These alternative names will normallybe those used by ward/medical personnel.
This file contains diet patterns.  The entries for a specific patternrepresent changes from the production diet for this particular pattern.
This multiple contains all the Standing Orders selected from file118.3 for breakfast.
This multiple contains all the breakfast Recipe Categories selectedand their quantities.
This multiple contains all the noon Recipe Categories selectedand their quantities.
This multiple contains all the evening Recipe Categories selectedand their quantities.
This multiple contains all the Diet restrictions associated to theDiet modification.
This multiple contains all the Standing Orders selected from file 118.3for noon.
This multiple contains all the Standing Orders selected from file118.3 for evening.
This file contains both standard USDA nutrient data based uponHandbook 456 and Revised Handbook 8 as well as user entered data.The standard data includes 32 common nutrients.

This file contains the values of the Dietary Reference Intakes (DRI). In1997, the Food and Nutrition Board began releasing updated recommendationsfor nutrient intake levels that apply to healthy individuals under a newframework called Dietary Reference Intakes.  For nutrients that have notyet been revised as DRI (protein for example) the 1989 RDA values are themost current recommendations and are used here.
This file contains menus of food items, classified by day and meal,which are saved for nutrient analysis.
This field contains the sequence number, or day number, of thedays represented by this menu. It is normally 1 to the maximumnumber of used entered.

This is the meal number for which food items will be entered.It is merely a sequence number and individual meals, such asbreakfast, noon, and evening are not referenced as such sincemeals may be snack times, or other eating times.
This multiple represents the food items, selected from theFood Nutrient file, which are represented in the meal.
This multiple stores the selected recipes from the Recipe fileused for the Meal Analysis.

This file is the master list of ingredients used in preparingrecipes. It contains purchasing information, such as stock numberand vendor, issuance data such as the issuing unit, and variousconversion factors. Nutritive data such as food group, poundagefactors, and a pointer to the analogous food nutrient item inFile 112 are also included.
This is the file of storage locations where ingredients arestored by the dietetic service. It is primarily used to sortvarious ingredient pull lists.
This file contains basic data on the various vendors supplyingingredients to the Dietetic Service. It contains address, telephonenumbers and name of contacts.
This file contains all recipes necessary to build meals. Eachrecipe consists of basic data concerning the recipe, variousingredients, and may also contain 'embedded' recipes.
This multiple contains the ingredients used in the recipe.
This multiple contains the Diabetic exchanges associated with thisrecipe.  It is use to handle the Diabetic calculated diets.

This field contains the directions for the preparation ofthe recipe. References to absolute quantities of aningredient should not be made since the recipe will normallybe printed in an 'adjusted' form -- that is, the number ofportions will be adjusted and hence the individual ingredientamounts will vary from those entered for the yield of therecipe.

This field contains recipes which are 'embedded' in this recipe.For example, a hot roast beef sandwich might contain breadas an ingredient but roast beef as an embedded recipe andperhaps even brown gravy as another embedded recipe.
This multiple is used to indicate the various types of equipmentnecessary to produce this recipe.
This file contains a basic list of categorizations which maybe applied to recipes. It is primarily used to sort and/ordetermine the order in which lists of recipes will print.

This file contains a list of areas in which food is prepared.Recipes may be classified by preparation area and this fileis used to sort recipes into the various preparation areasas well as determine the order in which various lists willprint.

This file contains a list of basic serving utensils. Recipesuse this file to indicate the most appropriate serving utensil.The utensil name is printed on various reports for use byserving personnel.
This file contains a list of basic equipment used in the preparationof recipes. A recipe may point to this list to indicate theprimary type of equipment used in the recipe preparation.

This file contains all dietetic orders for each admission of apatient. It includes diet orders, consult requests, supplementalfeedings, early/late tray requests, and tubefeedings. It alsocontains any food allergies entered for the patient.This file will also be used to store outpatient data for individualsserved in the outpatient meals functionality.
This multiple contains all dietetic information pertainingto this particular admission.
This field contains Nutrition Assessments performedfor this patient.
This multiple contains the nutrition assessmentstatuses that have been entered for this patient.
This multiple stores the recurring meals data.
This multiple stores special meals data.
This multiple stores the guest meals data.
This multiple contains the individual diet orders which havebeen entered during this admission.
This multiple contains laboratory data available for thenutrition assessment.
This multiple contains all of the dietetic consults orderedduring this admission.
This multiple contains all tubefeeding orders entered duringthis admission.
This multiple contains all early/late tray requests orderedfor this patient.
This multiple contains all Additional Orders entered during this admission.admission.
This multiple contains the various supplemental feeding orderswhich have been entered for the patient.
This field contains standing orders entered for the patientduring this admission.
This multiple contains the food preferences selected by the patient.
This multiple contains the tubefeeding products selected.
This multiple contains comments relating to the assessment.
This is a multiple for food/drug alert for a patient.

This multiple indicates the sequence in which the diet ordersactually become effective. Since orders entered later supercedeearlier orders, the sequence times may not be the same as thoseof the original order. This multiple is the outcome of arecursive templating schemata.
This multiple stores the tubefeeding product data for the recurring meal.

This file contains the items which can be selected as patientpreference items. It contains both items which can be selected,such as coffee or tea, as well as food preferences (such as no liver) which will result in certain recipes being excludedfor the patient.
In the case of a food preference, this multiple is the list ofexcluded recipes contained in the Recipe file (114) which shouldNOT be served to the patient.
This file contains site-specific nutrition classifications used innutrition assessment and screening.
This file contains the four nutrition statuses of the establishedguidelines that are used in nutrition assessment and screening.
This file contains a list of nutrition plan actions which arelisted on the Nutrition Screening form.
This file contains a list of types of dietetic encounters,or events, which are used to account for many of the professionalactivities of dietetic personnel.

This file contains the various dietetic encounters enteredby dietetics personnel. It includes patient-related events,such as diet instructions, as well as non-patient-relatedevents such as talks to the community.
This field is a multiple containing data relating to patientsinvolved in the encounter.
When a PTF record for an ODS patient is closed this file will automaticallybe populated with the billing bedsections and length of stay for thosebedsections.

A menu cycle consists of some specified number of days each dayof which is associated with a breakfast, noon, and evening meal.An effective date determines the start of the cycle and it willrepeat until the effective date of another menu cycle begins.
This field contains the day number within the cycle and istherefore 1 to the number of days in the cycle.

This multiple contains dates upon which this cycle will becomeeffective and will continue until superceded by the effectivedate of this or another cycle. The date becomes Day 1 of theselected cycle.

This file contains the various meals served by the institution. Ameal consists of all recipes prepared for a breakfast, noon, orevening meal as well as the production diets associated witheach recipe. In turn, the production diet entry may indicate thepercentage of that recipe that is to be served in a cafeteriaor by tray.
This multiple contains the various recipes which will beserved for the meal.
This mutiple contains popularity (or selection percentages) fortray and cafeteria for each Service Point.
This is a list of different recipe categories which maycharacterize this recipe.  The multiple also contains theproduction diets to which this category applies.
This file contains a list of the production diets which are thebasic diets actually prepared and from which the wide varietyof clinical diet modifications are derived.
This multiple contains a list of the production diets whichconstitute the combo production diet.

This file consists of a list of holiday dates for which specialmeals are prepared. It consists of the holiday date, name, andallows for entry of a breakfast, noon, and/or evening mealwhich, if present, will override the normal menu cycle mealson that date.
This file contains the statistical data necessary to prepare theServed Meals Report and the Staffing Data Report. Datais saved for each date.
This file contains the statistical data necessary to prepare theStaffing Data report. Data is saved for each date.
This file is used to store the monthly costs of the variousfood groups. Data is used to calculate the cost of mealsserved as well as ensure an adequate distribution offood across the food groups.

The Annual Dietetic Report is designed to facilitate data gatheringand to eliminate information that has been discontinued or deemedirrelevant.  The report will be compiled manually and submitted toCentral office Dietetics through regular mail.
This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for question threeof the Dietetic Survey on the temperature of the food.
This multiple contains the categories of the Specialized MedicalPrograms.
This multiple contains the categories of the Primary Delivery System.
This multiple contains the Locations of the Satellite Clinics andthe number of Outpatients that visited them.
This multiple contains the Cost Per Diem and Cost Per Meal.
This multiple contains the Dietetic Equipment available.
This multiple contains a list of Areas of Research under theUnfunded Nutrition Research.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for question oneof the Dietetic Survey on whether the food looked attractive, appetizing.
This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for question twoof the Dietetic Survey on whether the food tastes good.
This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for questionfour of the Dietetic Survey on the variety of foods served.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for question fiveof the Dietetic Survey on whether the dishes, cups, and utensilswere clean.

This multiple contains the number surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for questionsix of the Dietetic Survey on whether the Dietetic Service staffwere courteous.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for question sevenof the Dietetic Survey on whether there was adequate time to eat.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for question eightof the Dietetic Survey on the diet information given by thedietitian/dietetic technician.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regards to the fiveratings, Very Good, Good, Average, Fair, and Poor, for question nineof the Dietetic Survey on the overall quality of the food service.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the fiveratings, Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #1of the Dietetic Survey on whether the food looked appealing and appetizing.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the fiveratings, Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #2of the Dietetic Survey on whether the meals include preferred foods.
This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the fiveratings, Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #3of the Dietetic Survey on whether the food was hot enough.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the fiveratings, Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable forquestion #4 of the Dietetic Survey on whether items such as juice,milk and desserts were cold enough.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the five ratings,Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #5 of theDietetic Survey on whether NF&S employees were polite.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the five ratings,Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #6 of theDietetic Survey on whether patient's food likes and dislikes are discussed.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the five ratings,Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #7 of theDietetic Survey on whether meals are served about the same time each day.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the fiveratings, Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #8of the Dietetic Survey on whether the patient had enough time to eat.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the five ratings,Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #9 of theDietetic Survey on whether the patient received nutritional information or an individual diet plan.

This multiple contains the numbers surveyed in regard to the five ratings,Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair and Unacceptable for question #10 of theDietetic Survey on the overall quality of the N&FS.
This file contains the categories, Specialized Medical Programs,Primary Delivery System, Primary Production System, and theDietetic Service Equipment.

This file contains all items served as supplemental feedings.When appropriate, it may include combinations such as ice creamwith spoon. Items designed for bulk delivery to the wards arealso contained in this file.
This field allows for a number of synonyms for the supplementalfeeding to be entered.

This file contains a pattern of supplemental feedings (up to fouritems for each of three time periods) which are often requestedin common situations (e.g., a diabetic patient) and avoids thenecessity of individually selecting the various items whenordering supplemental feedings.
This file contains the products commonly used for tube-feedingsas well as their characteristics such as Kcals/ml, cost, andsynonyms.
This multiple contains alternate names or synonyms for theproduct. These names should include any names commonly knownor used by ward/medical personnel.
This is a list of the common standing orders (often called add-onsor specials) which may be ordered for a patient. It may includesuch things as 'double portions' or preferences such as 'no fish.'
This file contains entries relating to required reviews foreach dietitian response for a ward or group of wards. It canalso be used to record personal or non-patient relatedentries.
This field contains a free-text description of the item requiring action.
This file consists of a list of units used by the ingredient fileto indicate the dietetic issue unit.

This file contains the list of isolation/precaution types, ascommonly identified by medical personnel, and indicates thecharacteristics of those types important to the DieteticService such as type of china and appropriate tray deliveryperson.
This file contains the list of types of dietetic consultationsperformed as well as 'time-units' necessary to complete suchconsultations for workload purposes.

This file is a list of wards in the hospital and associated room-bedsand contains various dietetic specific information suchas the assigned clinician, bulk nourishments for the ward, andwhich Service Point, Communication Office, and Supplemental FeedingSite is assigned responsibility for the ward.This file will also be used to store outpatient locations necessaryfor the outpatient meals enhancement.
This multiple represents bulk nourishments (supplemental feedings)delivered to this ward.
This is a pointer to File 405.4 and indicates that that room-bedis to be considered part of this Dietetic Ward.
This is a list of MAS wards which are to be used as defaults to thisDietetic ward for purposes of patient location when the room-bed isunknown and for purposes of forecasting.
This multiple contains the hospital location(s)/clinic(s) associated withthis outpatient nutrition location.
This file is a list of Production Facilities and associatedparameters. A Production Facility is generally a main kitchen wherebulk food is prepared for use by Service Points.
This file is a list of Service Points and associated parameters.A Service Point is a tray assembly line or cafeteria where bulkfood from a Production Facility is served.
This multiple represents the number of additional meals, overand above the forecast or inpatient census, which are to beproduced for each meal for each day of the week.
This multiple contains the percentage of the total censusrepresented by each production diet for each day of theweek.
This field contains the date for which various census forecast datais available.
This file is a list of Communication Offices and associated parameters.A Communication Office has responsibility for processing diet ordersfor a group of wards.
This file contains a list of Supplemental Feeding Sites and associatedparameters. A Supplemental Feeding Site prepares orders for a group of wards for which it is responsible.

This file contains entries for all patient movements, diet changes,tubefeeding orders, additional orders, food preferences, standingorders, and patient isolation orders requiring action by theDietetic Service.

This file contains an extensive set of site parameters designed toindicate characteristics of the Nutrition and Food Service and/ordifferent methods by which the Service wishes the program to perform.
This multiple contains a list of laboratory tests whichare of interest to clinicians.
This is a list of printers using label stock.
This multiple contains drug classifications of interestto clinicians.
This file contains vital sign information and other measurement data for a patient.
A list of qualifiers associated with this measurement.
This multiple contains a list of reasons for entering a vital measurement in error.

Creatingand/or editing locally defined fields in the file are not permitted. This file contains information specific to the General Medical Record -Vitals/Measurements orders.
This file contains the various site configurable parameters for theVitals/Measurements application.
Contains patient allergy/adverse reaction information.
List of drug ingredients to which patient had reaction for thisallergy/adverse reaction.
List of VA drug classes to which patient had reaction for thisallergy/adverse reaction.
These are the reactions observed for this allergy/adverse reaction.
A list of those people who indicate that the patient's chart has beenmarked for this reactant.
