This file contains temporary information for the automationof Fee Basis Vendor and 5010 Providers to the IB NON/OTHERVA BILLING PROVIDER (#355.93) file.  The automation assists IB clerks in thecreation of bills to third party insurance companies for paid fee claims.

This file contains a list of claim adjustment reason codes.  These codesare used to indicate why the amount paid is different from the amountbilled on a health care claim.  The source of the codes is the NationalHealth Care Claim Payment/Committee Bulletins.  It is available fromWashington Publishing Company.  The associated suspend code, suspensiondescription, and applicability for use by VA on fee claims is provided bythe Fee Replacement Project Management Office in Denver which representsthe VA Chief Business Office. This file is exported with data and the contents should not be locallymodified.

This file contains a list of claim adjustment group codes.  The codes in this file are used to identify the general category of payment adjustment.The source of the codes is the National Electronic Data Interchange Transaction Set Implementation Guide for the Health Care Claim Payment Advice (ASC X12N 835).  It is available from Washington Publishing Company.  The applicability for use by VA on fee claims is provided by theFee Replacement Project Management Office in Denver which represents theVA Chief Business Office. This file is exported with data and the contents should not be locally modified.

This file contains a list of remittance remark codes.  The codes in thisfile represent non-financial information critical to understanding theadjudication of a health insurance claim. The source of the codes is theNational Standard Format Electronic Remittance Advice.  It is availablefrom Washington Publishing Company.  The applicability for use by VA onfee claims is provided by the Fee Replacement Project Management Office inDenver which represents the VA Chief Business Office. This file is exported with data and the contents should not be locally modified.

The file contains the present on admission (POA) indicator codes.  Thesecodes are defined by the Center for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) andshould not be locally modified.  The codes are used to indicate if a diagnosis was present on admission
This field contains a description of the code.

This file contains Intra-governmental Payment and Collection System (IPAC)vendor agreement data that is applicable to Fee Basis invoices.  Eachrecord in this file is for a specific vendor and fiscal year.  More thanone record can be entered for the same vendor. When Fee invoices are entered, if the vendor being paid has an active IPACvendor agreement on file the system will require the payment to be madevia the IPAC system. This Department of Treasury system is used totransfer funds between government agencies. Per VHA Directive 2004-038, this file definition should not be modified.

This file contains Master Record Adjustment entries for the Intra-Governmental Payment and Collection (IPAC) Vendor Agreements. When IPAC Vendor Agreement information is added, edited, or deleted, this updated information is sent to the Central Fee system in Austin so the Central Fee master record data can have the same updates applied. Per VHA Directive 2004-038, this file definition should not be modified.

This file holds reject codes that are applicable to payment line items.  This file will be exported with data.  The data must not be locallymodified. VistA Fee Basis has four logical files/sub-files that contain payment lineitems: 1. SERVICE PROVIDED (#162.03) multiple within the FEE BASIS PAYMENT    (#162) file. 2. TRAVEL PAYMENT DATE (#162.04) multiple within the FEE BASIS PAYMENT    (#162) file. 3. PRESCRIPTION NUMBER (#162.11) multiple within the FEE BASIS PHARMACY    INVOICE (#162.1) file. 4. FEE BASIS INVOICE (#162.5) file. Each of these four logical files has a free-text REJECT CODE field withina REJECT CODE multiple. The value stored in the REJECT CODE field is normally expected to have a matching record in the FEE BASIS PAYMENTREJECT CODE file so a description of the reject code can be displayed onappropriate outputs.  In the event the FEE BASIS PAYMENT REJECT CODE filedata is out-of-date and does not contain a code that is stored with apayment, a description similar to "Reject reason code not currentlydefined in list" will be used as the code description until the code is added to file #161.99 by a patch.
This field contains a description of the reject reason code.

Contains all Fee Outpatient medical payment data.  Include's paymentancillary data for Contract Hospital as of version 2. Does NOT include Pharmacy payment data. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This mutiple keeps track of all the vendors used by theFee Basis patient.
The date that the treatment or service was provided.
This multiple contains all the outpatient and ancillary servicesprovided the Fee Basis patient.

The REJECT CODE multiple is populated with one to four reject codes by theFBAA BATCH SERVER and FBAA REJECT SERVER server options when a line itemis rejected via the interface with Central Fee.  The REJECT CODE multipleis not used for local rejects.  The reason for a local reject is enteredinto the REJECT REASON (#20) field.
This multiple keeps track of any travel paid to a Fee Basispatient, in conjunction with an outpatient service.

The REJECT CODE multiple is populated with one to four reject codes by theFBAA BATCH SERVER and FBAA REJECT SERVER server options when a line itemis rejected via the interface with Central Fee.  The REJECT CODE multipleis not used for local rejects.  The reason for a local reject is enteredinto the REJECT REASON (#5) field.

This field is used only when the suspend code entered is '4' meaning 'Other'. This allows the entering of the reason that the payment amountwas not in full. This will be printed on the suspense letter.
Date that the purge routine was run which resulted in the purging ofpayment data for this patient.  This data will exist ONLY IF data waspurged for the patient for the specific purge run.
Contains Pharmacy invoices and payment data associated with hometownpharmacy payments. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This multiple allows the user to enter all prescriptions includedon a pharmacy invoice.

The REJECT CODE multiple is populated with one to four reject codes by theFBAA BATCH SERVER and FBAA REJECT SERVER server options when a line itemis rejected via the interface with Central Fee.  The REJECT CODE multipleis not used for local rejects.  The reason for a local reject is enteredinto the REJECT REASON (#18) field.
This field allows the entry of a description of why the amount claimed for a prescription is not the same asthe amount paid .
This file contains the information gathered when a site is notifiedthat a veteran has been admitted to a civil hospital. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
If the user enters a '4' for 'other' in the suspense fields/he can enter a word processing text for reason why.
The user audit tracks users that enter or edit the notification.
This file contains all bed movement activity associated with thecommunity nursing home program. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This file contains the information associated with a 7078authorization. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.

This is a word processing field that should contain a statementsimilar to the following: "Hospitalization and Professional care necessary until the  patients condition is stabilized or improved enough to permit  transfer without hazard to a VA or other Federal facility for  continued treatment." or "Hospitalization and Professional Care".
The user audit tracks users that enter or edit the authorization.  Thisincludes edits to the authorization rate or patient movements for nursinghome authorizations.
This file contains the payment data associated with the inpatienthospital programs of FEE Basis. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.

The REJECT CODE multiple is populated with one to four reject codes by theFBAA BATCH SERVER and FBAA REJECT SERVER server options when a line itemis rejected via the interface with Central Fee.  The REJECT CODE multipleis not used for local rejects.  The reason for a local reject is enteredinto the REJECT REASON (#14) field.
This field is only populated when there is a dollar amount that has beensuspended.  The user is prompted to enter a description of the suspensionin word-processing format.

This multiple stores Rendering Provider information that is specific to a line item on the claim. A record should only be added to this multiple if the Rendering Provider for a line item is different from the Rendering Provider at the claim level. Example, if the PROC1 code isentered and has a different Rendering Provider than the claim Rendering Provider (field #70) the multiple will store the different data. Line item #1 would be referencing PROC1; Line Item #5 would reference PROC5.
This file contains the disposition choices when moving a patientin the inpatient programs. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.

This file contains unauthorized claim information for active fee programs.Sites have the ability to either track only complete claims or incompleteclaims, depending upon the value in the site parameter field.A claim is considered complete once all information is received in order to make a determination (dispostion). Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
Special remarks regarding the initial disposition that should be includedon a disposition letter to the claimant. (Optional)
Special remarks regarding the disposition of an appeal that should beincluded on a disposition letter to the claimant. (Optional)
Special remarks regarding the disposition of a COVA appeal that should beincluded on a disposition letter to the claimant. (Optional)
Provides reason(s) why a claim was disapproved.
The description of the disposition.  Replaced by the REASON FOR DISAPPROVAL field.
The reason the claim was pending.  Replaced by the FEE BASIS UNAUTHORIZEDREQUESTED INFORMATION file (# 162.93).
The user audit tracks users that enter or edit the unauthorized claim.
The data audit multiple stores historical information for selected fields.

FileName: FEE BASIS UNAUTHORIZED CLAIMS PENDING INFO
Description: This file contains the information requested on an incomplete claim.  TheUnauthorized Claim can only move to the next status once all pending information for a claim is received.  Each item which is pending is enteredas a separate record into this file. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.

This file contains a listing of dispositions used in the UnauthorizedClaims sub-module.  The description of the disposition is used as textin the unauthorized claim disposition letter.            *** ENTRIES SHOULD NOT BE ADDED TO THIS FILE *** Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This field contains a detailed description of the disposition.This description is used in the letter which prints when a claimis dispositioned.

This field contains a detailed description of the disposition for claimsconsidered under Millennium Act 38 U.S.C. 1725. This description is usedin the letter which prints when that type of claim is dispositioned.

This optional field contains any additional text associated with thedisposition.  This text is used in the letter which prints when a claim isdispositioned.  If the disposition is a disapproval, this field will beprinted after the list of disapproval reasons.

Each unauthorized claim is assigned a status.  This file contains thepossible status' which an unauthorized claim may be assigned.  Associatedwith a status is the status order.  This is the order in which a claim may progress.  Also associated with each status is the number of daysbefore the claim expires, if applicable.               *** ENTRIES SHOULD NOT BE ADDED TO THIS FILE *** Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This field contains the detailed description of the status.

Data contained in this file pertains to information needed in order to process an unauthorized claim.  Sites have the ability to add local entries.The description of the requested information is printed as part of the textin the letter which is mailed to the submitter requesting the information. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This field contains a detailed description of the requested information.The description is printed as part of the text of the letter whenever information is requested.
If populated, the postscript is printed as part of the text of the letterwhenever the associated information is requested.  It is printed at theend of the letter after the signature.

This file contains various reasons why the claim was disapproved.  The description of the disapproval reason is entered as part of the textin the disposition letter which is mailed to the submitter of the claim. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.

This field contains a detailed description of the disapproval reason.The description may appear as part of the text in a letter when anunauthorized claim is dispositioned.  It will appear only if REASON FORDISAPPROVAL has data.

This file stores the check cancellation reasons and codes used by theFinancial Management System (FMS).  These reasons will be returned tothe site from FMS when a check is cancelled.  This file will be pointedto by all payment files. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.

This file contains by calendar year all relative value unitsassociated with a geographic area.  Geographic area is definedwith Zip Codes.  This is a table file that should not be alteredat the station unless instructed to do so.  The relative valuesare set by the Health Care Finance Administration. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This multiple will store by calendar year the GPCI associatedwith a ZIP Code Locality.

This file contains by calendar year all relative value units associatedwith a service rendered.  The Service rendered is defined with CPT Codes.This is a table file that should not be altered at the station unlessinstructed to do so.  The relative values are set by the Health CareFinance Administration.   Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
For each service rendered there are a set of relative valueunits by calendar year.  These RVUs are established byHealth Care Finance Administration.

These entries contain percentage value to pay for a service.After calculating the Medicare rate and the modifier is nota separate entry in the fee schedule, this table stores bycalendar year a percentage multiplier which will adjustthe payment amount accordingly. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.

This file contains, by calendar year, Major CPT Categories and theconversion factor (multiplier) assigned to each by the Health CareFinance Administration (HCFA). Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
For each Major CPT Category, HCFA assigns a multiplier by calendar year.

This file contains the list of VistA Fee Basis invoices that are pending transmission or have already been transmitted to the Fee PaymentProcessing System (FPPS) hosted at the Health Administration Center (HAC). VistA invoice data must be transmitted to FPPS for invoices that are associated with an electronically submitted health care claim.  FPPS canthen generate the electronic remittance advice to the vendor as requiredby HIPAA. Invoices are automatically added to this file when various trigger events occur such as receipt of a payment confirmation message.  The interface software uses this file to identify invoices that should be transmitted to FPPS and to maintain a record of transmissions and acknowledgements.

This file contains an audit log of changes made to a VistA Fee Basisinvoice after the invoice has been initially transmitted to the FeePayment Processing System (FPPS) located at the Health AdministrationCenter (HAC).  Such changes are made using special edit options thatautomatically populate this audit log file.

FileName: FEE BASIS VA TYPE OF SERVICE
Description: This file is controlled by the program office and will be used forhelping sites do cost analysis. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This field contains a detailed explanation of the VA Type of ServiceCode.

This file stores the default amount paid for outpatient medicalpayments. It is populated using the fee schedule option found onthe supervisor menu. Per VHA Directive 10-93-142, this file definition should not be modified.
This is a multiple field that will allow for the storageof historical costing data by fiscal year.

Complete ICDO-2 Topography from the 1990 International Classification ofDiseases for Oncology (2nd edition), World Health Organization. Containssite specific coding for Extent of Disease and AJCC Staging. This file comes with data, which overwrite the site's data.  It is notrecommended that sites modify this file.
MULTIPLE FIELD ALLOWING FOR RECORDING OF TYPE.
This multiple contains T codes from the fourth edition of the AJCC Manualon Staging of Cancer.
This field contains the Sixth Edition Primary Tumor (T) codes.  T codesrecord the extent of the primary tumor.
This field contains the full text of the Sixth Edition Primary Tumor(T) code definitions.
This field contains the Sixth Edition Regional Lymph Nodes (N) codes.  Ncodes record the absence or presence and extent of regional lymph nodemetastasis.
This field contains the full text of the Sixth Edition Regional LymphNodes (N) code definitions.
This field contains the Sixth Edition Distant Metastasis (M) codes.M codes record the absence or presence of distant metastasis.
This field contains the full text of the Sixth Edition DistantMetastasis (M) code definitions.
This field contains the Seventh Edition Primary Tumor (T) codes.  T codesrecord the extent of the primary tumor.
This field contains the full text of the Seventh Edition Primary Tumor(T) code definitions.
This field contains the Seventh Edition Regional Lymph Nodes (N) codes.N codes record the absence or presence and extent of regional lymph nodemetastasis.
This field contains the full text of the Seventh Edition Regional LymphNodes (N) code definitions.
This field contains the Seventh Edition Distant Metastasis (M) codes.M codes record the absence or presence of distant metastasis.
Contains the schema discriminator codes needed for CSv2 subsiteidentification.
Contains the schema discriminator code HELP text needed for CSv2 subsiteidentification.
This field contains the full text of the Seventh Edition DistantMetastasis (M) code definitions.
POINTS TO THE FILE CONTAINING THE SNOMED CODES FOR HISTO-MORPHOLOGY.
RECORDS THE TEXT GENERATED BY THE SNOMED CODES.
RECORDS THE T(UMOR) DESCRIPTION.
RECORDS THE LYMPH N(ODE) DESCRIPTION.
RECORDS THE STAGING GROUPING IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE AJCC MANUALFOR THE STAGING OF CANCER.
This is a corresponding ICDO-1 code.
The parent ICDO-2 Groups for the ICDO-2 Topography codes. Pointed to byfile 164; simple list of code groups and meaning.
This multiple contains the N-codes from the AJCC Manual on Staging ofCancer, 4th edition (1992).

ICDO-2 Morphology File (World Health Organization's InternationalClassification of Diseases - Oncology), containing all codes including /2's. This file comes with data, which overwrite the site's data.  It is notrecommended that sites modify this file.
FREE TEXT FIELD RECORDING TYPE OF CODE.
Number for internal code minus one.
This is the sequence number for display.

This file, pointed to by the ICDO-SITES File (#164.08), facilitates theproduction of the Annual Registry Summary Report. This file comes with data, which overwrite the site's data.  It is notrecommended that sites modify this file.
"Tumor Markers" record prognostic indicators for specific sites orhistologies.
FREE TEXT FIELD RECORDING THE TUMOR CLASS ENCODING SCHEME.
This file lists the physical conditions of patients prior to the beginningof initial treatment using Karnofsky's Rating.
Chemotherapeutic drugs as listed in SEER SELF-INSTRUCTIONAL MANUAL FORTUMOR REGISTRARS Book 8 - ANTINEOPLASTIC DRUGS Third Edition
Short Names, Synonyms and Brand or Trade Names

Contains major site-groups for the Oncology package. It contains ALL theACOS Site-Specific Surgery Codes. In addition, it also contains the SEERExtension and Lymph node coding - sharing that function with file 164. The "F" cross-reference of the TOPOGRAPHY Field (#.01) of the TOPOGRAPHY Multiple (#10) sets an index under ICDO-1 TOPOGRAPHY Field (#.02) of the TOPOGRAPHY Multiple (#10),and by the "AC" cross-reference of the TOPOGRAPHY Field (#.01)of the TOPOGRAPHY Multiple (#10) of the ICDO-1 SITE FOR ONCOLOGYFile (#169.2).
This field is a free-text KWIC cross-reference.
POINTS TO THE FILE CONTAINING TOPOGRAPHY CODES.
Morphologies associated with this SITE-GP.
This is the sequence number for display.
FREE TEXT FIELD FOR RECORDING ADDITIONAL GRADE INFORMATION.
This is the sequence number for display.
This is the sequence number for display.
This is a more complete, multi-line description.
Data file containing other methods of staging for particular sites.Data will overwrite data in field.
POINTS TO FILE CONTAINING SITE INFORMATION.
File contains the AJCC Staging Groups and the TNM coding schema.This is a very important data file and should not be modified.
FREE TEXT FIELD CONTAINING TUMOR CLASS ENCODING INFOMATION.
This field contains the Sixth Edition Distant Metastasis (M) codes.M codes record the absence or presence of distant metastasis.
This field contains the Seventh Edition Primary Tumor (T) codes.  T codes record the extent of the primary tumor.
This field contains the full text of the Seventh Edition Primary Tumor (T) code definitions.
This field contains the Seventh Edition Regional Lymph Nodes (N) codes.  N codes record the absence or presence and extent of regional lymph node metastasis.
This field contains the full text of the Seventh Edition Regional Lymph Nodes (N) code definitions.
FREE TEXT FIELD CONTAINING LYMPH NODE CLASS ENCODING INFORMATION.
This field contains the full text of the Seventh Edition Distant Metastasis (M) code definitions.
FREE TEXT FIELD FOR RECORDING STAGE GROUPING INFORMATION.
FREE TEXT FIELD CONTAINING METASTASIS CLASS ENCODING INFORMATION.
This multiple contains the M (distant metastasis) codes from the fourthedition of the AJCC Manual on Staging of Cancer.
This field contains the Seventh Edition Distant Metastasis (M) codes.  M codes record the absence or presence of distant metastasis.
Common cancers file containing list of common cancers (data file).
FREE TEXT CROSS REFERENCE.

This file contains a superset of the DAM Cancer Status Codes for usein identifying tumor status at follow-up on the ONCOLOGY PRIMARY File (#165.5).  The extended codes (4-7) help the registrar to record more completely the overall cancer status of an expired patient. This file comes with data, which overwrite the site's data.  It is notrecommended that sites modify this file. This file is referenced directly by routine ONCOCOFA.

This file contains codes used to record the grade of tumor in the GRADEField (#24) of the ONCOLOGY PRIMARY File (#165.5). This file comes with data, which overwrite the site's data.  It is notrecommended that sites modify this file.

This file contains transforms for converting AJCC stage data from internalto external format and vice versa. This file comes with data, which overwrite the site's data.  It is notrecommended that sites modify this file. This file is referenced directly by routine ONCOTNS.

This file contains codes used to record the patient's race in the RACEField (#8) of the ONCOLOGY PATIENT File (#160).  The codes are derivedfrom the ACOS Data Acquisition Manual. This file comes with data, which overwrite the site's data.  It is notrecommended that sites modify this file.

This file contains extension, lymph node, and surgery codes from the SEER Extent of Disease Codes and Coding Instructions.  Each set of codes can be linked to code sets from future editions. This file is referenced directly by routines ONCODEL (for extension and lymph node codes) and ONCODSR (for surgery codes). This file comes with data, which overwrite the site's data.  It is notadvised that sites modify this file.
Identifies additional information needed to generate stage, orprognostic factors that have an effect on stage or survival.
This multiple contains the codes and descriptions for this set.
The Commission requires staging of pediatric patients using AJCC or thestaging criteria of the pediatric intergroup studies and the pediatriccooperative groups.

This item may be used as a quality assurance monitor to evaluate theoverall pattern of care within a facility.  It is potentially usefulas a monitor of appropriateness and efficacy of treatment and inselecting patients for outcome reporting.In many cases, RADIATION TREATMENT VOLUME will be most appropriatelycoded by the radiation oncologist.

RADIATION COMPLETION STATUS is useful in evaluating treatment outcomesand the appropriateness of the initial decision to treat.This file indicates whether the patient's radiation therapy wascompleted as outlined in the initial treatment plan.  This informationis generally available only in the radiation treatment chart.
This file contains the WHO histological classification of tumor codes fortumors of the brain and central nervous system.
File for Oncology contacts. Populated by  the user, partly  automatically byFollow-up options, and by the user. Used only for patient follow-up.
Form letters for Oncology/Tumor Registry follow-up. These are linkedby type to the Contact file. Upon installation the option isgiven to preserve or delete the letters already in the system.
WORD PROCESSING FIELDS RECORDING THE MAIN BODY OF THE CONTACT FORMLETTERS.
This field allows the Tumore Registrar to define and describe eachletter. Also it allows for the description of letters exported.
SEER Geocodes.  These codes include states of the United States as well asforeign countries.
CROSS REFERENCE.

For a hospital registry, Class of Case divides cases into two groups.  Analytic cases (codes 00-22) are those that are required by CoC (Commission on Cancer) to be abstracted because of the program's primaryresponsibility in managing the cancer. Analytic cases are groupedaccording to the location of diagnosis and treatment. Treatment andoutcome reports may be limited to analytic cases. Nonanalytic cases (codes 30-49 and 99) may be abstracted by the facilityto meet central registry requirements or because of a request by thefacility's cancer program.
Tumor-related data for Oncology patients is stored in this file.(Demographic and follow-up data is in the Oncology Patient File).File is populated in the field by using the abstracting options.
Enter subsequent therapy (therapy provided after completion ofthe first course of therapy).
Free text field.
Text area for information from history and physical examinations.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Free text field.
Text area for information from laboratory examinations other than cytologyand histopatholgy.
This is a multi-line free text field permitting comments to be entered.
Record the type of radiation therapy.
This is a multi-line free text field permitting comments.
Free text field.
Enter the QA FINDINGS of the QA review.  Please limit your findings to 3lines of text.
This file contains whole file conversion flags.Currently the only flag available is for the ROADS to FORDS conversion.
This multiple records information on subsequent recurrences of the tumor.
This multiple is populated by the Post/Edit Follow-Up optionof the Follow-Up Menu.  It contains the date of each follow-upfor this patient, and the tumor status at each follow-up.

Tied to Primary file (Dinumed to .01 field), containing computed fields only.This can be used by IRM to add computed fields to the file for use in thestatistical options for cross-tabulation routines.
This file is intended to assist the registrar in coding the sourcethat first identified the tumor.
This file contains a list of managing physician specialties.The file is used for the Patient Care Evaluation Study ofCancers of the Urinary Bladder form.

REGIONAL TREATMENT MODALITY is intended to identify the dominant modalityof therapy delivered to the primary volume of interest.  In some cases,it may be appropriate to choose a code for its academic or economicinterest, even though it may not reflect the majority of the patient'stherapy.  For example, a patient with carcinoma of the nasopharynx mayreceive original treatment using a linear accelerator and then have aboost with High-Dose-Rate (HDR) brachytherapy.  In a department with aspecial interest in brachytherapy, the code 15 would be chosen.This field can be useful in assessing resource utilization, planning forexpansion, or monitoring quality.  It should be used at the discretion ofthe Radiation Oncologist.
This file supports the 1996 Patient Care Evaluation of Soft Tissue Sarcoma.

Identifies systemic therapeutic procedures administered as partof the first course of treatment at this and all other facilities.If none of these procedures were administered, then this itemrecords the reason they were not performed.  These include bonemarrow transplants, stem cell harvests, surgical and/or radiationendocrine therapy.For further information see FORDS pages 182-183.
This file is intended to assist the registrar in coding the source of documents used to abstract the cancer being reported.
This file is used to identify the type of multiple tumors that are abstracted as a single primary.
This file contains the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology,Third Edition (ICD-O-3) morphology codes and code descriptions.
This field contains the synonyms and equivalent terms for thismorphology.

The simple file allows for the storage of the status of the packageunder control of the programmer: version installed, beginning andending of the installation, with the generation of a mail-messageto the installer, and supporting ISC the installation information.
*Unknown at this time*
The SP cross-reference created as follows:    The values of [xxx] were taken from the following sources:  1. FSNs 2. Synonyms

The purpose of this file is twofold:----------------------------------- 1. The hold the data for all Medication Instruction file entries from   the legacy system.  (Data is held in fields# ,01,2, and 3.) 2. To hold the problem entries (those entries which would expand   incorrectly on the primary system) and their proper, new conversion   value.  (See field descriptions for additional information.)

Contains all outpatient RX data used by the outpatient pharmacy package.As the above indicates, this is the hub of the outpatient system.  It willeasily be the largest pharmacy file in time and is pointed to very heavily.Deletion of an entry in this file must be handled VERY carefully and is notallowed if refills have been issued. Of particular interest is that essentially all the history pertaining to aparticular Rx is contained in each Rx entry.

Anyone present in this multiple is considered "turned off"; no profilesshould be displayed, and not Prescription transfers can take place. Note!!  The entries in this file are always on the basis of the DFNof the entry in the Primary system file.
File used to track site-specific NDBI activity.
File used to track the consolidation projects.  Each entry in this filewill usually be the hyphenated names of each site involved in consoli-dation.  (Eg., BATAVIA-BUFFALO.)
This is a parameter file for CPRS response time monitoring.  It keeps all necessary information to make web pages with the response times graphed on them.

This is the CPRS Monitor data file which stores information necessary to make graphical data for the monitor web pages of the facilities.  It is also used to send data to the National Response Time Monitor web site.
This is the name of the patch as it comes in the mail message.

This file holds the site parameters for this installation of FoundationsManagement and VistALink. It will have only one entry (DINUM=1) and the .01 field points to aDOMAIN that represents the name of the installation site.

This multiple field contains the VistALink Listener configurations for BOX-VOLUME entries in the DOMAIN NAME's scope. Each configuration is used by the XOBV LISTENER STARTUP menu option. Thisoption is typically scheduled to run as part of the system startup afterthe VistA system has been restarted. The option will start up VistALinkListeners for the BOX-VOLUME where Task Manager is running. Note: This only applies to Cache NT systems. VMS/DSM systems need to use the TCP/IP (UCX) utility to have Listeners automatically startedon reboot.

The entries in this file contain the connection related and proxy classinformation of remote web services. This information is required in order for the HealtheVet Web ServicesClient (HWSC) application to call remote web services.

This file holds VistALink Listener configurations.  A configuration may contain multiple Listener ports, and each Listener port may be configured to start upon system startup.  Note: This only applies to Cache NT systems.  VMS/DSM systems need to use the TCP/IP (UCX) utility to haveListeners automatically started on reboot. This file is pointed to by the Foundations Site Parameters file (#18.01)and is used when obtaining the default Listener configuration for a specified BOX-VOLUME pair.

This multiple field contains Listener port information associated with a specific VistALink configuration entry. Each Listener port entry holds the port number to be used by the VistALinkListener along with an indicator which will specify whether the Listenershould be automatically tasked to start on system startup.

This file contains informational status pertaining to the current state ofVistALink Listeners for each BOX-VOLUME pair.   Note: This file only applies to Cache NT systems and is not utilized forVAX/DSM systems. Those systems must use the TCP/IP (UCX) utility to startand stop VistALink listeners. This log file is initially populated when one or more VistALink Listenersare started.  This will occur when either the Start VistaLink ListenerConfiguration option [XOBV LISTENER STARTUP] is invoked, or by using theaction protocols found under the Foundations Management Menu option[XOBU SITE SETUP MENU] to either start the BOX-VOLUME defaultconfiguration or start a single VistALink Listener. When a Listener is stopped, the log file is edited with an updatedstatus.  Non-active Listeners are deleted from the log file when the CleanUp Log action protocol is invoked.  As mentioned, this action protocol aswell as the action protocols previously described above can be found underthe Foundations Management Menu option [XOBU SITE SETUP MENU].

This file contains the message type definitions used by the VistALink request manager. Each message type is associated with a request handler. The request manager uses TCP/IP input stream information to lookup entriesby 'message type' or 'proprietary format indicator'.  Once an entry hasbeen found, the request manager can execute the correct request handlermethods for the incoming request stream. Information contained in the entries of this file allow the requestmanager to dynamically determine which request handler to load andexecute.
This file contains the web server(s) and associated informationrequired for HealtheVet Web Service Client (HWSC) to communicate with theserver using SOAP and REST web services over HTTP.
This multiple contains the list of web services that the web serveris authorized to contact in order to a issue request.

This file contains lookup key names that are mapped to WEB SERVER fileentries. These key-to-server mappings allow application developers to codeusing key names and call the appropriate HWSC API at run-time toresolve the server using the key name as input to the API. There is also a deployment time API that can be use to registered the keyname during the installation of application.

Information in this file is used to drive the menu system.  Options arecreated, associated with others on menus, locked, set out-of-order,assigned prohibited times or devices, or given entry/exit actions.  TheEdit Options of Menu Management should be used (instead of VA FileMan)so that the global root (DIC) and other such fields are given the correctvalues.  Options may be tailored by setting FileMan variables via this file. The Order Enter/Results Reporting package is accessed by using the appropriateoption type.  It is cross-referenced by name, menu text, uppercase menu text,type, item, synonym, help frame, out-of-order message, lock, prohibited times,restricted devices, and priority.
This field points to the descendent options of this menu.
Sort FROM criteria associated with the subscripts defined by the BY(0)input variable.
Sort TO criteria associated with the subscripts defined by the BY(0) inputvariable.
This field contains a brief explanation of the particular option.It will be displayed in the menu system to the user when '???'are entered to the selection choice of the parent menu.

The Kernel Site Parameters File establishes when and how a log of optionusage will be recorded in this file.  For the indicated time period, allspecified options, namespaces, and users will be audited.  Each time anaudit is put into effect, it is recommended that the number of auditedentities be at a minimum so that disk space is not inadvertently wasted.This file is cross-referenced by option.

This file holds the names of security keys that are used to lock options.To lock an option, the name of the key is entered in the Lock field ofthe Option File.  To permit a user to unlock the option, the user's nameis entered in the Holder field of this file.  It is cross-referenced byname and holder.
This is a short description of the security key, indicating what thekey locks out, and what class of users should be assigned the key.
Subordinate authorization are "given" when the "master" authorizationis given.  This allows easier and more efficient delegationof authorizations.

This file hold records that relate to the scheduling of optionsto run on a one time basis or more likely on a schedule.There is one record for each time that an option is scheduled.This allows one option to be scheduled to run on more that oneCPU or at more that one time without having to duplicated the optionin the option file.
This multipule holds name-value pairs that are setup before the optionis run.
This subfile may contain dasy and time during which this option may not beenvoked.  This subfile replaces field 3.9, Prohibited Times, in the 0th nodeof the Option File.

By entering days and times in the subfile the option's outputcan be restricted to days and times not included in this file.The Menu System passes a flag to the Device Handler causing itto force queuing during the days and times included in thisfile.
This subfile may contain a list of devices upon which this option is permittedto run.
This file holds help text to be displayed in the screenman edit form for the menu file.  It will only change when there are changes to the Menu system.
This allows free text comments for expanding the ability of the systemto describe the history of the missing record episode.
This allow the user who found the record to describe with free text theepisode in which the missing record was found.

It will allow asite to make a Claim Tracking Type Active or Inactive if needed. Entries will only be made to this file with the approval of the VISN20 MCCR coordinator.

Will be used by the Mental Health Department to track Chronic Mentally Ill patients and their appts.

This file contains VistA patch information which is stored by a server option when a patch arrives to G.PATCHES at a site.  The server extracts certain information and stores it here. A night-time program will then check the file, match it against the install file.  If the current date is past the allowed date for patch installation (typically 30 days for regular patches, three days for emergency patches) it will do one of two things:         1.  If the patch has been installed since last run, it will delete the entry from this file, regardless of the number of days.         2.  If the patch has NOT been installed, its information will be saved and reported via a mail message to mail group AXV Patch Monitor. The person(s) who are in charge of monitoring patches at the site will be responsible for following up on delinquent patches.

FileName: AXVVA VISUAL AID FOR CLINIC APPOINTMENTS
Description: This file is a database file that keeps the clinic template informationfor the option AXVVA VISUAL AID CLIN APPS. To create, edit or delete a clinic template, activate the template editorby double-clicking on the "Clinic Template" label on the GUI panel. Astart time, stop time and the type (e.g. "ret" for return patients) areusually recorded. The DUZ of the current user will also be recorded if anew template is created or an existing template is modified. Another field of this file is dedicated to keeping track of the defaultclinic for a certain user. If "Set as default" button is pressed, theselected clinic becomes the default clinic for the user. The next timethis option is used, the default clinic appears in the clinic box.

The Clinical Rule file describes all the rules follows by the Clinical Event Monitor. Each rule describes a clinical condition that might ariseand what the monitor should do about it when it does. This file is used mainly by the Clinical Event Processor option [AXVM CLINICAL EVENT PROCESSOR], which runs as a persistent task. AXVM protocolsrun whenever the events we're monitoring occur. These protocols send HL7messages to the processor describing each event. The processor loads eachmessage and runs it through the rules in this file, each of which teststhe event and takes action if it meets that rule's criteria. The rules are implemented in a partially table-driven manner in whicheasy-and-efficient-to-represent rule data is put in this file, and anything trickier is hard-coded into routines, one per rule, that describethe rule and use the data from this file to properly test for and respondto the conditions in question. An option is also created for each rulethat involves lists the users need to manage. Although this file couldhave been designed to represent all parts of the rules so that specialroutines were not needed, the sheer number of message processed per daymakes efficiency important, so we compromised. Rick Marshall created the Clinical Rule file at Puget Sound VAHCS on June 13, 2002 for Clinical Event Monitor version 2.0.

Rick Marshall created this file at Puget Sound VAHCS on May 6, 2002 to replace the six AXVM Parameters. He doesn't like the efficiency of theXPAR Parameters tool, especially the fact that you can't attachcross-referencing actions to individual parameters the way you can toparameter fields in regular FileMan files like this one. During theconversion of the Clinical Event Monitor to MUMPS, he was able to retireenough of the parameters that even just having the two remainingparameters together on one node was a big improvement.

This file is a new dental activity file.  It is not meant to replace theofficial DAS at this time.  Data stored in this file will be differentfrom that in the DAS file (221).  This file will have a break down byindividual teeth and procedures that were used to create the record.These file entries will be created by the Document Storage Systems (DSS)Dental-GUI application.  The purpose of that application is to allow thecreation of records in this file.  But at the same time, it will createPCE workload entries and will also create a record in the Dental ActivitySystem (DAS) file (221).  This has the following advantages:  1. The DSS-GUI has one user interface for inputting data 2. The need for the dental card reader should be eliminatedA.  The cardreader should be kept for backup purposes 3. The dentist and assistants won't need to go into VistA PCE options torecord their workload 4. The dentists can do their Progress Note in the DSS-GUI which willdownload it to the VistA TIU package.

This file contains all the MHS Treatment Plans for all patients.  Within this file, there are several multiple fields that contain Patient and Professional responses to specific Mental Heath Suite questions.This file drives the MHS appliation and acts as a repository for all events specific to a treatment plan and patient.

This file contains all the MHS disciplines that may be selected and used in a Treatment Plan.  There is only one Discipline associated with each Plan.  A Discipline is the top node of a hierarchal structure and represents the parent side of a parent-child relationship.  Each Discipline has at least one or many child Categories.

This file contains all the MHS Categories that may be selected and used in a Treatment Plan.  Each Category points to at least one Discipline.  A Category represents the child side of a parent-child relationship where the parent is the Discipline.    A Category may have zero or more child Goals associated with it.

This file contains all the MHS Problems that may be selected and used in a Treatment Plan.  Each Problem points to at least one Category.  A Problem represents the child side of a parent-child relationship where the parent is the Category.  A Problem may have zero or more children.  Problems may have "Objective" type children and/or "Goal" type children or any combination thereof.

This file contains all the MHS Goals that may be selected and used in a Treatment Plan.  Each Goal points to at least one Problem.  A Goal represents the child side of a parent-child relationship where the parent is the Problem.  A Goal has no children.

This file contains all the MHS Interventions that may be selected and used in a Treatment Plan.  Each Intervention points to at least one Objective.  An Intervention represents the child side of a parent-child relationship where the parent is the Objective.    An Intervention has no children.

This file contains all the MHS Objectives that may be selected and used in a Treatment Plan.  Each Objective points to at least one Problem.  An Objective represents the child side of a parent-child relationship where the parent is the Problem.  An Objective may have zero or more child Interventions associated with it.

Both the sender and receiver must already exist in NEW PERSON file (#200).
This field is being used to store the Diagnoses and Specifiers associated with a specific treatment plan.

This file contains a repository of all Treatment Plan Records that have been purged.  A Health Care professional must already exist in the NEW PERSON file (#200) and must hold the DSIU PURGE RECORDS security Key in order to delete a Treatment Plan.

This file stores patient centric data that is associated with a patient and not with a specific treatment plan.  For example WHODAS is a score that is given to a patient and is not specific to an individual treatment plan.  The latest WHODAS scores are visible within a range of patient treatment plans.

This file contains the computed data for FOIA reports along with offsets to the calculations and a locking mechanism to prevent changes after the FOIA report has been run. The fields on the zero node ofthis file identify which anual FOIA reportis stored in the record and the status of the lock for this report.   The remaining fields which end in the word REPORT are the values calculated during the FOIA extract process.  The fields which end with the word MANUAL are the values from the offset screen in ROI which are then added to their associated REPORT fields to create the final FOIA numbers for the FOIA report.

This file contains the Status History of an ROI instance.  It is the way to track the historical processing of a request.  The following are the accepted statuses and dispositions:   STATUS  'O' FOR OPEN  'C-G' FOR CLOSED GRANTED  'C-P' FOR CLOSED PARTIAL  'C-PR' FOR CLOSED/PENDING PAYMENT RELEASED  'C-D' FOR CLOSED DENIED   'P' FOR PENDING  'P-C' FOR PENDING CLARIFICATION  'P-P' FOR PENDING PAYMENT (OBSOLETED IN V 7.1)  'P-H' FOR PENDING PAYMENT HELD   'N-NR' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE NO RECORDS  'N-RF' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE REFERRAL  'N-ND' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE NOT DESCRIBED  'N-NV' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE NOT VA RECORD  'N-RC' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE OTHER (OBSOLETED IN V 7.1)  'N-NF' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE FEE RELATED  'N-NU' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE DUPLICATE REQUEST  'N-NP' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE NOT PROPER FOIA  'N-MS' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE MEDICALLY SENSITIVE  'N-PD' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE PATIENT DIED BEFORE COMPLETION  'N-PA' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE  'N-G' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE GLOMAR  'N-SL' FOR OTHER NONDISCLOSURE SUBSUMED BY LITIGATION    'A-RV' FOR APPEALED REVERSED  'A-PR' FOR APPEALED PARTIAL REVERSED   'X' FOR CANCELLED  'E' FOR ERROR  'A' FOR APPEALED

This file contains audit information for ICB. When Buffer entries(#355.33) are created, audit file entries are created to capture fieldsfor reporting. When Buffer entries are processed only a stub record isleft so the audit file allows reporting/auditing for a longer,site-defined period of time.  Audit entries are purged manually by the site.

The Group Plan comments that were saved in the application.  This data is not saved in the Buffer (#355.33), so the data is moved from the audit file to the Group Insurance Plan (#355.3) during the Accept Buffer process as part of the ICB enhancement.

The Plan Filing Time Frame (.13), Electronic Plan Type (.15), Plan Standard FTF (.16) and Plan Standard Value (.17) fields from the GroupInsurance Plan file (#355.3) that were saved in the ICB application.  Thisdata is not saved in the Buffer (#355.33), so the data is moved from theaudit file to the Group Insurance Plan (#355.3) during the Accept Bufferprocess as part of the ICB enhancement.

The Policy Not Billable (#3.04) field from the Insurance Type multiple (#2.312) of the patient file is saved from the ICB application.  This data is not saved in the buffer so it is moved from the audit file to theinsurance type multiple (#2.312) during the Accept Buffer process as part of the ICB enhancement.
You may enter unlimited free text comments about this insurance company.  It may be helpful to date ongoing comments and identify the source of the comments.

This file contains ICB report data that is compiled by a background job.  It currently only contains Exception Report data from the DSIV NIGHTLY REPORT option, but it could also contain Audit Report data compiled from file 19625 in the future. The Exception Report is a listing of patient appointments that were not acted on (placed in the buffer if needed) in a timely manner.  Since itlooks through all appointments for the day and processes clerk actions itcan take more than a few minutes to run if all clinics are run at a site(there are inclusion/exclusion parameter lists).  The nightly job shouldbe scheduled during off peak hours and after the scheduling job haschanged the appointment status of appointments that were not checkedin-out for the day (automatic process).
A multiple containing the report data that was compiled in the background process.
This file contains clinics to be excluded from the ICB Exception Report.

This the parameters file for the Rx-Framework product and is used to determine which HL7 messages are transmitted between Vista and a vendor.

The entries in this multiple will be used to filter whether or notto send outpatient registrations to the Rx-Frameworks Interface. The .01fields will be used to match against outpatient locationsand if there is a match, the "OUTPATIENT MAPPING" field will be sent.Each location that is to send outpatient information should be enteredinto this multiple to ensure correct location information.Even if all locations are to send data, it is still appropriate foreach location to be entered.  The OUTPATIENT MAPPING will be used first.  If there is nomatch, DEFAULT OUTPATIENT MAPPING (field 8) will be used.  If thatis also blank, the orignal value of PV1.3 will be sent.
This field defines the Vendor to whom data for this interface will be sent.

This file contains a tracked list of HL7 messages that are created by the RX-Framework product.

The parameters file contains all the logic to control the HL7 feeds that are needed by the site.  Vendor post installs require this file to be populated before those vendor post installs can be run.

This file contain parameters for working with HLO in taking and placing values into the HL7 structure and performing any transformations that may be necessary. It holds element positions, data type, data type transforms, tables, mapping tables, executable code for tables, and the designatioin of local variables to be used in parsing and/or build the HL7 messages.
The HL7 segment being defined.
This field defines the type of COTS product that will interface withVista.

This file collects data from HL7 messages generated by the DSIH DataBridge package.  There are references to files 772 and 773 to track messages by date/time, patient or message type.  This file is purged when the entries are older than the site parameter purge date.  This value is usually set to 90 days.

DataBridge supplies an outbound message for each event type.  Normally a vendor subscribes on the DataBridge server protocol for the event desired and the vendor protocol can transmit a copy of the message to an additional server. If the message is to be screened, and only a portion of these messages sent, the vendor can use this file to place executable code before the message is generated and define the HLL array used with a dynamic link. This file is NOT intended as a method to change the message stream.  To do that, a router protocol must be added to the DataBridge event server.

File 19672 is used to track specific API's that are run as part of the DataBridge GUI.  Once these specified API's are run, the RPC 'DSIHH DATABRIDGE API TRACKER' is used to populate the file with date/time and user information for the API and menu used.

File 19672.1 is a supporting pointer file for file 19672.  The Vista menu options that are to be tracked by file 19672 are entered in this file.  The file entries are never deleted, but may be disabled if tracking is no longer desired for an entry.

File 19672.2 is a supporting pointer file for file 19672.  The Vista Gateway methods that are to be tracked by file 19672 are entered in this file.  The file entries are never deleted, but may be disabled if tracking is no longer desired for an entry.

This file tracks the Taskman jobs that run to support the Data Analytics portion of Data Bridge.  Each monthly run of data creates an entry in the file with the Task job number stored.  In addition the task number is stored in each record created in file 19675.1.  In this manner it is possible to retrieve all of the file records associated with the original queued report.
This file contains all of the parameters required to control theextraction of data for Data Link
This file contains the log of entries extracted.
This file contains the list of patients included in the extraction process.

The Link Monitor saves date/time events when the DSIH logical links are not functioning.  Each tracked logical link has a separate record and a history multiple to allow review of the link over time.
This file is used to screen outbound messages for origination from valid Locations/Stop codes.

This file is the main report repository for the DSIY package. All Above PAR reporting tasks use this file to schedule reports to be run throughtask manager, monitor reporting status and collecting resulting reportdata. The file contains scheduling information, status information, taskinformation, report parameters, and resulting data.
This holds the parameters for controlling the report.

FileName: DSIY WORK ORDER XREF FOR ENGINEERS
Description: XREF from the be found in the

File to store additional data for Work Orders.  Currently storing the IEN to the Equipment Category Field and the IEN to the NEW PERSON file as these are both free text fields in the current Work Order system
Data file to hold additional information about each piece of equipment from the Equipment Inventory file
Stores additional information at the Master Item level for Inventory
Global used to store the Cross References to the Work Action codes - both the EBERS and APAR category codes will be stored.  The Node of the file will be the Work Action IEN from file
File to hold information about Primary Inventory Point Groups.  Each Primary Inventory Point should be assigned to one group.
This file contains the Inventory Distribution Points that are recognized by DSIY Above PAR as dealing with Prosthetics.
This file stores data to be shown in the Above PAR dasboards.
Definition of available data sets to use in Above PAR.
DSIY ADHOC REPORTS Saved information for Ad-Hoc Reports
This global keeps a list of files available for ad-hoc reporting via the APAR Ad-Hoc Report Writer
Temporary file set up to hold all itemsitems to run through a bulk-edit process.
Above PAR Audit File. Used to track changes made by users in the Above PAR application.
List of changes that were made to the file.
This file is to be used with the ENOSUS IE product sold byDaou-Sentient.
This subfile contains pointers and tracking information on themail messages containing the data extracts for PCG.

This file contains the names of users of the 3M coder interfaceand the IP address of their work stations.  This file should be usedwhen static IP addresses are needed to be defined.  Only users entered in this file and with the key VEPE3M willhave access to the option VEPE3M LOAD/EDIT PTF DATA.
This file is the translator from the VA dispositions to the 3M Coder disposition list.
Namespace changed by Ebonsoft Systems, Inc. Nov 2006originally ENOSUS developed by Daou-Sentient.
This subfile contains pointers and tracking information on themail messages containing the data extracts for HMS.

The PATIENT file contains all the patients followed by the medical center/Outpatient clinic.  At a minimum each patient entry must have a NAME, DATEOF BIRTH and SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBER.  In order to add a new patient to thePATIENT file the user must also indicate whether or not the patient isrequesting to receive care as a VETERAN of the U.S. Armed Forces andspecify the TYPE of patient being added to the system.  For the mostpart the information contained in this file is demographic in nature,i.e., address, employment, service history, etc., however dataconcerning admissions, appointments,etc., is also stored in this file.The ADMISSION sub-field is scheduled to be moved into the new PATIENTMOVEMENT file by the end of calendar year 1989.  Care should be usedwhen removing a patient from the PATIENT file since virtually allother DHCP modules do utilize data from this file.  Of the many fieldsin the file you will note that many are preceeded by an asterisk.Those fields are scheduled to be removed from the file due to eitherlack of use or replacement by another field/file in the next release.
This multiple field contains the data relating to clinic enrollments forthis patient.

If this applicant is known by any name other than that entered inthe NAME field enter that/those other name(s) here.  Any entryto this field will be cross-referenced and the applicant may becalled up using this alias.

This multiple contains the pertinant data relating to this patientsenrollment in this clinic.  Data contained in this multiple includesthe date the patient was enrolled, the date of discharge from the clinicand whether the patient was seen on an outpatient or ambulatory care basis.
This multiple contains all eligibilities under which this patient canreceive care.  This includes his primary eligibility and all othereligibilities he may have.

From the available listing choose and enter conditions for which theapplicant has been verified as being service connected.  Only users whohold the designated security key may enter/edit this field.
Enter conditions as stated by applicant for which s/he claims serviceconnection [1-30 characters].

This multiple contains all of patient responses to questions about My HealtheVet registration and actions taken by the clerk to acquaint the patient with My HealtheVet (MHV).  Once a patients registration in My HealtheVet is confirmed by setting the MHV Registered (#537027), the MHVAUTHENTICATED (#537028), and MHV SECURE MESSAGING (#537029) fields to to 1(YES) and/or 0 (NO), no additional actions or responses will be filedhere.
The MHV MSG ACTIONS multiple captures the actions taken by the registration clerk to assist a patient opting to use secure messaging with their My HealtheVet account.
The MHV AUTH ACTIONS multiple contains the actions taken by the registration clerk to upgrade/authenticate the patient's My HealtheVet registration.
This multiple contains a multiple of fiscal years containing informationregarding the vesting status of a patient.
These are the dates/times the preferred language information was givenby the patient and recorded in the Patient File.
Maintains the history of all of the full Integration Control Numbers(ICNs) assigned to patients.

The date/time at which this applicant applied for medical benefits, e.g.,was registered for care using the 'Registration' option of ADT. This multiple contains information on each registration entered for thispatient including the date of registration, date of disposition, and typeof disposition.

For this veteran applicant who either incurred a dental injury(DENTAL INJURY IN SERVICE prompt must be answered YES) or hadteeth extracted (TEETH EXTRACTED IN SERVICE prompt must be answeredYES) while serving in the U.S. Armed Forces enter the date of dentaltreatment received.  Once the service record is verified only userswho hold the designated security key may enter/edit this field.

This multiple is not presently used by the MAS module.  Archivingcapabilities for the patient file are not yet available. This multiple was distributed in 1987, but the archiving routines werenot distributed.
This multiple contains data pertaining to each specific archive (thedate, the beginning and ending archiving dates, and the tape numbers).
This is a multiple valued field containing the confidential addresscategories for this applicant.
This is a word processing field to contain information on the patient'sineligibility or information about this missing patient.
This multiple contains all the information related to the current Health Benefit Plan(s) for the patient.
This multiple contains the history of the Health Benefit Plans that are assigned or unassigned to a patient.
From the available listing enter the type of insurance under which thisapplicant is covered regardless of who holds the policy.
To supply information related to the delivery of health care.
Subscriber/Dependent additional identification data.

This contains the information relating to the deployment of thepatient to a conflict location for the operations Iraqi and EnduringFreedom (OIF, OEF respectively).  It also includes records of conflictthat can be identified as being EITHER OIF OR OEF, but the specificlocation cannot be determined.

This contains the definitive military service episode history for the patient and is updated from the Health Eligibility Center (HEC) system.  HEC is the authoritative source for this data and it may not be edited inVistA except to add new episodes.
This multiple contains all of the eligibility and benefit datafor a specific insured person returned from the Payer.
This field contains any additional text about the eligibilitybenefit information.  It is transcribed from X.12 271 MSG segments.
This multiple contains contact information for an eligibility/benefitentity.
Healthcare services delivery multiple.
Subscriber dates multiple.
Additional subscriber information multiple.
Subscriber reference id multiple.
Entries in this sub-file identify the characteristics of a provider.

This sub-file (#2.342 COMMENT - SUBSCRIBER POLICY) will contain theSubscriber's Policy Comments, the Date and Time the Subscriber's PolicyComments was entered, and the User's ID that entered the Subscriber'sPolicy comments.
This field contains one or more Descriptors, which provide the Catastrophic Disability Reasons the patient has been found to be catastrophically disabled.
This multiple field contains the responses to the Socialization Actionquestion asked to the patient about my HealtheVet registration.

This field is filled in by Seattle's Appointment Archive Routinewhich takes appointments previous to a specified date and moves themto a separate global.  It marks the number of archived appointmentsin this node.

This multiple contains information on appointments this patient has had oris scheduled to have.  This information includes the date/time of theappointment, the clinic, and the reason for the appointment.

This file, introduced with Name Standardization (Patch XU*8.0*134), holdsthe component parts of a person's name as follows:   Family (Last) Name (field #1)  Given (First) Name (field #2)  Middle Name (field #3)   Prefix (field #4)  Suffix (field #5)  Degree (field #6) The "source name" that has these components is identified by the followingthree fields:                                                        File (field #.01)  Field (field #.02)  IENS (field #.03) The "ANAME" cross-reference on the Family (Last) Name, Given (First) Name,Middle Name, and Suffix fields keeps each component in synchronizationwith the corresponding source name. In the case of Patch XU*8.0*134, thesource name is the .01 field (the Name field) of the NEW PERSON file(#200). The Degree and Prefix fields are not considered part of a standard name,but can be used to build formatted names for display.

This file contains data on employees, users, practitioners, etc.who were previously in Files 3,6,16 and others. DHCP packages must check with the KERNEL developers to see thata given number/namespace is clear for them to use. Field numbers 53-59.9 reserved for Pharm. Nodes and X-ref 'PS*'.Field numbers 70-79.9 reserved for Radiology Nodes and X-ref 'RA*'.Field numbers 720-725 reserved for DSSM Nodes and X-ref 'EC*' and 'AEC*'.Field numbers 740-749.9 reserved for QA Nodes and X-ref 'QA*'.Field numbers 654-654.9 reserved for Social work Node 654 and X-ref 'SW*'.Field numbers 500-500.9 reserved for mailman Node 500 and X-ref 'XM*' and 'AXM*'.Field numbers 740-749.9 reserved for QA Nodes and X-ref 'QA*'.Field numbers 910-910.9 reserved for Police Package Node and X-ref 'ESP'
This is the begining of a network address.  Enter the Lastname of the useror an identifier that he is known as on the receiving system.
This field stores the exception spelling dictionary for the user.
This field is used to store predefined format lines which a user canselect from during editing.
This field stores predefined phrases which can be inserted into the document during editing.
The phrase to be inserted into the document.

FileName: LM LIMIT WP FIELDS TO EDIT
Description: This field is used by the user to limit which word processingfields should be edited by LetterMan.
This is the set of UCI's that this user must choose from at sign-ontime.
This is the one or more divisions that this user may sign-on and dowork for.
Options awarded a user not on his or her primary menu option

This multiple-valued field contains the list of files the user may access.The type of access granted to the user is included for each file thatappears on the list.  The user may be allowed to look at records (READaccess), edit existing records (WRITE access), add new record (LAYGOaccess), delete records (DELETE access), or modify the file structure(DATA DICTIONARY ACCESS).
This is the provider's personal list of preferred diagnoses codes.
Other names used by this new person.
These are "keys" that define the characteristic(s), authorization(s), orprivilege(s) of the person.
This subfile contains pointers to the Key File of those keys thatthis person is allowed to allocate to other users.

This subfile stores the information that travels along with visitors usingthe CPRS Foreign Views software to look at medical data of a patient whichresides on a system where the visitor may not have valid access or verifycodes.  When that person name and Social Security Number is put into thevisited system's New Person File this multiple is updated to provide theability to trace the visitors back to the system from which they arevisiting.  This field (.01) stores the number of the site where thevisitor was authenticated.
This multiple field contains information about the classification assignedto Rad/Nuc Med personnel.  Possible classifications are Technologist,Interpreting Resident, Interpreting Staff, and Clerk.
This field will allow the user to access all data specific to a particularRadiology/Nuclear Medicine location.

The Account History subfile (200.091/New Person field 9.1) records the history of changes to each New Person file entry, to help those managing each user's account coordinate their activities. As audited events occur, the Kernel adds entries to this subfile and, whenever the events are interactive, prompts the user to explain why changes were made. The Kernel also shows the account history prior to allowing each change. Once subfile entries are created, they cannot be changed. Events currently audited include: 1. Setting or clearing the Disuser field (7); and 2. Setting or clearing the Termination Date field (9.2).
This is a sub-file of pointers to the Option File which detail thoseoptions this user may delegate to others.
This is a multiple field which is used to generate alerts to the users.The data for alerts is filed by date and time.
This subfile holds the set of namespaces available to this user inthe creation of menus with delegated options.
This multiple holds sets of predefined menus which can be envoked bythe user by entering a right-square-bracket ("[") followed by atemplate's name.
This multiple contains the information on the option sequence specifiedfor a given MENU TEMPLATE.
This multiple contains credentialing information about a providerthat is used by the state.
This mutiple contains the DEA# issued by a state in order to allowproviders to write medication orders for controlled medications.
This multiple field contains the DMMS units to which this person hasaccess for entering data and generating reports.
This file contains the screen characteristics of the screens to bedisplayed.
This file contains the screen used to enter new/modify entries intoa user screen.

It is distributed withoutdata.  Objects handled by the VistA Imaging System currently include singleimages (various resolutions), series of images, scanned documents, motionvideo, waveforms, and audio files.  There is a record in file 2005 foreach object, containing the attributes of the object. All fields areautomatically stuffed by the Imaging software - there is no user input.Objects handled by the VISTA Imaging System currently include:   * Single images (various resolutions)  * Series of images  * Scanned documents  * Waveforms   * Motion video  * Audio files  Each object has a natural language Name (.01); this usuallyconsists of the patient's name, ssn, and object description. Depending on the object type, the object will either have:   * A filename and logical location on the network (e.g., single image, graphics).  * A multiple field called Object Group, containing entries, whichpoint back to the Image file (e.g., image series or tiledabstract display).
This file is where Study level data associated with storedimages can be managed, e.g., Key Images.

The informationincludes the detail about each annotation, e.g.: annotator, date/timesaved, tool version, source and XML data...etc.
These fields store user annotations to the image.
This field contains the annotation XML raw data.

This table contains audit information regarding the export locationsof file copies generated by the generic carbon copy (GCC)utility.  This utility is used by the Health Eligibility Centerfunctionality.
This field keeps track of any routing activity.

This word processing field allows the user to describe the image atlength.  The user may only choose to append this long description onselected images - those which are "classic" or "unusual" cases. It can beused to summarize a group of images which have been put together for aconference or consult.  It will be used in the future to a greater extent,as options for image capture (independent of VistA packages) are provided.

It is exported with data. All sites must have entriesfor the data types distributed in order to display objects sent viamultimedia mail. The Object Type file handles objects of various types.  These include:   * still images   * image groups  * graphics or waveforms  * scanned documents  * audio files    Other types are expected in the future (i.e., image overlays,motion video chips, and office automation files).  An object,such as an image series, may actually consist of multipleobjects.  In this case, the object type is Group.  The ObjectGroup multiple field is used to point to a set of objects in theImage file.  Each object type has associated methods (softwareroutines) for performing certain actions.  For example, there aremethods for displaying images and image abstracts.  The grouptype is used to combine multiple objects of the same or differenttypes to create complex objects.  There are different image types, for example:   * black and white high-resolution x-rays  * black and white ultrasound images (lower resolution)  * pseudo-color nuclear medicine scans  * medium resolution true color bronchoscopy images  * pathology images  Each type of object has a number of specific characteristics,including the methods  required to display them.  For example,each object type has a type name and an associated display methodor window.  All accesses to objects use the file finder routine points of this routine will find locations of full files,abstract files, and jukebox copies of files.  In addition, thenetwork write location will be returned for image captures.
This node contains the list of "Key" images, so designated by theInterpreting Radiologist when performing an interpretation with Vistarad.

As such, it may not be changed in any way. | | Modifications to this software may result in an adulterated   | | medical device under 21CFR820, the use of which is considered | | to be a violation of US Federal Statutes.                     | |                                                               | +---------------------------------------------------------------+ The Imaging File (2005) has many "imaging multiples" pointing to it fromother packages such as Radiology, Medicine, Surgery, Mailman and thevarious sub-files of Laboratory such as Surgical Pathology etc.  In orderto have a method of tracing back from the Image file to the parent filemultiple, a file was developed to aid in this process, along with someadditional fields in the Image file. Using these fields along with thePARENT DATA FILE, backward navigation is possible whether it be to amultiple of a file, or a multiple of a sub-file of a file. Each image thatis captured is associated with a procedure or test report.  Depending onthe service collecting the image, different types of reports will beassociated.  For example:   * Medical Procedures:  Endoscopy, Dermatology, Hematology, Rheumatology, etc.  * Anatomic Pathology:  Surgical Pathology, Cytology, Autopsy, Electron Microscopy  * Radiology:  Xray, CT, MRI, Ultrasound  * Surgery  Operation reports  * Text Integration Utility  Progress notes  In order to be able to display information from the associatedreport, references to that report are stored in the Image file. One of these references is a pointer to the Parent Report file(2005.03), which contains an entry for each package's report filethat is currently supported.
This node contains a list of images that were referenced duringthe Exam Interpretation either by annotations, or by designationas KEY images.

The object group is a multiple field pointing back to the Image file(2005).  Only objects with an object type of GROUP have the Object Groupfield defined.  These objects can be thought of as the "parent" of a setof images.   Generally, instead of having their own abstract, objects of the GROUP typeuse the abstract of the first entry in their object group multiple.  Sometimes, text will be used in place of the GROUP abstract for speed.  Methods for viewing a GROUP object generally allow viewing of all themembers of the group, either selectively or altogether.  A good examplewould be a set of thirty CT scan images.  Using the Integrated View menuoption, the tiled display of image abstracts would contain only oneabstract for the group.  Selecting the group object for viewing providesthe user with a tiled display of the abstracts of the individual CT scanimages.  The user can then identify individual images for full resolutionviewing.
Image Presentation state data stored below; this is free-text in XML format.Annotations are included in this data.
Contains a list of images saved for user-specific purposes,e.g., teaching file usage.
This multiple stores previous values of the record fields (audit trail).  See the "AUDIT2", "AUDIT40", and "AUDIT100"cross-references for more details.
