This file contains the design for the output format for the cummulativereport and the supervisor's reports.  The formats may be done with teststop to bottom, or left to right; and dates in forward or reverse chronology.
The major or general heading of the report.The first four letters of the major header name is used as an indexflag at the bottom of each page.
The minor, or sub, headings.Mixing formats within a major header is not allowed and onlyone vertical format per major header.
This report is built from the cumulative.  It is queued automatically through the OPTION file and TASK MANAGER.
This is a multiple field containing the headers for the summary reports.
This is an arbitrary report name.
An entry to a separate report location

This file is used to define whether or not your site will be generatinginterim reports of patient lab values and to what locations these reportswill be sent or routed.  Interim reports are defined as hard copy print-outs of a patient's test results which are generated between the timesthat the permanent chart copy (cumulative) is printed and made available.The entries in the fields of this file also let you determine whether ornot to generate these interim reports automatically upon verificationof the results in the lab, and specify the device (printer) for any ofthe reports to print on at a given location.  NOTE:  In order to haveANY location receive automatically generated interims, you must fill inthe field 'Queue verified test(s) notice' in the LABORATORY SITE file(#69.9) with 'YES'.

This file stores temporary pages of the cumulative report. The data in this file is maintained by the cumulative routines.  Because patient care can be effected if the cumulative report has incomplete lab results, you should not edit this file or data containedwithin it.  Contact your ISC for technical support if problems arise. Cross-reference descriptions:
These are the major or general headings of the report.
These are test(s) not defined under a major header.

This file is used primarily as a National Laboratory Test (NLT) databaseupgrade source file. When new/additional NLT codes are released to thefield, they are exported in this file. The installation software takes theentries from the LAB NLT/CPT CODES (#64.81) and adds them to the WKLD CODE(#64) file, then deletes that installed code from this file. If theinstallation is successful, this file will be empty.  NORMALLY, THIS FILE HAS NO DATA EXCEPT DURING INITIAL STAGES OF DATABASEUPGRADE. The end user never uses this file for day to day laboratory activities.
This is an entry transported from the Workload Code file (64).
This file contains the fields that are audited in LAB. Fields listed in this file will show up on various audit reports and extracts within the LAB software.
These are the field numbers to be audited in the associated file.

The Master Name Index File is the center of all VAPD Files.  All otherfiles are triggering information into this file within the respectivefields.  In addition, as information is entered into other files, then thecorresponding information from Master Name Index in automatically displayedin that field.  For a more detailed explanation of the file, refer to VAPD HELP FILE.

This file is used to maintain a historical record of VA Police OfficersONLY.  By maintaining restricted access to the file or various fieldswithin the file, it can be used as an in-house personnel file.

This file is designed to provide a more detailed explanation of each fieldor file so that entry information is consistant.  Normally, the help-promptprovided is sufficient to assist the person entering data.  However, thereare more complicated entries, such as NAME and ADDRESS, that require abetter understanding of the way in which entries should be made.

Provides mechanism for documenting the mandated validation of the BloodBank software options.  Data entry in the file is NOT intended to replace the mandated documentation of the validation testing, including:(1) observations from testing, e.g. screen prints, logging files, printed reports, written transcriptions, data tapes, data disks, etc.,(2) a record/log of unusual occurrences, bugs, deviations from theBB User Manual & resoltuion, or (3) final approval by other responsibleindividuals, including the BB Medical Director and the LIM.  It MAYbe used to replace the documentation of the review, the acceptability/outcome of the review, the date/signature of approval and the dateof implementation.   This file offers longitudinal tracking of validation of the softwareto include the release of new versions, the installation of patches andthe installation of any local modifications. The content and the formatting of the file is consistent with theworksheets provided in the Blood Bank User Manual and the TechnicalManual and complies with the requirements of the the AmericanAssociation of Blood Bank and the Food and Drug Administration.

This file is used to hold pointers to the patient 2319 file (660).Each time a stock item is issued to a veteran the following files will beupdated... 660    - Create record of Prosthetic Appliance/Repair (patient's 2319) 661.6  - Create Prosthetic Inventory Transaction record 661.4  - reduce stock on-hand quantity and value by issued amounts for         HCPC item, vendor, location and unit of measure. 661.63 - record pointers to the 660 and 661.6 file records just created. 661.7  - reduce stock quantity and value by issued quantity and value.         If the new stock quantity for the stock date and location is         0 then delete the record.

This file implements the concept of 'First In First Out' (FIFO) stockaccounting. Whenever stock items are brought into stock on a given date an entry willbe created for that date for the relevant HCPC item, location, vendor andunit of measure. The date will include time to cater for the rare instancewhere the same stock item with the same vendor, location and unit ofmeasure is brought into stock on the same day but with a different cost. This file can then be used to look up locations containing the oldeststock for any given HCPC item. When items are removed from stock the associated vendor and location willbe identified by scanning a bar code (or manual entry in case of equipmentproblems). The system will then assume that the oldest item for the vendorand location has been issued and will reduce the stock quantity. If thequantity becomes 0 or -ve the record will be deleted.
This file is not being used at present.  It will be used for barcodeimplementation.

This file holds the running balance of an inventory for every HCPCS andHCPCS ITEM for a particular station.  All transactions created usingthe Stock Issue options and Prosthetics Inventory Program (PIP) will havean entry in this file in chronological order indexed by Station, HCPCS anddate.

The "Bingo Board" application is designed to list orders from inside and outside CPRS. It is currently being expanded to also allow applications like a Pharmacy BB display, and for remote display where a medical center provides night/off hours service to other MCs. It is expected that it can be expanded and/or utilized in its original form for any application locally decided.The original was designed essentially to display non-verified nursing orders and is a hard addressed printer-assignment throught the M -> VMS device system. It now also contains a broker-based application (from Portland) and a web-based application (from Murfreesboro).  We are expecting to pack all these into one package for interested sites.

Description: Programming Tasks file tied to TASKS.EXE Delphi utility.The intent of this project is to allow a programmer to: A.  Pick up a list of his/her tasks from Class III file 663990    [PROGRAMMER TASKS]    These task may coincide with an IRM Workorder, but need not do so. B.  Be able to add a new task to the file along with the following    information       1) Task Name (up to 50 characters)       2) Task ID (up to 10 characters]            a) May be IRM WorkOrder # if desired, but at this time                there field is FREE TEXT and is not associated with                a pointer to that, or any other, file.            b) Suggest each programmer us a common numbering scheme                so his/her TASK ID numbers will be recognizable              (eg. ARKCxxxxx)       3) Date Task Assigned / Begun       4) Enter a complete task description in the provided word processing          field.  This description is entered at the TASK DESCRIPTION TAB          and may be edited and re-saved at any time. C.  With a single click of a task in the task list be able to     1)  Display all the information in B above     2)  Also display all previous notes on this task in date/time-of-entry         order.   D.  With single click of the Session Open/Close button be able to open a    new session for a given task.     1) You cannot open a new session if one is active (can only work on        one task at a time).  This is set up so that actual working time        on any task can be calculated.     2) Opening a session will set the date/time toggle for this session     3) Opening the session begins a new Note headed with the Date/Time        Stamp.  No note text need be added - in which case the note will        contain only the beginning and ending timestamp of the session.  E.  Upcomming options to be added     A.  Sort tasks by         TASK ID         TASK SHORT DESCRIPTION         within those categories         ALL         COMPLETED         OPEN         NOIS'd     B.  Be able to push a button to see times spent by task for the day     C.  Display total time spent on any task to date     D.  Print all data on a Task to a file     E.  Purge a task (?? automatically print to file before purging??)     F.  Print a task to a file

;INTRODUCTION TO D.H.C.P.    Welcome to (D)ecentralized (H)ospital (C)omputer (P)rograms !!     DHCP consists of 6000 options, is written in the programming language 'M'. There are roughly 40 packages, or collections of programs specific to various services, such as Lab, Pharmacy, MAS, Surgery, Fiscal, and others. Each service has a computer coordinator, also known as a SAC, or Service Application Coordinator. You receive your access/verify codes from the SAC, as well as your menu options.     You MUST NOT share your access codes!! Someone else, using your menu, could enter erroneous data and endanger patient care. You can get whatever menu option you need from your Service Application Coordinator, See the Index for a phone list of the SAC's.  ;LOCAL> AND 'TIED' TERMINALS   There are two different ways to get into DHCP, depending on what appears on your screen when you press the <RET> key a few times.   If the text which appears ends with the words ACCESS CODE: you must type in your access code and press <RET>. (Your code will not appear on the screen.) When the screen prompts VERIFY CODE: enter your verify code, <RET> and the system will ask you to select from your main menu. It will also notify you of any new mail messages you may have.    You get 4 chances to enter your codes, after which the terminal will not allow further unsuccessful tries. It will reset in a few minutes.    If the prompt LOCAL> appears, this means you must call into the computer. Enter C DHCP and hit <RET> twice. The prompt for access and verify codewill appear, and you may sign in as usual. If you have been designated as a user in the test system, enter C TEST and press <RET> , then enter "TEST" at  the USERNAME: prompt You should then  get the access/verify code prompts. The test system is a 'dummy' system used for testing new software and for training, and does not contain real (live) patient information.  ;?,??,??? FOR MENU HELP   After you sign in , you are asked to "select (your Primary menu) Option:" If the entire menu has not already printed, enter '?' to see the options. You may also enter '0' (zero) at this point to see your secondary menu options, and pick one of them by number. There is some help text available for most options.   If you enter a single '?', you will get a list of options, and if you enter '??', you will get your menu options, their program names, and a listing of additional options which you can reach from any sub-menu .    Some of these options are MAIL, Time, Edit User Characteristics (so you can change your verify code and other personal data), the library menu, the Phone Directory, etc., and you can select your secondary menu items, if any have been assigned to you.   If you enter '???' you will get a brief description of what the option does.  ;THE '    The ' out of the system, or get options from other menus. You enter this symbol by holding the SHIFT key and pressing the number 6, then release both and <RET>. We call this the 'up-arrow'. Entering it in response to a request for input of data will take  you to the beginning of a new record in the file in which you're working, such as the patient file,the purchase order file, etc. In addition to using the up-arrow to 'back out' of a data input option, you can add it to an option name to jump into another menu option without the need for a lot of <RET>. For instance, if you are in the Lab Accessioning menu and want to get a result, enter  directly to the Results menu report option.   You can exit the system by pressing <RET> enough times until the system halts, or you can just enter 'HALT' at any menu prompt. You MUST halt from the system when you leave your terminal, or another person can use your menu and create security violations, alter patient data, send Mail messages under your name. REMEMBER TO LOG OUT when you leave the terminal!  ;THE '//' CONVENTION (DEFAULT ANSWERS)    When the computer prompts you to enter some data into  particular field, it may offer you an answer, followed by two slashes, as 'Read MAIL BASKET: IN//' or 'Select Patient Name: RINGO,JOHNNY//'.  The // means that what is in front of the two slashes will be entered by default when you <RET>, If the default is correct, just <RET> and you will move to the next field. If the default is incorrect, type in the correct answer and <RET>. The correct info will be stored for that field, and will appear as the default next time. REMEMBER-- if you see // after a data field entry, you enter the default by pressing <RET>.    When the information in a particular field is lengthy, as with a free- text field consisting of several lines of text, you may be invited to edit that information. The cue is the prompt 'EDIT Option:'. The next section is a primer in the use of the DHCP editor. ;THE EDIT OPTION    You may select either a line editor or a full screen editor. Do this by entering "TB" at any main menu prompt to get into your ToolBox, and answer the prompt "PREFERRED EDITOR" with the letter 'S' and you will then be able to use the screen editor, which is much more powerful than the line editor. Hit the F1 (or PF1) key and then hit 'H' for help with the screen editor. Type F1 and then 'E' to exit the screen editor.  ;EDITING, CONTINUED     The line editor is very literal--when you are replacing something, you must type the incorrect part exactly as it appears. There are shortcuts! You may have a paragraph with a number of instances where the date 1990 exists, and you want to change all the 1990's to 1992. At the EDIT Option: prompt you would enter a 'C' (for Change Every) and you could replace every incorrect number with a different number. This would be quicker and easier than using the 'Replace' function. Instead of typing in the entire phrase 'than a fish without a bicycle' you would enter 'than...cycle' to replace the entire phrase. You can even replace many lines at a time this way.  But if the system displays the text followed by'//', you will have to type all the new text. This will not happen if there are more than a couple words of text.    You can delete a line or a range of lines, move lines around (like the "cut and paste" editor), add lines to the end of the text, insert a line after a line number, and so forth. Use '???' at the 'EDIT Option:' prompt to see a listing of edit commands, or switch to the screen editor.  ;DATA FIELDS    When you enter data into the system, the data is placed into FIELDS, of which there are 7 types. They are: DATE/TIME, NUMERIC, SET OF CODES, FREE TEXT, WORD PROCESSING, COMPUTED, POINTER TO A FILE. Sometimes you need to know the rules for a particular field type. Entering '?' will usually give you enough information about the field to tell you what kind of data the system expects you to enter. Getting a 'beep' and two '??' means you are either entering the wrong kind of data, or something is missing.    DATE/TIME: You can enter the date in many ways, and a '?' will show you the acceptable ways. It is handy to enter a 'T' for today, 'T-1' or 'Y' for yesterday, or 'T+3W' for 3 weeks from today. 'N' will translate to 'NOW', and the system will fill in the date and time. You could also enter 'T+6M' for a date 6 moths hence.   FREE TEXT: Numbers, letters, puctuation are all acceptable--you can enter any characters on the keyboard, up to a certain number, usually from 3 to 30. Sometimes the data entered must match a certain pattern, such as SSN, or P.O. numbers in the IFCAP menu. If you enter something which does not match that pattern, you will hear a 'beep' from the keyboard, and get '??' from the screen. Enter '???' to see what the computer wants.  ;CORRECTING MISTAKES    You will sometimes make errors when typing in data. To correct them before you have hit a <RET>, you may 'back up' using the DELETE key, which is just above the <RET> key on VT320

ARLEM Event Type stores each of the events the Event Monitor responds to. The purpose of the Event Monitor is to capture clinically significantevents by inserting conditional protocols into the right protocol chainsconnected to clinical activities we're interested in. For each event, wefire via TCP/IP a copy of the HL7 message describing that event to anexternal Event Monitor running on a separate computer. To test the Event Monitor, we have created the Event Simulator, whichresponds to changes in this file. The event Simulator runs as a backgroundtask that monitors clinical events in the past and fires thecorresponding Event Monitor protocols as though the event had occurred inthe present. The Event Simulator uses the contents of this file to buildits list of events to monitor and to fire the corresponding events. Although at present only the Event Simulator directly uses this file, webelieve other parts of the Event Monitor may soon do so as well. Note that the contents of this file are used together with the ARLEMparameters in the Parameters file (# 8989.5) to guide the simulation. ARLEM Event Type was created by Rick Marshall at VA PSHCS on March 24,1999 in collaboration with Jim Savarino for Event Monitor version 0.1. Weconsidered using the Protocol file (# 101) instead of creating a new file,but decided file 101's purpose (as much as could be gleaned from thescanty Description) is orthogonal to ours, and many of the required fieldsof that file would seem to bear that out.

CONTENTS: MH Patient stores a list of all patients seen by the MentalHealth service. This list is generated automatically when entries are madeto the Outpatient Encounter (409.68) or Patient Movement (405) fileslinking patients who are not in the MH Patient file to Ward Locations orStop Codes associated with Mental Health. NEW ENTRIES: Users should never need to manually add entries to this file,but may do so whenever they are sure a patient who has been treated by theMental Health service is nevertheless not in this file. The file wasoriginally populated to include all patients seen by Mental Health sinceOctober 1, 1998. FIELDS: The file itself is mainly a pointer file, DINUMed to the Patientfile (IENs match), with computed fields that return the value of commonlyneeded fields in the Patient file. SELECTING ENTRIES: Although the Record field (.01) will usually be used topick entries, it is a pointer and therefore does not make it easy to sortby name. SORTING ENTRIES: Use the Name field (.02) to sort by name instead of theRecord field (.01); this field has a copy of the Name field (.01) of thePatient file (2), and is set automatically when the Record field is firstset or changed to point to a new patient. If the Name field of the Patientfile entry later changes, someone must also manually change the Name fieldof this file to keep it the same. This design limitation can be fixed infuture versions of PSHCS Mental Health if it is too much of a problem. SECURITY: The Mental Health ADPACs need read, write, delete, and LAYGOaccess to this file. Key Mental Health users need read access. The IRMPackage Manager should continue to develop the file and add options asrequested by the ADPAC to help encapsulate the details of the file'sstructure. ** TECHNICAL INFORMATION ** ORIGINS: This file belongs to the Class III package PSHCS Mental Healthversion 1.0, developed by Rick Marshall at VA PSHCS August 2-4, 1999 incollaboration with Melissa Hughes. ORIGINAL ENTRIES: Its contents were populated by running the ARJTYSroutine, which scans the Patient Movement (405) and Outpatient Encounter(409.68) files for patients who have been to Ward Locations with theMental Health service or Stop Codes in the 500 series. See the routine'scomments for details. NEW ENTRIES: It will be kept populated by MUMPS cross-references (to benamed later) on files 405 and 409.68.

Prosthetic Suspense file used to contain information regarding pending Prosthetic requests and orders.  This file contains both Manual and CPRS Orders.  When a suspense is added to Prosthetics the status is OPEN.  Once an initial action is taken on the suspense record, the status changes from OPEN to PENDING.  The status remains PENDING when additional action is taken on a suspense record.  The status is changed to CLOSED when the process is complete and either service was performed or an item was given to the patient. There are two main types of suspense items, MANUAL and CPRS via ConsultTracking.
This is the date an Other Action Note was created.

This file contains entries which represent the functional subdivisionsor departments of the laboratory, referred to by the Laboratory packagesoftware as accession areas.  The file is used to define the site-specificinformation needed by your laboratory for each accession area.  This includes the type of accession transform (or how often the accession numbers assigned to test performed in that area will be reset to 1), theabbreviation of the area (which becomes part of the accession identifyingthe specimen and test results), the order in which the data for testsperformed in the area will be displayed and other specific information. Definitions of variables used: LRDFN = Internal entry in LR( that is being worked on. LRIDT = Inverse date/time that data is stored at.  LRAA = internal value of accession area  LRAD = date working on in accession area  LRAN = accession number working on  LRODT = order date  LRSN = order entry within date CROSS REFERENCE DESCRIPTION:      used by the cumulative      used by micro verify by supervisor     used by micro for cumulative report     used for WKLD count
The date of the accession.
The numeric part of the accession.
The pointers to the Laboratory Tests for this accession.
The site/specimen from the Topography Field file.  There may be morethan one specimen for certain types of accessions.
Progress notes on the accession.
Data is stored here for use in Bull's algorithm.
Data from the running average of Bull's algorithm is stored here.
Select the instrument (if appropriate, otherwise use the MANUAL selection)to be associated with the controls you will be selecting.
The control that should always be placed with the accession number to bedefined with the ACC # field .001
Quality control comparisons based on Westergard's suggested use ofthe Multi-rule Shewhart determinations are stored under this multiple.
Data from the Multi-rule Shewhart determinations are stored here forintermediate computations.
This field contains the test ordered for this patient/specimen
This sub file is devoted entirely to workload functions. The datais stuffed automatically by routines at the time of verification of thetest.
DEFINES THE LOAD/WORK LIST TO BE MADE FROM THE ACCESSION LISTThe  BUILD
All data in this multiple field is computer generated.
Where the data is stored in the LAH global.

This field let the tech select the test/panel number to be sent to theMicroScan. The number entered is from the table I or the MicroScan documentation.To be easier to use this this should be come a pointer to a file that containsthe code to send.

Only ONE load or work list can exist at a time.  But more than one profilecan be defined to make "alternate" groupings of tests for the load/worklistwhich might be used on an infrequent or non-standard basis.
These are the tests to be brought onto the load/work list from theaccessions.
Enter the tray number appropriate for the controls you will next bechoosing.  If this is a worklist or sequence loadlist, the "tray" isalways "1".

Identify the control appropriate for this "tray".  If you need tospecify more than one of the "same" control, use quotation marks aroundthe control name and the FileMan will allow you to add as many as you like.
If any specimens are specified here, accessions of these specimen(s)will NOT be included on the work/load list.
This multiple has the controls that are to be placed on the worklistat the beginning of the list.
This multiple has the controls that are to be blaced on the worklistat the end of the list.
To used for any additional WKLD codes used for this particular W/L.

This file allows the lab to customize the short accession list.  It willallow up to a 10-line heading of the accession.  This heading area may beseparated in a maximum of 4 columns.  Each column allows an entry that maybe used to define the supervisor of an accession area, or put in a spaceto allow the technologist to designate which shift, etc.
Contains a line number for the special heading.

This file contains the list of titles at the local VA library.Information that is title specific and unique to the local VAlibrary is here.  Some information here is holdings information,purchasing information, what is the subject for this title andwhether this title is being received or just that back issues are available in the library.
This is the category of the serial.
Enter notes concerning the renewal of a subscription in this field.
This field contains a set of codes to allow the indicationof which union list authorities are recipients of theholdings of a particular library.  Found in HOL option.
This is the subject of the serial.

This is a word-processing field where missing and/orsought issues and/or volumes may be listed.  There isa gaps report which prints this field; this report canbe used to acquire items from surplus lists.  Found inHOL option.
This is a word-processing option field which allowsthe input of long, issue-specific holdings statements.Found in HOL option.
Each serial may have a binding date.
This is a multiple field to list all the volume numbers sent in a binding order.
This is a nationally controlled file.  This file contains a list ofpublishers for all titles in the TITLE AUTHORITY FILE.  Addressesand phone numbers of the publisher are in this file also.
This is a word-processing field to allow input aboutmiscellaneous notes concerning the binding process.
This field should contain your SEE references, See Also references, titlechanges--whatever you want printed under your title (besides holdings)when you run a printed holdings list.
This field is a word-processing field to allow specificnotes concerning the check-in of a title to be entered.
This is a nationally controlled file.  This file contains the namefor how many times per year/month/week a title is issued alongwith a synonym for the name.
This is a list of locally created subjects.  These subjects are usedto indicate what type of articals are in a journal.
This file containes names and services for all donors, requestorsand routing recipients.

This is a nationally controlled file containing information for eachjournal title in any VA library.  Some items in each record are the correcttitle, the publisher, what this title had for the title previous to thisand what this title changed its name to after this name.publication, and editing information.
How is the serial indexed ?

This word-processing field allows for notes to be enteredconcerning the bibliographic history of this serials title,including former names, names it is continued by, alternativenames it may be known by, changes in publishing history, etc.

This file containes information about the library using theLocal Serials Module.  The name for the library, whetherautomatic printing is desired and the computer address forthe printer in the library used to print routing slips orreports are some of the entries in this file.
This file is a list of places where journals the library receivesare to be located.
This is a nationally controlled file.  This file contains a listof abstracting and indexing sources along with the common shortform for the index.
This is a nationally controlled file.  This file containsinformation used to predict what the journal date, volumeand issue will be for the issue for the title about to bechecked-in.
This is a word-processing field to fully describe thepattern established with the fields in this file inplain English.

This file contains all the copy specific information for anylocally received title.  Some items found here are what titlethe copy refers to, what copy number or Table of Contents thisis, who the vendor is and who the list of recipients are if thiscopy is routed.
This is the list of recipients who might have a copy or Tableof Contents routed to them after check-in.
This file on FORUM contains the full name and abbreviation ofvarious countries where serials are published.  It is pointedto by the Title Authority file (680.5).

All the information about each journal date for any local titleis in this file.  Such things as the journal date, volume, issueand the copy status for each copy or Table of Contents are storedhere.
Claim dates for unreceived issues should be entered here.
The routing status of this issue of the periodical is recorded here.
This file manages transactions between FORUM and local librarysites.
This is a word-processing field in which thebibliographic history of a serials title shouldbe described along with alternative titles, synonyms,changes in publishers, etc.
This field allows the input of the names of indexingand abstracting tools in which various articles fromvarious serials titles are found.
This is a word-processing field in which the parametersof the prediction pattern should be described in plainEnglish.

This field is for those transactions that may have more thanone title to be sent in the mail message.  For example, ifa prediction pattern is changed, then all titles with thatparticular prediction pattern will appear on the mail message.
Give an explanation about why a local serial title transactionwas rejected by the National Librarians.
This is the data that was edited for a 'UTL' transaction.This will be used for the 'Any TAF Changes' report.
This file will hold selected TIU Document Definitions that will be used to create Interdisciplinary Care Plan.

This file controls the orderly sequence of lab test ordering.  All orderinginformation is stored in the other files, and supplies information for order entry and order status output.  No editing of the entries should take place, as it may causecorruption or loss of ordering information. The file contains print and sort templates that are used by a variety of lab routines and options toformat reports. CROSS REFERENCE DESCRIPTION:     >>> THIS GROUP IS SET AT THE TIME OF VERIFICATION IF NOT A CONTROL. <<<    Used by some of the reporting routines and collection list   (set to 1 when on collection list)       This is used by the daily cummulative         Used by LRWD to give a list of patients with new lab data since    the start of the day.
The sequential specimen number.
Points to the specimen(s) for the given order.  (Some areas of labtreat a collection of samples as a SINGLE collection "sample").
The tests for the specimen.
Comments about the order.
ICD-9 ordering diagnosis code.

This field contains the a listing of test to be collected from this patient.

This file used to hold print headers for anatomic path reports and as a temporary holding file for path cumulative, incomplete and complete reports. It may also be used for any accession area file since the NAME (.01) field is a pointer to the accession area file (68).

Here are stored the temporary list of specimens logged-in for printing at time of microscopic exam.  The report will contain all past specimens with their SNOMED coding in free text form for Surg path, cytopath, and EM. If there are gross descriptions they will be part of the print-out.
SNOMED coded topography categories
SNOMED morphology entries

This field contains post operative diagnosis.

This mulitple contains AP Specimen/Collection Sample information.
This multiple contains the CPRS AP Dialog data.
This field contains the CPRS Dialog data for this specimen.

This is a temporary list of final path reports to be printed on demand. Entries automatically are entered when the microscopic diagnoses or supplementary are entered for Surg path, Cytopath or Electron microscopy.
Entry number to appropriate file
ID number of label
Generic label name
Name of the report on demand from the Lab Data file
Names of users from file 200

This file contains additional search and extract parameters to be used by the Laboratory Search/Extract software. These parameters are not specific to entries in LAB SEARCH/EXTRACT file (#69.5), but are specific to the Protocol (refer to Protocol file #101) being used.
This is the User(s) or Group that will receive alerts statingthe extract has run automatically.

This file contains search criteria used by the Laboratory Search/Extract software. This file should only be edited using  the Search/Extract Parameter Setup option [LREPI PARAMETER SETUP] provided with this software.

This file holds a pointer to the REMINDER DEFINITION (#811.9) file foruse by the Emerging Pathogens Initiative (EPI). The entries in this fileare used to determine which Clinical Reminders will be used to generatedata for the Hepatitis C registry.
This is the PTF file enty to be followed.
This is the general description for the entry.
This is the test that is to be searched for and retrieved.
This defines the Etiology to search for.
This defines the ICD9 to search for.
This determines that if any of the Etiologies selected are to be resistantto any Antimicrobials.
This determines what Topography to screen for.
This determines what Topography to screen out.
This is a list of SNOMED codes to be included in the search.

Lab Orders Pending file serves as a temporary storage locations forelectronic laboratory test orders. LEDI software populates and manages thecontents of this file. Electronic test orders from VA collecting sites are stored in this fileuntil ordered test results have been returned. Electronic orders arematched with physically shipped specimen during accessioning process.Specimen processing status update information is also stored in this fileto assist in the management of workload. When the results have been stored in the collecting site's patientclinical record, entries will be purged from this file. NOTE: The user should not directly edit this file via FileMan. Appropriateoptions are provided to manage the data in this file.
Stores the specimens information that accompany an AP order.Information is moved to corresponding fields in LAB DATAfile (#63) when order is accessioned.
Stores the various textual information that accompanies AP orders - patient history, pre-op diagnosis, operative findings, gross   description, frozen section , etc.
Text that accompanied the AP order for the corresponding information type.

For entries the most recent results of tests selected below will be displayed or printed.  Ex. You may want to know the results of selected chemistries for a patient who has just had a liver biopsy.  Topography entered would be LIVER For blood bank the tests entered will be displayed whenever a  crossmatch is ordered or when components are displayed.
Most recent results, if any, will be displayed for tests selected associated with a specific topography indicated above when that organ or tissue is submitted to anatomic pathology.
Contains the question to be asked of the user.
This field contains URL for additional information.
Enter the CPRS ID name

This file contains the information for the configuration of the LR AP Dialog for CPRS for AP ordering. There is one LR AP Dialog form which can be reused for any orderable item for AP. This configuration will allow for control over default values, the ability to find controls/prompts, and to build prompt assistance elements (builder blocks) that aid the user in populating the specimen description or word processing fields such as clinical history.
This file is used to capture and retain the specimen demographics.

This file holds specific information which defines certain site parametersrelating to the actual functioning of your laboratory.  The parametersinclude the official laboratory site name, whether the physician's name mustbe entered when ordering and/or accessioning tests, what type of accessionlabel format (if any) the lab will be using, and scheduled hours of routinephlebotomy collection times, as well as others.
The order cut-off time for associated collection time.  Time is in 24 hourformat.  Orders placed after the cut-off time will be put on the nextroutine lab collection.
This field contains the default parameters used to print Micro surveyreport.
This field contains a history of archive activity done in the past. Italso may contain information concerning archive process in progress.
This field contains those locations which have special printing or specimencollection status apart from other hospital locations.
This field contains the default parameters for the Micro Trend Report.

If your laboratory provides specimen collection service outsideof the normal routine collection, use this subfile to enter data aboutyour particular site. The parameters of Immediate Lab Collect define oneinstitution. Therefore, multidivisional sites can have different parametersfor each division.

This sub-file is for multidivisional sites that wish to print lab collectorders at separate divisions.  If this field is left blank, then the #303Log Printer for Routine LC is used.  Also, this sub-file is for multi-divisional sites that wish to have default label printers from LABLABEL toa division specific printer.
Used by Laboratory software to identify which devices are label printers.This allows the software to handle various types of label printers andlabel stock.

Engineering site parameter file. There should only be ONE entry in thisfile. If there is more than one entry, the routines will not know whichone to believe and are likely to produce unexpected results.

Enter the FIELD NUMBER (from the Equipment File) of a field that youwant to have printed (in human readable format) on your bar coded EQUIPMENTLABEL's.  Please do not enter more than two (2) such fields.  If more thantwo fields are specified, the system will accept the first two and ignoreall others. MULTIPLE fields, WORD PROCESSING fields, and COMPUTED fields should notbe selected for inclusion on bar coded EQUIPMENT LABEL's.
The field number (from the Equipment File) of a field or fields(no more than two) that you want to see on your Companion Lists.

Used by package specific device selection logic to assist users inidentifying output devices. As a rule, only hardcopy print devices shouldbe contained in this file. The intent is to discourage users frominadvertently sending output to a CRT or some other device not intendedfor printing.  This file also contains device-specific instructions for customizedformats and data layouts for use when printing bar coded equipment andlocation labels from AEMS/MERS. It is quite conceiveable for more thanone entry in the Engineering Computer Port file to point to the sameentry in the Device file (#3.5), the difference could be the bar codeinstructions.

Used by developers to contain information that governs the performanceof selected options. When choices have to be made and there is no clearconsensus among stations as to which choice is most advantageous, anattempt is usually made to make the subject parameter site selectableby including it in this file.
Description of the possible choices.
Contains applicable divisions for a multi-divisional facility.
History of changes and enhancements to Engineering Package.the Engineering Package.
File of screens used by Engineering Screen Handler.
Definition of each line item on a data entry screen.

This file contains default PM (preventive maintenance) parameters fordevice types. The intent is to give facilities a means of schedulingPM inspections for a given device type (defibrillator, transformer,electrical generator, etc) without having to explicitly edit therecord of each individual piece of equipment. If the PM parameters in theEQUIPMENT file (File 6914) do not agree with the corresponding PM parametersin this file, the information in the EQUIPMENT file will take precedence.

Any shop having maintenance responsibility for this item should be enteredhere. The principal use of this field is in generating preventivemaintenance worklists. If there is no RESPONSIBLE SHOP, the item will beignored by the PM module.

A multiple field intended to allow for selection of Equipment Categoriesin more than one way. For example: the Equipment Category of'ELECTROCARDIOGRAPH' would probably have 'EKG' and 'ECG' as synonyms.A MNEMONIC cross-reference of the entire Equipment Category File bythis SYNONYM field will insure that SYNONYM's are found along withNAME's during any look-up.
List of manufacturers. Centrally maintained, courtesy of EngineeringService Center, St. Louis. Local entries may be added using a MFGID of50000 or greater.
Other names by which this manufacturer is commonly known.

Repository of all capital assets. Typically used by Engineering andAcquisition and Materiel Management Services. Capitalized nonexpendableequipment records in this file are electronically ported to thecentralized VA data base (Fixed Assets Package) in Austin.
Any information that may be of value to Engineering or Supply Servicein managing this equipment.
History of all maintenance performed on this equipment. Maintainedautomatically by the Work Order module of AEMS/MERS. Under normalcircumstances, this field should not be edited via File Manager.

Any shop having maintenance responsibility for this item should be enteredhere. The principal use of this field is in generating preventivemaintenance worklists. If there is no RESPONSIBLE SHOP, the item willbe ignored by the PM module.
This field contains comments entered by IT staff concerning an ITequipment record.
Consolidated Memoranda of Receipt in use at your facility. Basicinstrument for establishing accountability for non-expendableequipment.

File of formal procedures used at the host site in the performance ofscheduled maintenance (PMI). If a facility wants their source documentsin electronic format and is willing to accept the limitations of theFileMan word-processing editor, then the actual step by step text of aPM Procedure may be stored in this file.
Enter the actual PM instructions here. Sites that are short on disk spaceshould generally maintain the actual procedures in hard copy only.
File of Standard General Ledgers (SGL) appropriate for capitalizednon-expendable (NX) equipment. This file should not be locally modified.
File of Budget Object Codes (BOC) appropriate for capitalizednon-expendable (NX) equipment. This file should not be locally modified.
File of Funds appropriate for capitalized non-expendable (NX) equipment.This file should not be locally modified.
File of Administration/Offices (A/O) appropriate for capitalizednon-expendable (NX) equipment. This file should not be locally modified.
File of Disposition Methods appropriate for capitalizednon-expendable (NX) equipment. This file should not be locally modified.

This file contains the standard department codes for Equipment InventoryListings (EIL) as determined by OA&MM in VACO. It is used to derive thecost center of equipment and to validate the CMR field for FA and FRDocuments.
List of reasons for creation of an adjustment voucher to a Fixed Asset(FAP) Document.
File of FA documents sent to Fixed Assets. This file should not be locallymodified.
File of FB documents sent to Fixed Assets. This file should not be locallymodified.
File of FC documents sent to Fixed Assets. This file should not be locallymodified.
File of FD documents sent to Fixed Assets. This file should not be locallymodified.
File of FR documents sent to Fixed Assets. This file should not be locallymodified.

This file contains monthly closing dollar balances by station, fund, andstandard general ledger for capitalized non-expendable equipment. Thevalues for the current month are automatically updated when Fixed Assets(FAP) Documents are transmitted. If there has not been any activity in agiven month the dollar balance for that month can be obtained by lookingat the preceeding month which has a value. The dollar balances are solely based on FAP Document code sheets. Thevalues in this file can be recalculated from the FAP Documents ifneccessary. See the Recalculate FAP Balances option for more information. This file must not be directly edited or locally modified.
The field contains the fund (by station) for which capitalizednon-expendable equipment has been transmitted to Fixed Assets.
This field contains the Standard General Ledger (by station and fund) forwhich capitalized non-expendable equipment was transmitted to FixedAssets.

A simple file of physical buildings. A 'division designation' maybe included if needed to distinguish between two buildings havingthe same number. Suppose, for example, there were two buildingsnumbered 100 at VAMC St. Louis, one at the John Cochran Divisionand one at Jefferson Barracks. These two buildings could be enteredseparately as 100-JC and 100-JB; where 'JB' and 'JC' are divisiondesignators. This file contains imaging information for patients.  This file is thefocal point of the entire radiology/nuclear medicine module. The file has four basic sections.  They are the following:     I. General Patient demographics   II. Patient demographics that are imaging related  III. Registered exam information   IV. Outside films registry; where films received from other hospitals       are recorded into the system  Data Storage ------------The data for the 'RAD/NUC MED PATIENT' file is stored under the global. This file is very volatile and should be journaled and translated ifthe operating system supports these two functions.  Input Templates ---------------The following is a list of input templates used by the packageand the entry in the OPTIONS file (#19) that uses the template:                        Compiled Name                  Routine    Description; Option(s) ----                  --------   ---------------------- RA DIAGNOSTIC BY CASE            Used to input interpreting physicians                                  and diagnostic code;                                  RA DIAGCN  RA OUTSIDE ADD                   Add outside films into system;                                  RA ADDEXAM  RA OUTSIDE EDIT                  Edit outside film registry;                                  RA OUTEDIT  RA OUTSIDE SUPEROK               Indicate outside film to require                                  supervisor 'ok' before returning;                                  RA OUTFLAG   RA CANCEL                        Cancel a registered exam;                                  RA CANCEL  RA EXAM EDIT                     Edit a registered exam;                                  RA EDITCN, RA EDITPT  RA LAST PAST VISIT               Allows entry of the last visit by a                                  patient to the department                                  before this module was installed;                                  RA PAST  RA NO PURGE SPEC IFICATION       Indicates no purging of an exam report.                                  RA NOPURGE  RA OVERRIDE                      Exam status is made complete without                                  doing a requirements check;                                  RA OVERRIDE  RA REGISTER                                             RA REG  RA STATUS CHANGE                 Status Tracking input;                                  RA STATRACK If any modifications to these input templates are needed for localpurposes, then great care should be taken not to degrade anybranching logic in the template.  Making modifications is not recommended. The following templates contain a large amount of branching andMUMPS code and as a result they are uneditable:    - RA REGISTER   - RA STATUS CHANGE   - RA EXAM EDIT   Print Templates --------------- The following is a list of print templates used by the package:  Name                 Description; Option(s) ----                 ----------------------  RA DAILY LOG         Prints an informational report for all                      exams for a specified date.                      RA LOG  RA OUTSIDE LIST      Prints list of outside films needing to be                      returned by a specified date;                      RA OUTSIDERPT  Sort Templates -------------- The following is a list of sort templates associated with this file:  Name                 Related Print Template ----                 ----------------------   RA DAILY LOG        RA DAILY LOG   RA OUTSIDE LIST     RA OUTSIDE LIST Also, the modification of the other sort templates is not recommended.
This is a multiple field containing information about the patient'sregistered Radiology/Nuclear Medicine exams.
This is a multiple field containing information on all imagingexaminations performed during this patient visit.  All exams (cases)within one exam date must be of the same imaging type.
This is a multiple field containing the sizes of the films used and filmswasted during this exam.

This is a multiple field containing a log of when the exam status waschanged from one status to another. Depending on how the system parameters are set up, this field may ormay not be filled in. Because the mass override process will degrade system performance byslowing the system down, it should be run at specified times only. (i.e.one week per quarter)
This is a multiple field containing information about this patient'sfilms obtained from an outside source.

This is a multiple field containing a log of actions that have been taken on this exam record during processing of this exam.   Use the function that allows you to View Exam by Case No. within the ExamEntry/Edit menu to view this activity log.

This is a multiple field containing a log of actions that have been taken on this outside film record.  The activity log can be used to resolve any discrepancies.  It can be displayed using the 'Inquire' option of File Manager.
This multiple tracks additional Interpreting Residents who interpreted theimages of an exam.
This multiple field is used to give the imaging modifiers that areassociated with this exam.
This multiple tracks additional Staff who have interpreted the images ofan exam.
This multiple field is used to give the names of technologists who performedthis exam. Depending on the site's specifications, this field may or may not befilled in.

This field may contain a written clinical history of the patient as wellas instructions to the interpreting physician .  For example, theinstructions might be to interpret the images to rule out the possibilityof a patient having a certain disease. This field is used as the 'Clinical History' that appears on the printedreport for each exam associated with this visit.
This field contains additional Diagnostic Codes for this Rad/Nuc Med exam.
This file contains information specific to nuclear medicine studiesin which radiopharmaceuticals are used.

If radiopharmaceutical(s) have been associated with a nuclear medprocedure, they will be automatically entered by the system when the caseis registered.  Radiopharmaceuticals associated with a case may bedeleted or added during case editing.

This file is used to measure the amount of radiation absorbed by a person,known as the "absorbed dose," which reflects the amount of energy thatradioactive sources deposit in patients, on a study by study basis,through which they pass.

An irradiation event is the occurrence of radiation being applied to a patient in a single continuous time-frame between the start (release) and the stop (cease) of the irradiation. This sub-file is a record of up to five of the highest irradiation instances for this study.
This field indicates why the examination should not be purged.
This file stores the data on Pulmonary Function Tests performed on thepatient.

This is the CP Conversion File file (#703.9).  This file is used for storingthe site parameters needed and used to convert Medicine reports to CPText reports.  This file also stores the status of the conversion processfor each converted Medicine report.

This multiple is used to store the data for the conversion log.
This file maintains the Access Control List (ACL) for items in the console by that item's ID.
This file maintains a log of HL7 Messages processed by Clinical Flowsheets.
This file monitors Clinical Flowsheets HL7 message processing anomalies.These Clinical Flowsheets HL7 messages are referenced via the CP_HL7_LOGFile (#704.002).

This file will hold a subset of patient movement data.  This must be done rather than using a direct reference to the PATIENT MOVEMENT file (#405) because, in the instance of cancellations, the internal entry number (ien) of a patient movement disappears before there is the chance to work with it.  This file will coalesce all of a movement'sdata to send to 3rd party users.  That data is sent to 3rd party usersvia Health Level Seven (HL7) messaging.  To ensure that message is available to 3rd party users, the ACCEPTED BY QUEUE field (#.09) is set to '1' to confirm the message is in the HL7 outbound queue; that CP MOVEMENT AUDIT file entry will then need to be purged.

This file will be used by the Clinical Flowsheets application to determinethe target for an outbound admission, discharge, and transfer (ADT) message.  Messages are sent to a target via Health Level 7 messaging (HL7). NOTE:A target is defined here as a receiving CIS or other COTS product thathas expressed a desire to be notified when a patient admission, transfer or discharge has occurred for a specific hospital location.
This file is used to store the site configurable shift definitions.
This file is used to store the site configurable schedules for the Kardex.

NOTICE: This file is maintained exclusively by the CP Terminology group and must not be modified or edited in any way. Subsequent releases of CP Terminology may create lasting errors in the CliO data store if this file is changed. This file stores all terminology elements for the Clinical Flowsheetsapplication. The entries in this file are called "terms".  These terms along with CP files #704.102 - #704.109 constitute the Clinical Data Model.

NOTICE: This file is maintained exclusively by the CP Terminology group and must not be modified or edited in any way. Subsequent releases of CP Terminology may create lasting errors in the CliO data store if this file is changed.  GUI PROGRAMMING NOTES: This file translates 1-1 to the TTermType ordinal set by the file's internal entry number (ien). The ordinal set is as follows:   TTermType = (ttUnknown, ttObservation, ttUnit, ttMethod, ttPosition,                ttLocation, ttQuality, ttProduct, ttNullFlavor, ttTask,               ttSchedule, ttValue, ttConcept);

NOTICE: This file is maintained exclusively by the CP Terminology group and must not be modified or edited in any way. Subsequent releases of CP Terminology may create lasting errors in the CliO data store if this file is changed. This file is a join table for the Clinical Data Model that matches observations to their allowable qualifiers.  A sample could be the observation equating to "weight" and the paired qualifier equating to "lift scale".

NOTICE: This file is maintained exclusively by the CP Terminology group and must not be modified or edited in any way. Subsequent releases of CP Terminology may create lasting errors in the CliO data store if this file is changed. This file links like units of measure together with required conversion logic to change the value from one unit to another. NOTE:Units are presented as entries in the TERM File (#704.101). For example the unit "CENTIMETER" could be identified by the TERMFile (#704.101), TERM ID (field #.01) "{EF700458-8C2D-16E8-02DC-9E1711584C53}".

NOTICE: This file is maintained exclusively by the CP Terminology group and must not be modified or edited in any way. Subsequent releases of CP Terminology may create lasting errors in the CliO data store if this file is changed. This file matches observation(s) with available units for the observation,and the range settings for each pair. NOTE: Observations are presented as entries in the TERM File (#704.101). For example the observation "TRACTION WEIGHT" could be identified by the TERM File (#704.101), TERM ID (field #.01) "{0C913807-C678-4E94-BD20-B8B2EBE697BE}".

NOTICE: This file is maintained exclusively by the CP Terminology group and must not be modified or edited in any way. Subsequent releases of CP Terminology may create lasting errors in the CliO data store if this file is changed. This file holds the structure for complex observations by pairing the parent observation to the child observation with an ordinal position as well.  Observations are entries in the TERM File (#704.101)

This file maintains value ranges for related observations/terms. An example could be a TERM RANGE CHECK entry that would result in an observed TEMPERATURE of 80 DEGREES FAHRENHEIT for a MALE between 55-150 years of AGE, triggering a "CRITICAL LOW" response by the Clinical Flowsheets application.

NOTICE: This file is maintained exclusively by the CP Terminology group and must not be modified or edited in any way. Subsequent releases of CP Terminology may create lasting errors in the CliO data store if this file is changed. This file is the anchor for the mapping table structure for the CP Gateway. Each mapping table is called up by elements in the HL7 message.  The entries are used to translate the HL7 data into appropriate CP terminology.

NOTICE: This file is maintained exclusively by the CP Terminology group and must not be modified or edited in any way. Subsequent releases of CP Terminology may create lasting errors in the CliO data store if this file is changed.  This file correlates a vendor (VENDOR KEY field #.1) with a mapping-table (MAPPING TABLE ID field #.01) and an HL7 message segment(TERM TYPE field #.03).A sample entry could be interpreted as follows:         Mapping-TableXX is used for processing when VendorX has sent an          XType message.

This file maintains the views displayed within a flowsheet via the Clinical Flowsheets application.  A view is a group of terms displayed together.A sample view could display "ICU VITALS,INPUTS,OUTPUTS, and ICU HEMODYNAMICS" information together in a section of a flowsheet displayed via the Clinical Flowsheets application.

This file maintains the relationships between views of OBS_VIEW File (#704.111) and terms of TERM File (#704.001). Note: Some field descriptions are directed to a programming and development audience.
This file maintains relationships between view entries in the OBS VIEW File (#704.1111) and qualifiers/filters.
This file maintains the flowsheets used by the Clinical Flowsheets application.
This file maintains the relationships between OBS_FLOWSHEET File (#704.112) entries and pages/view (OBS_VIEW File #704.111) entries.
This file maintains supplemental pages/views.  The supplemental page is a variation of a page as supported via the OBS_FLOWSHEET_PAGE File (#704.1121).
This file maintains flowsheets (file #704.112) and observation totals (file #704.113) relationships.
This file maintains observation totals.
This maintains relationships between OBS TOTAL File (#704.113) entries and TERM File (#704.101) entries.
This file supports the Clinical Flowsheets application "alarm" functionality.  And the file maintains the relationships between alarms and patients.
This file maintains sets of observations used by the Clinical Flowsheets application.
This file maintains the relationships between observations and observation sets.
This file maintains observations for use with the Clinical Flowsheets application.
This file maintains relationships between observations and qualifiers.
This file maintains the chains of observation audits for Clinical Flowsheets observations.  An audit is defined here as a change in anobservation's status, state, or condition.
This file supports Clinical Flowsheets scheduled tasks and actions functionality.
This file supports Clinical Flowsheets scheduled events/actions functionality.
This file maintains audits of scheduled event/tasks via the Clinical Flowsheets application.
This file contains data describing a patients access point history for dialysis treatments. All data is stored as XML documents in UUEncoded format for VA Fileman compatibility.
This field holds the XML in UUEncoded format for this patient's access points for dialysis treatments.
This field holds the XML in UUEncoded format for this patient's accesshistory for dialysis treatments.
This field holds the XML in UUEncoded format for this patient's infectionhistory for dialysis treatments.
This file contains data describing each patient procedure fordialysis treatments. All data is stored as XML documents in UUEncodedformat for VA Fileman compatibility.
This field contains the study data XML document in UUEncoded format.
This field contains the summary data XML document in UUEncoded format.
This field contains the flowsheet data XML document in UUEncoded format.
This field contains the med log data XML document in UUEncoded format.
This field contains the Note List data XML document inUUEncoded format.
This field contains the Event Log data XML document inUUEncoded format.
This file contains system and user level settings for the client application. All data is stored as XML documents in UUEncodedformat for VA Fileman compatibility.
This field contains the XML document for this setting in UUEncoded format.

This file contains all the procedures that may be associated with animaging exam.  The entries in this file are the allowable choices the userwill be able to pick from at the procedure prompt. This prompt appears aspart of the 'Register', 'Case No. Edit' and the 'Exam Status Tracking'functions of the module. If the procedure has an inactivation date less than the current datethen the procedure is not a valid choice and will not appear on thelist of valid/active procedures when displayed to the user. Once this software is in production, you should never delete any entries.Entries can be deactivated by entering an 'inactivation' date for theentry. Adding new entries is always allowed.   Data Storage ------------The data for the 'RAD/NUC MED PROCEDURES' file is stored in the global. At the present time this file is very static after day-oneinitialization is complete.  However, it still should be journaled.It should also be translated if the operating system supports this function.  Input Templates --------------- The following is a list of input templates used by the package and the entry in the OPTIONS file (#19) that uses the template:  Name                 Routine            Description; Option(s)                     Compiled ____                ________            ____________ RA PROCEDURE EDIT             Use to enter/edit procedure to the file; If any modifications to this input template are needed for localpurposes, then great care should be taken not to degrade any branching logicin the template.  Print Templates --------------- The following is a list of print templates used by the package:  Name                         Description; Option(s) ____                         ______________________ RA ALPHA LIST OF ACTIVES     Prints a listing of procedures and used with                              the ALPHA LIST OF ACTIVES sort template to                              list only 'active' procedures;                              RA ALPHALIST  RA PROCEDURE LIST            Prints a 'long' listing of procedures;                              RA PROCLONG, RA INACPRCLONG, RA PROCSERIES  RA PROCEDURE SHORT LIST      Prints a 'short' listing of procedures;                              RA PROCSHORT, RA INACPRCSHORT  Sort Templates -------------- The following is a list of sort templates used by the package:  Name                         Related Print Template ----                         ---------------------- RA ALPHA LIST OF ACTIVES     ALPHA LIST OF ACTIVES  RA PROCEDURES BY             PROCEDURE LIST AMIS CODES  RA SERIES ONLY               PROCEDURE LIST  The modification of any sort templates is not recommended.
This is a multiple field which allows procedure names to be cross-referencedby their synonyms.
This field identifies the contrast agent(s) associated with thisRad/Nuc Med procedure.
This is a multiple field containing information about the films usuallyneeded for this procedure.
This is a multiple field containing information for the AMIS codesassociated with this procedure.
This is a multiple, used to select messages that pertain to this procedure.

This is a multiple field containing procedures that are considereddescendents of this parent procedure.  Only 'Parent' procedures may havedescendents.  If a 'Parent' procedure is ordered, its descendents will beregistered during the registration function.

Default medication(s) may be entered by the ADPAC for a procedure.  Ifthey are entered, the system will automatically enter them on thepatient's exam record whenever the procedure is registered.NOTE: Default Radiopharmaceuticals may NOT be entered here; they should beentered on a separate field.

Default radiopharmaceuticals and related information are edited byADPACs during system set-up.  If default radiopharmaceutical(s) areentered for a procedure, they will be automatically entered on the patientrecord each time this procedure is registered.  Information enteredby the ADPAC related to the radiopharmaceutical may appear during caseedit as a default response or may be used for edit checking.

The text entered here should describe the procedure.  It may be used byclinicians who are trying to familiarize themselves with imagingprocedures that are available via an option within this software system.This text can also be displayed along with the procedure message duringthe ordering process if the Rad/Nuc Med Procedure file parameter thatcontrols displaying it when ordered is set to 'Yes'.

This file contains the valid AMIS codes, descriptions and weighted workunits as assigned by Radiology Service in VACO. The data in this file isused in the compilation of various workload reports including the AMISReport. New entries and modifications to existing entries is prohibited withoutapproval from Radiology Service VACO.  Data Storage ------------ The data for the 'MAJOR RAD/NUC MED AMIS CODES' file is stored in thethe global should be journaled.  It should also be translated if theoperating system supports this function.  Input Templates --------------- The package does not use any input templates associated with thisfile.  Print Templates --------------- The package does not use any print templates associated with thisfile.   Sort Templates -------------- The package does not use any sort templates associated with thisfile.

This file temporarily hold a new radiology procedure while it is being developed and associated to the MASTER RADIOLOGY PROCEDURE file (#71.11).After the procedure is created and matched it will be moved to theRAD/NUC MED PROCEDURE file (#71) and then deleted from 71.11.
This is a multiple field containing informationabout the films usually needed for thisprocedure.
This is a multiple field containing informationfor the AMIS codes associated with thisprocedure.

This is a multiple field containing proceduresthat are considered descendents of this parentprocedure.  Only 'Parent' procedures may have descendents.  If a 'Parent' procedure isordered, its descendents will be registeredduring the registration function.

Default radiopharmaceuticals and relatedinformation are edited by ADPACs during systemset-up.  If default radiopharmaceutical(s) are entered for a procedure, they will beautomatically entered on the patient recordeach time this procedure is registered. Information entered by the ADPAC related to theradiopharmaceutical may appear during case editas a default response or may be used for editchecking.
This is a multiple field which allowsprocedure names to be cross-referenced byother names. They may be locally preferred names, or a common misspelling.
This field identifies the contrast agent(s)associated with this Rad/Nuc Med procedure.
One or more default CPT Modifiers may beentered for this procedure.  Each entry will bescreened against the CPT CODE for thisprocedure.

Default medication(s) may be entered by theADPAC for a procedure.  If they are entered,the system will automatically enter them on the patient's exam record whenever the procedure isregistered.  NOTE: Default Radiopharmaceuticalsmay NOT be entered here; they should be enteredon a separate field.
This multiple field points to the RAD MODALITY DEFINEDTERMS file (#73.1).  Which is a list ofprocedure modes.
This is a multiple, used to select messagesthat pertain to this procedure.

The text entered here should describe theprocedure.  It may be used by clinicians whoare trying to familiarize themselves withimaging procedures that are available via anoption within this software system.  This textcan also be displayed along with the proceduremessage during the ordering process if theRad/Nuc Med Procedure file parameter that controls displaying it when ordered is set to'Yes'.

This file contains the modifiers that can be associated with an imagingexam.  These modifiers are used to further describe the procedureassociated with the exam. For example, if an exam of the 'hand' wasperformed then the modifier 'left' can be chosen to indicate which hand. If an exam has a modifier associated with it, then it will automaticallyappear on the report. When the system is installed, the following modifiers are loaded as partof the module:          o PORTABLE         o OPERATING ROOM         o BILATERAL         o LEFT         o RIGHT Portable, Operating Room and Bilateral are very important for thecompilation of the AMIS report.  For this reason, the name of themodifier is uneditable.  Any modifier who meaning is portable, operatingroom, or bilateral should be further defined by entering one of thesechoices in the AMIS Credit Indicator field. Series type procedures cannotbe assigned modifiers that affect AMIS credit. Entries in this file should not be deleted. Adding new entries is alwaysallowed. Each modifier must be assigned one or more Imaging Type(s) in order toappear as a selection during modifier edits of procedures and exams. Todeactivate a modifier, use the option for editing procedure modifiers todelete all the imaging types that appear under the modifier. To add site specific modifiers and to obtain more information regardingthis file, see the ADPAC Guide.  Data Storage ------------ The data for the 'PROCEDURE MODIFIERS' file is stored in the global. At the present time this file is very static afterinitialization is complete.  However, it still should be journaled.It should also be translated if the operating system supports this function.  Input Templates --------------- The package does not use any input templates associated with thisfile.  Print Templates --------------- The package does not use any print templates associated with thisfile.  Sort Templates -------------- The package does not use any sort templates associated with thisfile.
This field contains the name of the type of imaging from the'Imaging Type' file.  Enter imaging types for which this modifieris valid.

This file contains the procedures used in the display of common procedureswhen requesting a procedure.  Up to 40 active common procedures areallowed per imaging type.  Active common procedures have a sequence numberthat determines their display order on the common procedure selectionscreen.
This field identifies the Procedure Modifiers that are associatedwith this Common Procedure.  Common Procedures may have more than oneProcedure Modifier association.

This file contains messages concerning special requirements when orderinga procedure.  One or more of these messages can be tied to a procedurein the Rad/Nuc Med Procedures file (#71) so that they are displayed to arequestor at the time an order is placed.  Data Storage ------------ The data for the 'RAD/NUC MED PROCEDURE MESSAGE' file is stored in the  Templates --------- The package does not use any input, print or sort templatesassociated with this file.

This file contains valid imaging stop codes.  It is not pointed to byany other file.  The Rad/Nuc Med ADPAC should make sure this file isupdated.  Obsolete or unused entries should be deleted.  This file should contain all stop codes that can be assigned to imaging locationsat the facility.
This file contains all possible routes of pharmaceutical andradiopharmaceutical administration used in imaging exams.
Bodily sites of drug administration appropriate for this route ofadministration should be entered here.  During case edit, users will berestricted to selecting only the sites entered here.
This file contains frequently-used sites of drug administration forimaging exams.
This file contains the names of vendors, pharmacies, and other sources ofradiopharmaceuticals.
This file is used to record names of radiopharmaceutical lots, batches,vials, syringes, or kits at the discretion of the facility.
This file is designed to handle functions in the MASTER RADIOLOGY PROCEDUREfile (MRPF) operations that require timeframes, progress recording andfunction status and names of mail groups and ADPACS.

Per VHA Directive 2005-044, this file has been "locked down" by Data Standardization (DS).  The file definition (i.e. data dictionary) shall not be modified.  All additions, changes and deletions to entries in the file shall be done by Enterprise Reference Terminology (ERT) using the Master File Server (MFS), provided by Common Services (CS).  Creating and/or editing locally defined fields in the file are not permitted.  Use of locally defined fields that were created prior to the VHA Directive's 2005-044 effective date shall not be supported.
This is the long description for this LOINC.  This description can exceed500 characters in length.
This the long name assigned to this entry.  This name can exceed500 characters.
Describes the pair Status and Effective Date/Time for each reference term.
This is the primary data file for the NOIS (National Online InformationSharing) problem reporting system.  It holds data for problem calls.
This is the description of the problem for the NOIS call.
This is an ongoing dialog about the NOIS call.  Responses are appendedto this field.
This is a summary of what resolved the NOIS call.
This is a description of any edits made to the NOIS call.  This doesnot include status changes or new entries.
This is a history of status changes made to the call.
This file stores the last number used in creating a NOIS Call ID.The number is unique to the year and month of when the NOIS call is reported.
This file stores notifications that are scheduled on NOIS calls.
This file stores NOIS calls that will alert a user.
This file has calls where alerts have been sent (manually).
This file is used to edit word-processing fields on a NOIS call.When the data is accepted the text in this file is copied to theNOIS file and the entry in this file is deleted.
This is the text entry made when editing NOIS calls.
This is the text of the response.
This file holds NOIS calls for active-update type lists.
This is the message associated with the install.
This file contains information on the locations (sites or services)that report NOIS calls.
This is a description of the location.
These are synonyms for this location.
These are names used by the client for this location.
This file contains information on NOIS users. Specialists canedit NOIS calls, define lists, and use fields in this file as personalparameters and defaults.
These fields control defaults when entering NOIS calls.
