The 1010EZ MAPPING File holds the mapping between each data elementin the On-Line 10-10EZ Application and the VistA Patient database.Each record in this file is uniquely identified by a Data Key whichcorrelates exactly with a specific 10-10EZ form question within aspecific 10-10EZ section.  Each record also contains the exact VistAdatabase location (i.e., file/sub-file/field) where the data will bestored. Local modifications to this file will cause the the 1010EZ moduleto malfunction and may jeopardize database integrity.

This file contains the Domains, which are a subset of medicine, a natural grouping of clinical acts (e.g., demographics,  vital signs, laboratory,pharmacy) and the VistA File/Fields associated with the Domain. This file is used on the Central Server and Facility for VUID Implementation.
The File/Field associated with the record.
This file contains the schema for XML documents.  It maintains everyXML element, it's sequence and whether the element has sub-elementsand whether the element is a multiple.
Each element (line) in the XML message is assigned an element number.The elements are processed by this number, so this data determinesthe sequence of data for the XML message.
This file contains the different status codes used by Data Standardizationprocesses. This file is used on the Central Server and Facility for VUID Implementation.
Description of the status and/or it's use.
This file contains the File/Fields in VistA. This file is used on the Central Server and Facility for VUID Implementation

This file contains the association of a Term/Conceptand its VUID and Activation Status as defined byEnterprise Reference Terminology (ERT). This file is used on the Central Server for VUID Implementation.
Describes the pair Status and Effective Date/Time for eachreference term.
The File/Field associated with the record.
This file contains the system related information for a facility. This file is used on the Central Server for VUID Implementation.

This file contains the Term/Concept assigned to a VistA File/Field InternalEntry Number (IEN) at a Facility (VAMC) by the Data Standardization VUIDImplementation Process. This file is used on the Central Server for VUID Implementation.
This file contains the Status of the VUID Implementation Process for a VistAFile/Field at a Facility (VAMC). This file is used on the Central Server and Facility for VUID Implementation.

This file contains system specific data.  On the central server(s) this file contains data specific to the systems communicating to it/them and variable information required when processing facility data.  On VistAsystems this file contains data specific to the facility, such as thelocation(s) of the central server(s).  The local system is typically thefirst entry in the file but there is no requirement for this to be true.

Each record in this file holds the contents of an On-Line 10-10EZApplication as received via e-mail at this site.  As the 10-10EZ Application is processed by the user, processing audit informationis also stored here. This file may not be directly edited through FileMan.
This multiple field holds a subrecord for each data element providedby the Applicant in the On-Line 10-10EZ.
This word-processing field holds whatever the Applicant entered in theOn-Line 10-10EZ in the Comments section of the Application.

This file stores the Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA) code foreach Zip Code.  The MSA code is used to identify the correctrecord in the GMT Thresholds file (#712.5) for counties that havemultiple threshold records.

This file contains the site specific parameters which are used by theEnrollment Application System. The parameters are set by using the 'EASMT Parameters' menu option.  The parameters are used in theauto-generation of the 60, 30 and zero day means test letters.

This file contains the patient list for which the automated means testletters have been generated.  This file will also allow specific patientsto be flagged from having means test reminder letters generated.  Based onlocal class III file #6185243

This file contains the patients Means Test anniversary date and letterthreshold dates.  Entries are generated when the auto-generated Means TestLetter functionality runs for reminder letters. 60, 30 and zero daythresholds are set, with respective Flag to Print? and Printed statusfields.

This file contains the EAS Means Test letters that may be sent out by asite.  The initial section of the letter should not be modified locally.Facilities should enter facility specific information in the FINAL SECTIONfield.
Main body of the letter.  Do not modify, changes will be directed asnecessary
Division related section of the letter

This file contains the reasons why a veteran would qualify for anexemption from Long Term Care co-payments.  This file is pointed to by theReason for Exemption field (#2.07) in the Annual Means Test file(#408.31).

This file stores the data relating to maximum Long Term Care (LTC) copayment calculations.  When an HL7 message is received and an EAS protocol event is invoked the Enrollment Application System will calculate the LTC copayment amounts and store the data received and calculated in this file.  The data is later on extracted and sent back to the requesting application via HL7 messaging.

This file contains the statuses an imaging exam may be in, as itis processed. The fields in this file generally fall into three basic categories:           o fields that indicate what data has to be entered for an            exam in order for the exam to be placed in the status.           o when using the 'Exam Status Tracking' system, which prompts            should be asked of the user when trying to move an exam            into the status.           o fields that indicate to the various workload report            routines whether an exam in a particular exam status            should be used in the compilation of the report When the system is initialized, the following statuses andtheir 'order' in the exam process are loaded into this file:          Order            Status         -----            ------          1               WAITING FOR EXAM          2               CALLED FOR EXAM          3               EXAMINED          4               TRANSCRIBED          9               COMPLETE          0               CANCELLED The site does not have to use this configuration.  The only requirementsof the system are the following:           o there must be a status with an order of '1'; this is the            status that the module will place an exam in upon registration.           o there must be a status with an order of '9'; when an exam            reaches this status then the module considers the exam            complete and the exam can no longer be called up by case            number; also the case number can then be reused.           o there must be a status with an order of '0' and it must            be called 'CANCELLED'.  Data Storage ------------The data for the EXAMINATION STATUS' file is stored in the global. At the present time this file is very static after day-oneinitialization is complete.  However, it still should be journaled.It should also be translated if the operating system supports this function.  Input Templates ---------------The following is a list of input templates used by the packageand the entry in the OPTIONS file (#19) that uses the template:                      Compiled Name                Routine      Description; Option(s)------               -------      ---------------------- RA STATUS ENTRY                 Used to enter/edit entries in this file;                                 RA EXAMSTATUS  This input template should not be modified.  Print Templates ---------------The package does not use any print templates associated with thisfile.  Sort Templates --------------The package does not use any sort templates associated with thisfile.

This file contains the categories and procedures associated withDSS units in the Event Capture software. All entries in this fileare procedures. If flagged using the CATEGORY (Y/N) field (2)these entries will be recognized as categories and procedures. Entries in this file are locally entered and edited. A synonym fieldis provided for local use in identifying these entries within varioushospital departments. **NOTE**This file is being exported with Event Capture Version 2.0 foruse in converting existing data, at the pilot sites, to currentdata formats. This file will be removed in a future release ofthe Event Capture software. ** Per patch EC*2*5, this file has been starred for deletion. **

This file is used to update when the Event Capture software isinstalled. It is used during the post installation process to trackprevious package installation information. In Version 2.0, thepost installation routine sets entry number one (1) and the dateand time the post installation routine ran to completion. Thisinformation is used for future reference. Version 2.0 requiresextensive data conversion if a previous pilot version of thissoftware is resident at site.  This file should NOT be modified directly using VA FileMan. This information is set during the package installation process.

This file contains information that is used to screen medicalprocedures based  on a unique location, DSS unit, category,and procedure.  This file should NOT be modified directly using VA FileMan. **NOTE**This file is being exported with Event Capture Version 2.0 foruse in converting existing data, at the pilot sites, to currentdata formats. This file will be removed in a future release ofthe Event Capture software. ** Per patch EC*2*5, this file has been starred for deletion. **

This file contains information that is used to screen proceduresbased on a unique location, DSS unit, category, and procedure.Information in this file should only be entered or editedthrough the Event Code Screen (Create) option. Accessto this option is restricted to the Event Capture ManagementMenu. One important note, information related to the event codescreen cannot be deleted; however, it may be inactivatedusing the Inactivate Event Code Screens option within theEvent Capture software. This file should NOT be modified directly using VA FileMan.This information is created and edited using the Event CaptureManagement Menu options.
This file will be used to add procedure reasons to event code screens foruse in Event Capture data entry.

FileName: EC EVENT CODE SCREENS/PROC REASON LINK
Description: This file contains pointers to the EC Event Code Screens (#720.3) file andthe EC Procedure Reason (#720.4) file and is used as a "link" file betweenthe two.

This file contains procedures entered through the EventCapture software. All entries can be created, edited, ordeleted using the options provided within the EventCapture Data Entry menu. This file should NOT be modified directly using VA FileMan.
This is a multiple field.  It points to the CPT MODIFIER file #81.3.
The secondary ICD-9 diagnoses code for the procedure performed.

This is the provider(s) giving patient care for this encounter. Prior to the installation of EC*2.0*72 provider data was stored in fields #10, #15 and #17.  EC*2.0*72 converted and stored these fields' data in this field #42,"PROVIDER MULTIPLE".
Say what you want.
Created for CCU lab.
This file contains data extract information used by the DMMS software.

This file contains the medical specialties associated with DSSunits and ordering sections associated with patient procedures.Entries in this file will be determined by the Decision SupportSystem (DSS) Program Office or designee. This file should NOT be modified directly using VA FileMan.Any additions, deletions, or modifications will be distributednationally through the release of the Event Capture software.

This file contains all DSS units defined for use in the EventCapture software. Entries cannot be deleted but may beinactivated using the Event Capture software. The fieldsrepresenting service, medical specialty and cost centerare required for each DSS unit. These fields can be editedusing options on the Event Capture Management Menubut cannot be deleted. This file should NOT be modified directly using VA FileMan.The Event Capture Management Menu provides the optionsnecessary to create, edit, and inactivate all DSS units.

This file contains a set of nationally defined procedures foruse in the Event Capture software. These procedures arenecessary for data collection in DSS that are not representedin the CPT file (#81). These procedures were defined by theDecision Support System (DSS) Program Office or its designee. Entries in this file are standard procedures that should not beedited or deleted. Options exist within the Event CaptureManagement Menu that provide users the tools to addlocally recognized procedures to this file. These localentries will be added, by the using the Event Capturesoftware, at internal entry number above 90,000. This file should NOT be modified directly using VA FileMan.
This is a locally populated file which contains the categories thatgroup procedures within the Event Capture software. Each sitewill determine their local categories and the extent of their usage.

This file contains data about the extracts from DHCP packages.  Eachentry includes the date of the extract, the package for which theextract was run, the date range covered by the extract, and thenumber of records sent.  Data is entered into this file by theextract routines at the time extracts are transmitted to thecommercial software.  Data in this file may be viewed by appropriateoptions within the DSS package.  It is not intended that this filebe read directly via VA FileMan and DATA IN THIS FILE MUST NEVERBE EDITED.  Editing data in this file will severely compromise theintegrity of all DSS applications.
This multiple holds the message numbers sent to the Austin AutomationCenter for this extract.

This file provides a mechanism for sites to tailor the running ofpackage extracts by defining the frequency (daily, weekly, or monthly)with which the extracts will run and the number of days in the pastfor which data will be extracted.  The EXTRACT NAME field (#.01) andthe FILE NUMBER field (#1) are national standard entries, exported withthe file, and should not be edited locally.

This file contains the set of laboratory tests tracked by the DecisionSupport System along with the corresponding local data names in theLABORATORY TEST file (#60) pointed to by these tests.  This file alsocontains the local names for BLOOD and URINE specimens.  Each DSS Lab Testis assigned a predefined indicator (SOURCE field) of the type of specimen(blood or urine) that will be used as search criteria in conjunction with the local names for blood and urine specimens. Entries in this file are determined by the DSS Program Office and shouldnot be changed or deleted.  New entries in this file should not be made.
This is the data name in the LABORATORY TEST file (#60) thatcorresponds to this laboratory test.

This file contains the set of laboratory LOINC codes tracked by the Decision Support System.  It contains corresponding DSS test numbers, DSStest names, reporting units, and LOINC name. Entries in this file are determined by the DSS Program Office and should not be changed or deleted.  New entries in this file should not be made.

This file is used to associate a local DSS Identifier with each medicalcenter division.  Do not use FileMan to enter/edit data in this file.  The DSS Site Manager is provided with a specific menu option with which toperform file updates.

This file is used to associate a DSS Department code with each activeward in the medical center.  Do not use FileMan to enter/edit data in thisfile.  The DSS Site Manager is provided with a specific menu option withwhich to perform file updates.

This file contains the names of those Mental Health Instrumentswhich are being tracked by the Decision Support System.  Each recordin this file refers to a record in the MH INSTRUMENT file (#601). Entries in this file are determined by the DSS Program Office and shouldnot be changed or deleted.  New entries in this file should not be made.

This file is a translation table for converting free text lab test resultsinto numeric codes for use by Decision Support System (DSS). The translation table is used to translate the RESULTS field (#10) ofthe LAB RESULTS EXTRACT file (#727.824) to a standard numeric code toindicate the test result when text has been entered instead of a numericvalue.  The translated value is used to populate the LAB RESULTSTRANSLATION field (#27) of the LAB RESULTS EXTRACT file (#727.824). This file has been populated initially with common free text values for lab test results that were compiled by the DSS Program Office.  Sites may add new entries to this file as needed with other free text values andtheir corresponding translation codes.

This file contains data elements as specified by the Decision Support System (DSS) Program Office for the MAS Admission extract from existing DHCP files. Entries into this file are made by extracting data from several files. Once approved by the DSS site manager, entries in thisfile are loaded into an electronic mail message and sent to the commercial vendor. This file is intended to be used for validation purposes only. Entries should be made only by the extract load routine.  Since validation techniques will be determined by the local site, it isintended that the site add whatever cross references deemed necessary.However, this file contains one nationally determined cross reference,the "AC" cross reference on the EXTRACT NUMBER field (#2).  This crossreference is used by the DSS Extracts software package as an essentialfeature for managing and purging data in this file and should not bemodified.  This file should NOT be modified directly using VA FileMan.

This file contains data elements as specified by the Decision Support System (DSS) Program Office for the Laboratory extract from existing DHCP files. Entries into this file are made by extracting data by two different methods depending upon whether or not LMIP codes are used. Using LMIP codes, the data are extracted, in large part, from the WKLD LOG file (#64.03) which is populated by a routine provided by the Laboratory development team.  Not using LMIP codes, the data are derived from several Lab files as well as from several other DHCP files. Once approved by the DSS site manager, entries in this file are loaded into an electronic mail message and sent to the commercial vendor. This file is intended to be used for validation purposes only. Entries should be made only by the extract load routine.  Since validation techniques will be determined by the local site, it isintended that the site add whatever cross references deemed necessary.However, this file contains one nationally determined cross reference,the "AC" cross reference on the EXTRACT NUMBER field (#2). This file is used to hold information to create data for the inpatientpopulation on the date that a site chooses to begin using DSS.  Datais entered into this file by a background job which identifies allpatients who were in the facility on the selected date.  Then theseentries are moved, by another background job, to the ADMISSION EXTRACTfile (#727.802) to be transferred to the DSS package.  Once the transferto the ADMISSION EXTRACT file (#727.802) is complete, data is purgedfrom this file, and it becomes inactive. Data elements in this file should never be entered, edited, or deletedthrough the VA FileMan.

This file is used to hold information to create data for the physicalmovements (transfers and discharges) for inpatients on the date that asite chooses to begin using DSS.  Data is entered into this file by abackground job which identifies all patients who were in the facilityon the selected date.  Then these entries are moved, by anotherbackground job, to the PHYSICAL MOVEMENT EXTRACT file (#727.808)to be transferred to the DSS package.  Once the transfer to the PHYSICALMOVEMENT EXTRACT file (#727.808) is complete, data is purged fromthis file, and it becomes inactive.  Data elements in this file should never be entered, edited, or deletedthrough the VA FileMan.

This file is used to hold information to create data for the treatingspecialty changes for inpatients on the date that a sitechooses to begin using DSS.  Data is entered into this file by abackground job which identifies all patients who were in the facilityon the selected date.  Then these entries are moved, by anotherbackground job, to the TREATING SPECIALTY CHANGE EXTRACT file (#727.817)to be transferred to the DSS package.  Once the transfer to theTREATING SPECIALTY CHANGE EXTRACT file (#727.817) is complete, datais purged from this file, and it becomes inactive.  Data elements in this file should never be entered, edited, or deletedthrough the VA FileMan.

This file contains various data extract information utilized by the DSSExtracts software.  This data includes the last date an extract wasrun, the Austin queue receiving the extract data, and extract setupinformation. Data in this file should be entered and edited only by using the DSSsoftware and not by direct access via VA FileMan. **TECH NOTE**When adding a new extract, make sure that the "LAST DATE XXX" is onsame piece of the 7 node as the "XXX" field is on the 7.1 node.
This sub-file/field contains DSS Prosthetics divisions and theirrespective LAST DATE(s) extracted.

This file holds data from the IV module of the InpatientMedications package to be extracted by the DSS software.  Data is enteredinto this file by routine ECXPIV1 which is called by statistics optionsin the IV module. Data is deleted from this file after it isextracted in a form to be shipped to the commercial software. Data in this file should not be entered, edited, or deleted throughdirect access via VA FileMan.

This file holds the DSS translation tables for entries in the HOSPITALLOCATION file (#44).  For each clinic, this file holds its name, stop code,credit stop code, and DSS alternatives for both stop code and credit stopcode.  Also included is a field indicating which code should be sent to theDSS commercial software, that is, stop code, credit stop code, or both.  Ifthere is no data in this file for a given clinic, the stop code in theHOSPITAL LOCATION file (#44) will be used.  If DSS alternate stopcodes are entered, they will be used in place of those entered in theHOSPITAL LOCATION file (#44).  This file should be reviewed by theDSS manager on a regular basis and corrected as needed.  Since severalfields in this file are linked to fields in the HOSPITAL LOCATIONfile (#44), data in this file should be entered and edited only by usingthe DSS software and not by direct access via VA FileMan.

This file contains the national standard clinic codes to be sent to thecommercial software as part of the DHCP DSS Extracts software.  Entriesin this file are compiled by the DSS Program Office. This is a standard file exported with the DSS Extracts software.  Noadditions, deletions, or modifications to entries in this file arepermitted.  As updates become necessary, a new version of this filewill be released nationally.
The long description for the type of clinic represented by this code.This discription may be used to provide guidance in assigningnational codes to clinics.

This file contains various data extract information utilized by the DSS Extracts software. Data in this file should be entered and edited only byusing the DSS software and not by direct access via VA FileMan.

This file contains various data extract information utilized by the DSS Extracts software. Data in this file should be entered and edited only by using the DSS software and not by direct access via VA FileMan.

This file holds information needed to determine the DSS drug productcode for any entry in the local DRUG file (#50) which has been matchedto an entry in the NATIONAL DRUG file (#50.6).  The determining factorsare VA classification, route of administration, and, in some cases,specific VA product name.  These factors have been determined by theDSS pharmaceutical task force based, in part, on information providedby the National Drug File (NDF) task force.  Use of this file dependson fields in the local DRUG file (#50) which were set by the matchingprocess in the National Drug File package as specified by the NDF taskforce. For these reasons, it is imperative that neither the data nor thedata dictionary for this file be modified at the local VAMC.  Asmodifications are required, they will be sent from the developers asdirected by the involved task force members.
Drug identifier composed of two numbers, separated by the letter "A",that represents drug and dose form from the NATIONAL DRUG file (#50.6).

This file holds data from the Unit Dose module of the InpatientMedications package to be extracted by the DSS software.  Data is enteredinto this file by routine ECXUD1 which is called by pick list optionsin the Unit Dose module. Data is deleted from this file after it isextracted in a form to be shipped to the commercial software. Data in this file should not be entered, edited, or deleted throughdirect access via VA FileMan.

This file provides codes associated with DSS production units.  Thesecodes are used when the DSS Site Manager develops DSS Department codesto be associated with various medical center entities such as wards. This file is intended for read only purposes.  It must not be modifiedin any way by the local site.  Modifications to this file will bedistributed nationally in accordance with guidance provided by theDSS Bedford Technical Services Office.

The Rad Modality Defined Terms file is required by the VistA Imagingapplication; entries in this file are as defined in the DICOM Standards PS3.3 - 1998 under section General Series Attribute Descriptions(C.7.3.1.1).  The Radiology developers update entries in the file inaccordance to changes in the DICOM Standards.  THIS FILE CAN NOT BEEDITED. This file is pointed to by the RAD/NUC MED PROCEDURE (#71), and for eachactive procedure a modality or modalities must be identified.  It ispossible for a single procedure to be performed on multiple modalities.For example, a GASTROGRAPHIN UGI procedure can be done on a RadioFluoroscopy and a Computed Radiography modality. VistA Imaging software will build a modality worklist using this file andthe RAD/NUC MED PROCEDURE file entries.  The worklist identifies thescheduled radiology cases to be performed on the individual modality(equipment).

WARNING:  ENTRIES SHOULD NOT BE ADDED/DELETED/CHANGED FROM THIS FILE. This file contains only data supplied by the Office of Patient Care Services.  The data are sent to the Radiology development and maintenance teams as an Excel spreadsheet.  Updates to the data are sent as a comprehensive spreadsheet, so all entries in this file must be deleted before loading the new comprehensive spreadsheet into this file. This file provides data for certain CPT Codes.  One of the data items is PROCEDURE TYPE.  The PROCEDURE TYPE is similar to the Type of Imaging in the IMAGING TYPE file (#79.2), and is needed from this file to comparePROCEDURE TYPES nationally for performance monitors and performancemeasures, because not all sites are assigning the same Type of Imaging tothe same CPT Code via the RAD/NUC MED PROCEDURES file (#71).

This file contains the approved list of national services.  Entries inthis file are standard and should not be edited or deleted.  A LOCALSERVICE? field allows you to designate each national service as a'local' service.   A T&L UNIT field is provided for associating T&L units with each 'local' service.
Identify the T&L units which are associated with this 'local' service.
General Privilege associated with this National Service.  Used by theCredentials Tracking module of the Quality Assurance package.

File contains VAMC management information for each fiscal year.Data includes assigned FTEE by service by FY, workload data, andcontract information.  **WARNING**  All data should be inputinto this file through the IMS enter/edit menu options.
Service is a pointer to the National Service file.  Choose the servicefor which FTEE data is to be entered.
Enter the contract number which uniquely identifies the contract.
This multiple contains workload data for the VAMC, nursing home,or domiciliary.
This multiple contains workload data for all outpatient facilities.
This file serves as a planning tool for management.  All localVAMC planned equipment may be tracked - including IRM/ADPand regional high technology equipment list items.
Enter the justification for the planned equipment item.
File contains staffing data by service for each pay period.
Service is a pointer to the National Service file.  Choose the servicefor which staffing data is to be entered.
File of Regulatory Agencies for documenting citations.
This file is used for Minor Design and Minor Miscellaneous PrioritizationMethodology.  Here points are given according to the type of spaceundergoing 100% renovation or new construction.
This contains the H-08-9 Chapters for Space Planning.  It is used toidentify areas where space is added or renovated in construction projects.
File of Construction Project functional categories.
File of Construction Progect budget categories.

The Quality Improvement Checklist Question file stores the pertinent data about each question which is answered on the QUIC semi-annual survey.Fields include the question text, type of response expected,parameters of the expected answer, and the surveys in which thequestion is asked. This file arrives at the VAMC with data, and SHOULD NOT be altered locally.
This field contains the Quality Improvement Checklist question as it isdisplayed on the Answer Survey and Edit Survey Entry options.
This field points to each Quality Improvement Checklist survey which will contain this question.

The Quality Improvement Checklist Survey Date file contains all data necessary to define a specific survey.  The survey is conducted semi-annually.  The file contains the beginning and ending dates of the survey,the number of questions in the survey, and the survey status.  This file arrives at the VAMC with data, and SHOULD NOT be altered locally.

The Quality Improvement Checklist Sort Data file contains the sort mechanisms necessary to generate the national reports.  The file containsall VAMCs which will answer the survey questionnaire, theiridentifying station number, region, and other sort fields.This file arrives at the VAMC with data, and SHOULD NOT be alteredlocally.

The Quality Improvement Checklist file contains stationspecific data for the semi-annual survey.  The station's answer for each question on a selected survey is stored in this file.Also included are fields for approval/sign-off, sign-off date,and the date the data is transmitted to the centralized data base.Data in this file SHOULD NOT be altered through the use ofVA FileMan; input should take place ONLY through the Quality Improvement Checklist menu options.
This field is a pointer to the QUIC Survey Date file.
For a selected survey, this field stores the question numberwhich is a pointer to the QUIC Question File.

This file will be used to "automatically queue" the options on theQUIC "DHCP Extract Reports" menu.  The file consists of the optionmenu text and a list of variables which must be "pre-answered"in order to queue each extract report to print.  The file arrives atthe VAMC with some data.  Data in this file SHOULD NOT be alteredthrough the use of VA FileMan; input should take place ONLY throughthe Quality Improvement Checklist menu options.
This field contains the variable name which must be "pre-answered"before calling the entry point to queue the extract report.

This field contains the pointer values for a variable.  The user must"pre-answer" this field prior to queueing the extract reports toprint.  The user may supply more than one answer (i.e., a number of laboratory tests).

This field will contain comments from the transmitting facility thatare entered by the approving official at sign-off time.  These commentscan be whatever the facility wishes, for example, suggestions fornew functionality and/or enhancements to future surveys.
The station's answer to each word-processing Quality ImprovementChecklist survey question will be stored in this multiple.

This file contains the reports for registered exams.  These reports areusually first dictated by the interpreting physician before being enteredby the transcriptionist. The Radiology/Nuclear Medicine software includes an HL7 interface tosupport report entry using voice recognition systems. The data in this file has three basic sections:          I. Demographic information about the file                - patient, date reported, date entered etc.        II. Text Data                - clinical history, report and impression       III. Computed Fields that obtain data from patient's exam record                - technician, procedure etc. The computed fields can be a very efficent way to do File Man prints andsearches of exam record data, as opposed to doing prints and searchesthrough the 'RAD/NUC MED PATIENT' file.  Data Storage ------------The data for the 'RAD/NUC MED REPORTS file is stored in the global. This global is very volatile and should be journaled.It should also be translated if the operating system supports this function. Because of the large amount of disk space the report text will demand ofthe system, the module has a 'Purge Data' function that willallow the site manager to delete the 'REPORT TEXT' and 'CLINCIAL HISTORY'fields on a periodic basis. It is up to the computer site manager andthe imaging coordinator to determine how long this data will remainon-line. The 'IMPRESSION' text will not be purged. In the future, the module will also have an archive function.  Input Templates ---------------The following is a list of input templates used by the packageand the entry in the OPTIONS file (#19) that uses the template:                    Compiled Name              Routine    Description; Option(s) ----              --------   ---------------------- RA REPORT EDIT                                  information into this file;                              RA RPTENTRY  RA VERIFY          REPORT ONLY                  RA BATCHVERIFY, RA RPTVERIFY  RA PRE-VERIFY REPORT EDIT    Used to edit reports and associated                               information in this file. Does not allow                              report verification; RA RESIDENT PRE-VERIFY  RA PRE-VERIFY REPORT ONLY    Used to pre-verify reports;                              RA RESIDENT PRE-VERIFY If any modifications to these input templates are needed for localpurposes, then great care should be taken not to degrade any branching logicin the template.  Print Templates ---------------                   Compiled Name              Routine    Description; Option(s) -----             --------   ----------------------  RA REPORT           PRINT STATUS                Includes date verified, routing queue, date                              printed, printed by ward/clinic.                              RA RPTDISTPRINTSTATUS  Sort Templates --------------The package does not use any sort templates associated with thisfile.
This is a multiple field containing a log of actions that have been takenon this report record.

This field contains the report text for the imaging exam. The reporttext is written by the interpreting physician and may be entered into thesystem by a transcriptionist.  A report may also be entered into DHCP whenthe interpreting physician uses a voice recognition system. If the interpreting physician requests a standard report, the informationin this field is copied from the 'Report Text' field of the 'StandardReports' file.
This multiple field holds pointer values to the Image file (2005).

This field contains the 'impression text' of the rad/nuc med examassociated with this report.  The 'impression text' gives a quick summaryof the 'report text'.  It is written by the interpreting physician and isentered into the system by the transcriptionist. The system will allow theinterpreting physician to directly enter this information into the'impression text' field through a voice recognition system. If the interpreting physician requests a standard report, the informationin this field is copied from the 'impression text' field of the 'StandardReports' file.

This field may contain a patient's clinical history as well asinstructions to the interpreting physician.  For example, theinstructions might be for the physician to interpret the exam images torule out the possibility of the patient having a certain disease. The 'additional clinical history' is written by the interpreting physicianand is entered into the system by the transcriptionist.  Voice Recognitionsystems allow the interpreting physician to directly enter thisinformation into the 'additional clinical history' field.

This multiple subfile contains date-stamped reports that were unverifiedand amended.  The previous verified data that existed before the reportwas amended is stored here.  As a security precaution, these fields arereleased to the site as uneditable.

This file contains the standard report text that the interpretingphysician can choose from when dictating a report.  The transcriptionistis usually the person who copies the standard report into the appropriateexam's report record while using the 'Report Enter/Edit' function. The transcriptionist will only be given the 'Select STANDARD REPORTS'prompt during the 'Report Enter/Edit' function if the 'division'parameter controlling standard reports use is set to 'yes'.  Data Storage ------------The data for the 'STANDARD REPORTS' file is stored in the global. At the present time this file is very static after day-oneinitialization is complete.  However, it still should be journaled.It should also be translated if the operating system supports this function.  Input Templates ---------------The following is a list of input templates used by the packageand the entry in the OPTIONS file (#19) that uses the template:                      Compiled Name                Routine  Description; Option(s) ----                -------  ---------------------- RA STANDARD REPORT ENTRY                  Used to enter/edit entries in this file;                               RA STANDRPTS  This template should not be modified.  Print Templates --------------- The following is a list of print templates used by the package:  Name                            Description; Option(s) ----                            ------------------------ RA STANDARD REPORTS LIST        Print the impression and report for the                                 entries in this file;                                 RA STANDPRINT  Sort Templates --------------The package does not use any sort templates associated with thisfile.

This field contains the text associated with this standard report. When this standard report is chosen to be associated with an exam, theinformation in this field is copied into the 'report text' field for thatexam.

This field contains the impression associated with this standard report.The impression is used to give a quick summary of the report text. When this standard report is chosen to be associated with an exam, theinformation in this field is copied into the 'impression text' field forthat exam.

This file provides the mechanism to group draft reports into logicalcategories to help in the efficent processing of these reports. Usually, an interpreting physician dictates a series of reports onto onetape. The transcriptionist receives the tape and the patient foldersassociated with the reports dictated on the tape. By placing the reportsfor that tape in a single batch, usually by interpreting physician name,the following processes will be improved:          o re-printing the reports if the printer malfunctions.         o verifying the report can be done by batch with the           user only answering the 'report status' prompt for           each report. The system automatically proceeds through           the reports in the batch.         o if more than one transcriptionist has to print his/her reports           on the same printer then batch printing prevents           interweaving of each transcriptionist's reports. Naming of batches is controlled by the user and most often the name is thename of the interpreting physician whose dictation the user istranscribing. A user can only enter reports into a batch that he/shecreated.   Data Storage ------------The data for the 'REPORT BATCHES' file is stored in the global.  This file is volatile and should be journaled. It should alsobe translated if the operating system supports this function.  Input Templates ---------------The package does not use any input templates associated with thisfile.  Print Templates ---------------The package does not use any print templates associated with thisfile.  Sort Templates --------------The package does not use any sort templates associated with thisfile.
This multiple field contains information about the reports in this batch.

This file contains the names of the distribution queues and thecategory of reports for each queue.  Data Storage------------ The data for 'REPORT DISTRIBUTION QUEUE' is stored under the (74.3 global.  Input Templates--------------- The following is a list of input templates used by the package andthe entry in the OPTIONS file (#19) that uses the template. Name                     Description; Option(s)----                     ---------------------RA DISTRIBUTION EDIT     Used to edit the report                         distribution queue. RA DISTRIBUTION LOG      Edits the activity log of the                         distribution queue whenever                         reports are printed.  This is                         done automatically by the system                         whenever reports are printed or                         re-printed from a queue.  Print Templates---------------The following is a list of print templates used by the package: Name                     Description; Option(s)----                     ----------------------RA DISTRIBUTION          Prints a list of names of                         the distribution queues and                         category of reports associated                         with each queue.   Sort Templates---------------The package does not use any sort templates associated withthis file.
This is a multiple field that tracks activity associated with thedistribution queue.

This file points to the Rad/Nuc Med Reports file (#74). It contains onlyverified reports associated with the various active distribution queues. Input Templates---------------The package does not use any input templates associated with this file.  Print Templates---------------The following is a list of print templates used by the package: Name                        Description; Option(s)----                       ----------------------RA ALL UNPRINTED REPORTS    Prints all unprinted reports for a distribution                            queue. RA PRINTED REPORTS          Prints a list of previously printed reports for                            a distribution queue. RA UNPRINTED REPORTS        Prints a list of unprinted reports in alpha-                            betical order by patient name.  Sort Templates--------------The following is a list of sort templates associated with this file: Name                        Related Print Template----                        ----------------------RA ALL UNPRINTED            RA ALL UNPRINTED REPORTS RA CLINIC BY PRINT DATE     RA PRINTED REPORTS RA WARD BY PRINT DATE       RA PRINTED REPORTS

This field contains the version of a radiology/nuclear medicine reportprior to amendments.  It is saved at the time the report is unverified.Data retained includes any of the following that existed on the record atthe time it was unverified: Procedure/modifiers, Clinical History,Impression, Report Text, Primary and Secondary Diagnostic Codes, Verifiername/date/esig, Pre-verifier name/date/esig, Primary and Secondary Staffand Residents. This data is stored in a subfile that supports multiple occurrences ofamendments for one report.

Contains the site-specific parameters (such as site name) for each VAMC.This file serves the entire QM package.  Each component, such asOccurrence Screening, has one set of fields in the file.  This set offields is both number and node spaced.  This file is pointed to by theOccurrence Screening file (#741).  This file is populated at the site. PACKAGES USING SITE PARAMETER FILE:   Occurrence Screen 2.0   Credentials Tracking 1.0   Patient Representative 2.0   Incident Reporting   Survey Generator
This field contains the clinic(s) that are used to schedule patientadmissions.  The data entered in this field is used by the auto enroll todetermine which admissions are scheduled.
This field is a pointer to the INSTITUTION file (#4).  It is used by integrated sites to store the names of the Medical Centers in theintegrated group.
This file contains the print and sort macros generated by the Ad Hocreport mechanism.  The records in this file should be accessed onlythrough the Ad Hoc report options.
This multiple field contains the data elements that the user chosewhen building the macro.  The order of entries in this field isthe same as the order in which they were chosen by the user.

Contains an entry for each QM component, such as Occurrence Screening.Each package entry contains the user's name, date of entry, and type ofentry for every time the QA OCCURRENCE SCREEN file (#741) is accessed.This file is automatically populated every time access is made to thisfile.
This is the trail of the activity associated with the IEN of the file.
Contains Occurrence Screening data for each occurrence screened, withpatient name at the .01 level.  This file is populated at the site.
This is where the reviewer data for Clinical, Peer, and Management reviewsis entered or changed.
This is where all data on committee reviews is stored.
This is where the reviewer may enter a comment about the occurrenceor the review of the occurrence.
This is where the occurrence is attributed to the individuals involvedin this patient's care.
This is where the medical team attribution data is stored.
This is where the data is stored for the attribution to hospital location.
This is where the committee may enter a comment about the occurrenceor the review of the occurrence.
Contains the list of screens required by the Occurrence Screen circular,with their descriptions.  This file arrives populated with the standardscreens.  The site can add their own screens also.
This is where the screen exception data is entered.
This is where the action to be taken data is stored.
Contains the list of review levels, such as Clinical and Peer.  This datais used in the review process.  This file arrives populated.
Contains the names of persons authorized to be Clinical reviewers.  Thisdata is used in the review process.  This file is populated at the site.

Contains the list of reasons for Clinical referral for furtherreview, itemized for each screen, as defined by the OccurrenceScreen circular.  This data is used in the review process.This file arrives populated, but may be edited at the site.
Contains the list of exceptions for each screen, as defined by theOccurrence Screen circular.   This data is used in the review process.This file arrives populated, but may be edited at the site.
Contains the list of standardized review findings.  This data is used inthe review process.  This file arrives populated.
Contains a list of standardized actions to be taken as a result of thereview findings.  This file arrives populated.
Contains the severity of outcome as defined by QM.  This data is used inthe review process.  This file arrives populated.

Contains an entry for each treating specialty at the site, indicatingwhich are considered to be Acute Care, Special Care, Intermediate Care,NHCU, or Psychiatry for QM purposes.  This data is used in auto enrollment.This file is populated at the site.
Contains the list of Medical Teams at the site.  This data is used in thereview process.  This file is populated at the site.
Contains the number of cases screened (i.e., total admissions, transfers,etc.).  This data is entered manually from data provided by MAS, and itis used for the Semi-Annual Report.
Contains the list of standing committees at the site.  This data is usedin the review process.  This file is populated at the site.
Contains historical list of dates that auto enrollment was run.  Thisdata is used for determining the need for reruns.  This file is populatedautomatically every time auto enroll is run.
Contains the data associated to a patient who is involved in an incident.
Enter the Responsible Service(s) for the incident.
Contains the appropriate patient diagnosis to date for the patient.
Contains the approved list of incidents.  Pointed to by the QA IncidentReport file.
Contains the approved medication errors associated with a medication errors incident type.
This file holds some of the reasons for a death of an individual in a hospital setting.
Contains the applicable QA Report Form(s) for this incident.
Contains the data associated to a particular incident.  Pointed to by theQA Patient Incident Review file.
Contains the description of the incident.
Contains the action(s) taken by the medical center.
Contains any Pertinent Information as it applies to the incident.
Contains the approved incident locations.  Pointed to by the QA IncidentReport file.
Contains the totals of incident types.  Totals are broken down by medical center, quarterly date, and whether they're non investigated or investigated incidents.
Contains the totals for investigated and non-investigated types of deaths.
This file contains the full description of a monitor.  Some of the datais purely descriptive.  Other data in this file is used by the autoenroll portion of the Clinical Monitoring System.
A condition applies a True/False test on selected data elements in apatient's record.  If the result of the test is true that patient'srecord is captured for further processing.
This word processing field defines the standard of care to be monitored.
This word processing field defines the criteria necessary to meet thestandard of care.
This field defines the rationale for the use of this monitor.  You mayselect all that apply.
If a rationale was chosen that requires an explanation please explainthe reasons for its selection.
When a patient meets the conditions of the monitor and falls out, theother data to capture entries define which data elements in the patient'srecord should be collected.

This file contains the patients who were found to fall out for givenmonitors.  Fall outs are created by the auto enroll batch run or bymanual entry.  Any fall out record may be manually edited and its dataor data elements changed.
This is a pointer to the DATA ELEMENT file.  Enter a valid data element.

This file contains the statistics created by an active monitor and isupdated by the auto enroll batch run.  The statistics are broken downby monitor and are further broken down by the time frame the monitoris running in.
This file contains the conditions a user may select when building amonitor.  New conditions may be added by a programmer.
The description in this field is displayed when the user enters'?CONDITION' at the 'Select CONDITION:' prompt.
This field lists all the data elements that can be captured by thiscondition.
This file contains the data elements from DHCP a user may select to becaptured when a patient falls out for a given monitor.  New dataelements may be added by a programmer.
Enter the (sub) dictionary number where this field resides.
This field is used as the data for the DIR("?",#) strings.  The firstline of text goes into DIR("?",1), the second into DIR("?",2), andso on.
This is a larger message shown to the user before the prompt for thisdata element is presented.

This file contains groups of data from other DHCP files.  Group datais used by many conditions to determine if a patient should fall outfor a given monitor.  Users may create new groups and add or deletegroup members from existing groups
This field contains the actual members of the group.
This file contains the dates that auto enroll ran and the monitors thatran for that date.
This field contains the monitor(s) that auto enroll ran.
This file contains the rationales that may be attached to a monitor.The rationales are the same as those used by JCAHO.  Other entriesmay be added by the user.
This file contains the time frames over which a monitor may aggregatestatistical data.  New time frames may be added by a programmer.
This file contains information on consumer contacts.Data is not sent with this file; it is populated at the site.
This is the employee allegedly involved in the issue or the employee receiving the compliment.
This is the person or service the issue is referred to for action.
This is a code for a brief statement of the issue.
This is the service or section that is associated with this issue.  Entera service name or if a section is involved, enter the section.
This is a written discussion of the issue(s).
This is the type of QM activity for this same issue.
This is a discussion of how the issue or issues were resolved.
This is the person(s) who will be notified of this patient contact.

This file contains a list of reasons/issues for contacts.  Some reasons are called headings and may not be edited or added to by theuser.  Headings from version 1.0 were inactivated with the installation ofversion 2.0.  The new headings are as follows: Staff Courtesy, Access/Timeliness, One Provider, Decisions/Preference, Emotional NeedsCoordination of Care, Patient Education, Family Involvement, Physical Comfort, Transitions, Risk Management Complaints, Medical Records Issues, Eligibility Issues, Environmental Issues, Regulation Issues, Requests for Information and Compliments.  Only Nationally exported Issues Codes can be used.
This is the definition of the code name.

This file contains the Services, Levels of Care, and QualityAspects for the Quality Matrix used by the Office of QualityManagement to measure patient care.This file is exported with data and should not be edited.

This file contains names of congressional offices or persons that madecontact with the site concerning patient issues.  Data is not exportedwith the file.  Data in this file is only used for contacts that arecongressional in nature.

This file contains Services/Disciplines for Patient Representative Reports of Contacts.  Local sites may make entries in this file.  Eachservice or section must point to the Contact Disciplines file (#745.5).

Our customer Service Standards were developed by listening to ourcustomers--the patients who daily come to us expecting the highestquality care and services available.  You told us that the following 10 areas were the most important to you.  We have turned those areasinto standards that you can expect us to meet.  Whenever we don't meetthem, you can expect us to improve until we do.  We want you to chooseto come to the VA for all your health care needs.
This is the QA survey generator file.
This field will allow any person whose name is entered to perform anyactions on a survey that would normally be done by the survey creator.

This field will contain any items which the survey creator will want toknow about for demographical purposes.  Examples would be race, age, dateof birth, job type, etc.  For consistency purposes any item entered herewhich will be used for reporting must be marked as a required answer.

The instructions for use field should contain anything that the survey participants need to know in order to take the survey.  It is up to the survey creator to assure that the instructions are adequate,and that the essential things are present.
This file holds the names of files which may be referenced for demographicpurposes during survey responses by users.
This file holds the questions for the surveys located in

This field has the internal entry number of a question, which can bedifferent from the actual question number or question position on asurvey.  For example the IFN may be 1 but the question may come out as 20on the actual survey because questions may be swapped around.

This field contains the actual text of the question.  It is enteredexactly as the creator wishes the participants to see it.  No formattingis attempted and it is displayed as it is typed in by the creator.

This multiple field will hold the actual text of a multiple choicequestion.  The answers will be displayed in accordance to the MULTIPLECHOICE TYPE.  No extra formatting is needed, only the text of eachselection        correct:   First choice     incorrect:   A.  First choice     incorrect:   1.  First choice
Holds the responses given to survey questions by the survey participants.
This field is the internal file number (IFN) of a specific question infile 748.25.
If the type is a code, this field has the actual code as it will bepresented to the participant.

This file contains all information pertaining to an imaging order enteredfor a patient. The file structure like that of the Rad/Nuc Med Patientfile in future, will allow the storage of nuclear medicine, nuclearmagnetic resonance and other types of imaging data.   Data Storage------------The data for 'RAD/NUC MED ORDERS' file is stored in the This file is very volatile and should be journaled and translated if theoperating system supports these two functions.   Input Templates---------------The following is a list of input templates used by the packageand in the OPTIONS file (#19) that uses the template:  Name            Routine       Description: Option(s)----            --------      ---------------------- RA ORDER EXAM                                procedure;                             RA ORDEREXAM RA QUICK EXAM     ORDER                      exams for a patient.                             RA ORDEREXAM RA OERR EDIT                 Edit an unreleased order that was entered                             through the OE/RR package.  Print Templates---------------There are no print templates associated with this file.  Sort Templates--------------There are no sort templates associated with this file.

This field may contain a written clinical history pertinent to theprocedure requested, as well as instructions to the interpretingphysician. For example, the instructions might be for the interpretingphysician to read the exam films to rule out the possibility of a patienthaving a certain disease. This field is used as the 'Clinical History' that appears on theprinted report for each exam associated with this visit.
This multiple field is used to store the rad/nuc med procedure modifiersthat are associated with this exam.

This field is a multiple that contains dates and times the status of therequest is changed. The status changes will only be recorded if theDivision Parameter 'Track Request Status Changes' is set to 'YES'.
This is a word processing field for entering the reasonan order is on hold.

This file contains the reasons a user may select from when placing anorder in the 'HOLD' or 'CANCELLED' status. Data Storage------------The data for the 'RAD/NUC MED REASON' file is stored in the    Input Templates---------------There are no input templates associated with this file.   Print Templates---------------There are no print templates associated with this file.   Sort Templates--------------There are no sort templates associated with this file.

This file is a map of Major Concepts within the Lexicon Utility andcontained in the expression file (#757.01).  While the primary purpose of this file is for file maintenance, it also supports various other functions such as the display of classification codes by linking conceptsto codes and the ability to filter out unwanted search responses by linkingconcepts to semantic classes and types.

This file records the usage of concepts by applications performing lookupsusing the Special Lookup Routines provided with the Lexicon Utility.  A listingof concept usage in decending order may be found at the "AF" index.

This file contains all text pertaining to the Major Concepts, ConceptSynonyms,  Concept Lexical Variants, Synonymous Lexical Variants, andModified Concepts.  It includes displayable text, distinguishing text (thatportion of text that makes a modified concept different from the parentconcept) and the term definitions (when available).  Searches areconducted using the special look-up routine LEXA1.
This file contains the type of the expression (i.e., Major Concept, Synonyms,Lexical Variants, Modified Concepts).
This file contains the form of the expression (acronym, plural, trade name,etc.).
Definition of an expression when available.

SNOMED CT concepts are organized in hierarchies with multiple levels of granularity. This file stores the names of the hierarchies and whenapplicable, the Lexicon Subset the hierarchy is a member of.
This file contains classification codes from multiple classificationsystems (i.e., ICD, CPT, DSM, SNOMED, Title 38, NANDA, NIC, COSTAR, COSTART,CRISP, etc.).
This file contains the descriptive titles for medical terminology anddiagnosis and classification systems.
This file contains the definition of a characterposition in a code of a coding system where thecharacter positions have meaning.

This file contains words which are meant to be excluded either fromindexing, look-up, or both indexing and look-up.  NOTE:  Data Entries in this file should not be altered by the site  This file requires re-indexingto occur in a specified sequence.  The complete re-indexing instructionsare included in the Technical Manual.
This is a history of descriptions for a characterposition identified by a code fragment.

If the user input contains one of the words (single word) in this file, itwill be replaced by the corresponding term (one or more words).  NOTE:  DataEntries in this file should not be altered by the site.  This file requiresre-indexing to occur in a specified sequence.  The complete re-indexing instructions are included in the Technical Manual.

This file provides feedback from the sites regarding the content of the Lexicon.  This is done either by a user through a calling application(user unresolved narratives) or by the calling application (applicationunresolved narratives).  USER UNRESOLVED NARRATIVES occur when the user searches the Lexicon and fails to find a suitable expression in the Expression file (#757.01).  If the user select to use his/her originaltext, then user's input is temporarily stored in this file.  However, for aUser Unresolved Narrative to be stored, the calling application must be defined in the Subset Definition file (757.2) and have the Unresolved Narrative flag set to 1.  APPLICATION UNRESOLVED NARRATIVE occur when anapplication detects a problem with an expression in the Expression file (757.01).  The application can return the Internal Entry Number (IEN) of that expression along with a short comment stating the problem. Periodicallythe entries in this file will be packed up into a mail message and sent to G.LEXICON@ISC-SLC.VA.GOV for consideration for possible inclusionin the Lexicon.  After the mail message is sent the entries in thisfile are deleted.  NOTE:  This file is exported without data.

This multiple stores the Standards Development Organization's (SDO) nomenclature that identifies the versions of their code systems and theirassociated dates. This information will be essential to applications thatshare code systems data with external agencies.

This file maps semantic classes and semantic types to the major concept,providing contextual meaning to both the term as well as the wordscontained in the term.  This semantic meaning, when applied to the terms,is used as a filter during term file look-ups.
This file contains the definitions of the semantical classes (groupings ofrelated semantical types).
Textual description of the semantical class containing (as a minimum) thesemantical types included within the semantical class.
This multiple field contains all of the classification systems (i.e., ICD,CPT, DSM) which have terms included in this semantical class.

The purpose of this multiple is to store designation IDs in the Lexicon. Designation is a word that terminologists use to encompass concept name, preferred term, expression, code text, synonyms, etc. In some systems such as SNOMED CT as well as the concept having a code (the SNOMED CT code), the individual designations (terms) belong to the concept each have their own codes (designation identifiers).
This file contains the definitions of the semantical types.
This multiple field contains all of the classification systems (i.e., ICD,CPT, DSM) which have terms included in this semantical type.
This file contains term categories provided by terminology source files.
This file contains the name and when applicable, the file number of the sourceof the terminology.

This field contains words which are negated within the expression, i.e, without mention of "complication", except "thumb", and other than an "open wound".  These type of negations will not be indexed in the word index, preventing erroneous search results.
Supplemental words (not found in the expression) which should be indexedto assist in look-up operations.
This is a list of the Lexicon Subsets this hierarchy can belong to.

This file contains the definitions for vocabulary subsets in the ClinicalLexicon, application definitions and user defaults (by application).These vocabularies (defined primarily by the search filter and the indexto be used while conducting searches) may be used during look-up in lieuof the main expression file (if indicated by either the applicationdefinition or the user's preferences).
This multiple contains user defaults for the search filter, display andthe vocabulary for a limited number of applications.

This file contains vocabulary subsets of the main Expressions file(#757.01).  Each sub-set is defined in file #757.2, and may contain[pointers to] terms which are exclusive to a discipline (i.e., Nursing), adevice (i.e., Grid Pad), or an application (i.e., Order Checking,Encounter Form, etc).
Contains a description of the general make-up of the vocabulary/subset.
This file contains some generic default screens in a DIC("S") format to beused while looking up terms in the Expression file.
Basic description of the intended use of the filter/screen.
This file contains some generic default display format to be used whilelooking up terms in the Expression File.
Contains a detailed description of exactly what is to be displayed.
This file is used to define a mapping between one coding system (sourcecode) to another coding system (target code).  The coding systems are listed in the Coding Systems file 757.03.
This field describes the purpose of the mapping. Mappings that lookthe same might have very different purposes.
This file contains the mappings from one coding system to another coding system.  Selection of a term or a code  fromone coding system can be translated to another coding system.
This multiple tracks the activation status of a code fragment.
This is a history of names/titles for acharacter position identified by a codefragment.
This multiple field contains a series of records indicatingthe mapping status (active or inactive) over time.
This is a history of Explanations for a characterposition identified by a code fragment.
This is a history of terminology synonyms for thecharacter identified by the code fragment.  Therecan be multiple synonyms.
This is a list of synonyms to include.

Not all screens (filters) will work with all vocabularies.  For example,the "Nursing Diagnosis only" screen used on the Dental vocabulary willresult in "No matches found".  This is a list of the vocabularies (thevocabulary mnemonic) which the screen will work successfully with.

This file contains a list of expressions (pointers) from the expression file#757.01 and shortcuts by context.  The expression(s) pointed to will be returnedimmediately if any of the context sensitive shortcuts associated with thatexpression are detected (exact match) in the users input.  The context must bea default value stored in the user defaults in the Subset Definition file#757.2 to permit the use of the shortcuts.
This is a list of shortcuts by context.

The Lexicon has the capability to maintain severalsets of shortcuts to rapidly access the expression file.Each of these shortcut sets is named by the context for whichthe shortcut set was meant to have been used.  The user mayselect this shortcut set by it's context name as their defaultset of shortcuts to use while searching the Lexicon.
This is a description of the intent of the context usage.

The Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) Copyright RegenstriefInstitute, Inc. and the UCUM Organization, Indianapolis, IN. All rightsreserved. This table of examples does not include all possible UCUMcodes. It does include those needed for routine laboratory and clinicalmeasures. This table was compiled by the National Library of Medicine,National Institutes of Health, U.S. Department of Health and HumanServices with content contributions from Intermountain Healthcare andthe Regenstrief Institute.

This is a series of pointers to expressions to which the WORD (.01) islinked to.  When a word like "CANCER" is linked to an expression like"CARCINOMA OF THE LUNG", the pointer of the expression is listed here anda separate index node is created in the expression file (757.01) atCANCER" will be able to retrieve "CARCINOMA OF THE LUNG."  During input,editing of this multiple field will only occur if ACTION (2) is set to "L"(linked words).

This file contains parameters associated with non-DHCP applicationsfrom whom the DHCP system can accept HL7 transmissions. This is the main file that sites must edit before they can begin receivingHL7 transmissions from another system.  This is done by using theNon-DHCP Application Parameters Enter/Edit option on the site manager'smenu.

This field is used to document the purpose of this non-DHCP applicationentry for local IRM staff.  Basic information about the types ofinformation exchanged, the frequency of the exchange, etc. should beentered.
This file contains a list of Vista applications that are capable ofsending and receiving HL7 transmissions.
This is applicable to HL7 v1.5 interfaces only. Enter the HL7 segmentsused by the Vista application.
This is applicable only to HL7 v1.5 interfaces. Enter the HL7 messagesused by the DHCP application.

This file is designed to contain the definition of each standard fieldused by the system.  The definition in this file can be compiled intoroutines which can perform the basic checks of data received from orsent to another system.
This multiple valued field contains information realted to use of this HL7filed by a specific application.
A list of message types supported by the system.
A list of segments supported by the system.
A list of data types and their corresponding processing rules.
A list of versions of standard protocols supported by the system.
This file is a table of statuses that are assigned to entries in theMessage Text file by the Messaging System. This file should not be modified locally.
This file is a table of error codes and messages that may be assigned toentries in the Message Text file by the Messaging System. This file should not be modified locally.
This file is a table of standard protocols supported by the MessagingSystem. This file should not be modified locally.
A list of educational degrees as specified in the HL7 standard,user-defined DEGREE table 0360.
The application that has specific use for this HL7 DEGREE VALUE.
This file contains information related to the processing of all incomingand outgoing messages.
The actual text of the incoming HL7 message(s).
This file is used to create and maintain unique message IDs.  It alsocontains a date/time when each ID was created.

This file is used to control the flow of messages from one system toanother. It is currently used by CIRN to permit sites to subscribe via HL7Master File updates to patient information. This subscription 'request'message contains the data necessary to update the Subscription Controlfile via the api: UPD HLSCN-subscription control numberHLNN-Logical Link nameHLTP-subscription type       0-patient descriptive only       1-patient clinical and descriptive       2-other (locally defined)HLAD-activation dateHLTD-termination date (optional)HLRAP-HL7 receiving applicationHLER-error messages (pass by reference) The patient file maintains a pointer to this file. When a clinical eventtakes place pertaining to a particular patient, the subscription controlnumber is looked up in the patient file, then a call is made to return thecurrent list of subscribers using: GET HLSCN-subscription control numberHLTP-subscription type (null returns ALL)HLCL-HL7 1.6 client protocol (optional, returned in first piece of return     array.HLL-return array. Always in format HLL("LINKS",n)=CLIENT     LINK HL7 1.6, Patch 14 provides additional documentation on the HLL array anddynamic addressing in general.
Text is placed in this word processing field using the RUNDIARYAPI.  The contents of this field is under complete control by the using application.
Text is placed in this word processing field using the MSGTEXTAPI.  The contents of this field is under complete control by the usingapplication.
This field holds the variable names and values declared by the calling application.

This field should be used by the application developer to describe the monitor, and how it is used.  (If desired, the application developer may add additional, more technical notes in the TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION word processing field.)
This field holds any additional technical notes deemed necessary by the monitor creator.

When a monitor runs, the M code can conditionally send a mail message to recipients.  This field, and other fields, are used to determine the recipients.  In addition, recipients can be added by M code immediately before the sending of the message. The fields used to determine mail message recipients are: * MAIL GROUPS (#60) - pointer to the Mail Group file (#3.8.)* RECIPIENTS (#61) - pointer to the New Person file (#200.)* REMOTES (#62) - free-text remote recipient addresses. And, remember that additional recipients can be added (by populating the XMY array) on-the-fly at the time the message is sent. Please refer to the documentation included with patch HL*1.6*106 for additional explanation.
See documentation for the MAIL GROUPS field.
See documentation for the MAIL GROUPS field.
This field holds information about the master job process, and cannot be modified by non-VistA HL7 applications.

When the master job runs, it checks all existing event monitors in the HL Event Monitor file (#776.1).  One entry in this Events Checked multiple ismade for every monitor found.  (See the fields in this multiple for additional information.)
This allows an application to store its own information relevant toresolving the event along with the event.
This file contains personal profiles for displaying events in the HL7 Monitor Event Log.
This is a list of sites that should be included in displays based on thisprofile.
Contains the body of an HL7 message, which excludes the message header segment.  For batch messages, it does not include the individual message header segments or the batch trailer segment.
Used to record each message as it is sent or received.  The content of themessage is stored in a file #777, as it might be sent to multiple locationsand applications.
This file is a table of event codes that are used by the MessagingSystem. This file should not be modified locally.
This file is a table of codes used by the Messaging System whenprocessing acknowledgement messages. This file should not be modified locally.
This file is a table of codes used by the Messaging System whenprocessing acknowledgement messages. This file should not be modified locally.

Per VHA Directive 2005-044, this file has been "locked down" by Data Standardization (DS).  The file definition (i.e. data dictionary) shall not be modified.  All additions, changes and deletions to entries in the file shall be done by Enterprise Reference Terminology (ERT) using the Master File Server (MFS), provided by Common Services (CS).  Creating and/or editing locally defined fields in the file are not permitted.  Use of locally defined fields that were created prior to the VHA Directive's 2005-044 effective date shall not be supported.This file is a table of country codes that are used by the MessagingSystem when building message header segments. This file should not be modified locally.
Describes the pair Status and Effective Date/Time for each reference term.
This file is a table of message structure codes that are defined by HL7table 0354.This file should not be modified locally.
This file contains parameters used by the HLO (HL7 Optimized)that are specific to the system the software is installed on.

The Health Leven Seven (Optimized) software (HLO) was released as patch HL*1.6*126 to the HL7 v1.6 software package.  Although it is structurally and functionally an independent system, it is officially part of HL7 1.6.  This is a messaging system similar to the old HL7 1.6 package, but it was designed from the ground up and is more robust, more capable, and supports a much higher message throughput.  This file is used create screens for reporting HLO messaging errors. A screenis a list of criteria used to either include or exclude specific error typesin an error report.  A screen is identified by its name.  The name should be namespaced and bedescriptive as to its intended use.
This should contain a full description of how this screen should be used, i.e.,its purpose.

This is a list of strings used to determine what errors should display.Each string is compared to each error that would otherwise be includedin the display.
